cuerpo: <p>Sono forme omografe e di funzione grammaticale identica, se non ci sono appigli di contesto o di eventuali concordanze nella frase è impossibile stabilire a priori quale intendesse l'autore.</p><p>In effetti, un revisore coscienzioso dovrebbe segnalare il problema se la forma risulta ambigua nella frase, e non a caso più di una volta credo di aver trovato scritta la forma in questione disambiguata esplicitamente con accenti tonici.</p>

<p>Girando per il Sud dell'Italia non è infrequente sentir dire 'crè', 'piscrè' e 'piscrìgh', quali parole dialettali significanti, rispettivamente, domani, dopodomani e il giorno successivo a dopodomani.</p><p>Chiaramente, così come accade per l'inglese, in assenza di un alfabeto fonetico le tre parole che ho scritto usando le lettere dell'alfabeto italiano, pur con gli accenti, non colgono precisamente il suono delle stesse, e sono possibili variazioni da una località a l'altra.</p><p>Pur nelle possibili diversità, vi risulta che nei dialetti parlati nel Nord dell'Italia vi sia una parola che significhi 'il giorno dopo dopodomani', o addirittura una  parola che significhi 'il giorno successivo al giorno dopo dopodomani'? </p>
titulo: Esiste una parola che significhi 'il giorno dopo dopodomani'?

cuerpo: <p>No, there are no words meaning "in three days", besides the obvious ("fra tre giorni"), but there are really many ways to say "the day after tomorrow".</p><blockquote>  <ul>  <li>Dopodomani</li>  <li>Posdomani</li>  <li>Domani l'altro</li>  </ul></blockquote><p>Probably if you said "Dopodomani l'altro" you may be understood but it's not an idiom I've heard before.</p><p>Furthermore, <a href="http://www.treccani.it/vocabolario/domani/" rel="nofollow">you can say (although it's rare to hear)</a></p><blockquote>  <ul>  <li>Domani a otto (o domani otto), meaning "tomorrow week"</li>  <li>Domani a quindici (o domani quindici), meaning "tomorrow fortnight"</li>  </ul></blockquote><p>So, again, stretching Italian quite a lot, maybe you could say "Domani a tre", but I doubt this would be understood at all.</p>

<p>Clearly "mattina" and "pomeriggio" are nouns. For example <em>"la mattina ha l'oro in bocca"</em> uses "mattina" as subject of the phrase.</p><p>However, when I say "Ci vediamo domani mattina" is "mattina" an adverb like "domani"? If not, isn't it missing a preposition (for example "domani di mattina")?</p><p>Also, is it correct to say "Ci vediamo pomeriggio?" (or "mattina")? If not, why not?</p>
titulo: Are "mattina" and "pomeriggio" also adverbs?

cuerpo: <p>If we focus on the lexical level, the answer is yes, Dante was a creator of many words and expressions that we use.  </p><p>First, according to some statistic <a href="http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/dante_%28Enciclopedia_dell%27Italiano%29/" rel="nofollow">here</a>, 90% of the basic Italian lexicon in use nowadays (that is, 90% out of 2000 most common words, which are in turn 90% of what is said, read, and written every day) are already in <em>Commedia</em>.  </p><p>Second, Dante's neologisms include <em>accidioso, cencro, contrappasso, imparadisare, indiarsi, indovarsi, inforsarsi, infuturarsi, inmiarsi e intuarsi, e anche inluiarsi e inleiarsi, inmillarsi, inurbarsi, inzaffirarsi, lonza, squadernare, trascolorare, trasmodare, trasmutare, trasumanare, trasvolare, veltro</em>, and many others. Yes, they were mainly derivatives from the words already known to the reader at the time, but that was exactly the point: to invent some new words but to make sure that the readers would still be able to understand them. A vast majority of 1700 words that are allegedly invented by Shakespeare consists also of derivatives.   </p><p>Third, just like Shakespeare, Dante has made popular many phrases, which are now used as idioms. The (more or less) full list of his expressions is <a href="http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/dantismi_%28Enciclopedia-dell%27Italiano%29/" rel="nofollow">here</a>.</p><p>For more information on the topic, one may consult:</p><ul><li>Baldelli, Ignazio (1996), <em><a href="http://trinity.micc.unifi.it/firb-vivit/sites/default/files/u80/Baldelli.pdf" rel="nofollow">Dante e la lingua italiana</a></em>, Firenze, Accademia della Crusca.</li><li>Fauriel, Claude Charles, Ardizzone, Girolamo (1856), <em><a href="https://archive.org/details/danteeleoriginid02faur" rel="nofollow">Dante e le origini della lingua e della letteratura italiana</a></em>, Palermo, La Societa libraria, A. Russo e comp.</li></ul>

<p>In the phrase “Ci vediamo domani mattina”, “domani mattina” as a whole is an adverbial phrase (<em>locuzione avverbiale</em>), and as such it does not need a preposition.</p><p>You can't say “Ci vediamo pomeriggio (mattina)”, because you either need to specify which day (like “oggi pomeriggio” or “domani mattina”) or use a preposition if the context is clear (“quando arrivi domani?” “arrivo nel pomeriggio”).</p><p>You can also use an indeterminate article if you want to express that the day you are referring to is (still) unknown (“ti telefono una mattina”).</p><p><strong>Edit:</strong></p><p>You can say “domani di mattina”: while maybe less elegant (probably subjective), it puts a slight emphasis on the fact that it's in the morning compared to “domani mattina”.</p>

<p>It would seem like an obvious (and superficial) generalization: Italian's "obvious" ancestor is Latin, Modern Greek's obvious ancestor is Ancient Greek, Latin and Ancient Greek were used (very loosely) in the same period of time. But, at least from my (unqualified) impression, it looks like Greek changed a lot less.</p><p>Greek kept the cases (although it merged dative with genitive, going towards simplification), many desinences are the same or very similar, phrase construction feels (at least superficially) familiar, and reading a neogreek phrase typically I get immediately the "familiar traits" (the augment and the sigmatic desinences for past tenses, the position of articles that correlate a word and its attributes, many particles are the same, ...). Also, I read that a modern Greek with normal education can usually understand koiné and even (with some more difficulty) attic greek (as a concept, it feels similar to us Italians reading Dante or Petrarca - but they came about 1000 years later than koiné!).</p><p>Compare this to Latin vs Italian: Italian lost the cases, changed radically the phrase construction, incorporated a lot more external influences, and in the meanwhile it split in dozens of dialects (I'm aware of Greek dialects, but, at least in ancient Greek, they seemed mostly understandable, with differences often boiling down to lexical choices, vowels contractions, switching between similar sounds and the like). Most important of all, an Italian trying to read a Latin text needs to have a specific instruction; I can't really imagine the average Italian understanding Cicero or Livius without years of training.</p><p>So, to come to the questions:</p><ul><li><p>first of all, is my impression correct? Or it's just a byproduct of me being mother tongue Italian (I can spot more easily the differences and subtleties when comparing against my own language) or of the way I've been taught Latin and Ancient Greek in Italian high school?</p></li><li><p>if so, what historical situations determined this situation? In particular, how did it happen that koiné (200 B.C.) is still mostly understandable by Greeks, while we Italians have serious problems with anything before the "sao cco kelle terre" (963 A.D.)?</p></li><li><p>finally, what would be a more correct comparison? Modern Greek is to Ancient Greek what Italian is to ... ? (maybe Dante/Petrarca's Italian?)</p></li></ul>
titulo: Is Latin to Italian what Ancient Greek is to Modern Greek?

cuerpo: <p>Consider <em>muoviti, che è tardi</em> and <em>muoviti, perché è tardi</em>. Which one is preferred? Why?</p>
titulo: When can "che" replace "perché" in a sentence?

cuerpo: <p>È obbligatorio usare la maiuscola dopo un punto interrogativo o esclamativo?</p>
titulo: È obbligatorio usare la maiuscola dopo un punto interrogativo o esclamativo?

cuerpo: <p>First of all, <em>ché</em>, not <em>che</em>, is the shortened form of <em>perché</em>. So, you could use any of them because they are literally the <a href="http://www.treccani.it/vocabolario/che/">same thing</a>.<br>Grammatica Italiana di Serianni reads as follows:</p><blockquote>  <p>Nell'italiano di registro colloquiale antico e moderno, ma con larghissime attestazioni anche letterarie, si ricorre spesso a <em>ché</em> per collegare una dipendente a una subordinata &lt;...> Abbastanza spesso si istituisce tra le due proposizioni un evidente rapporto causale: <em>copritevi, ché fa freddo</em>...</p></blockquote><p>I should note that, although <a href="http://books.google.se/books?id=eabbAAAAQBAJ">Modern Italian Grammar</a> (p.279) defines <em>ché</em> "rather old-fashioned but still used in the written texts," it's actually quite common.</p>

<p>Alle elementari mi insegnarono a trasformare "e" in "ed" se era seguita da una qualunque vocale, mentre qualche anno fa a un corso di sceneggiatura l'insegnante disse che ultimamente <em>si preferiva</em> trasformarla in "ed" solamente quando era seguita da "e" (e non dalle altre vocali).</p><p>Non ricordo se si stesse riferendo solo a qualche editor in particolare (Disney? Bonelli?) o se stesse parlando in generale.</p><p>Da qui il dubbio: alcune case editrici preferiscono un modo piuttosto che un altro? quanto sono diffuse (più o meno) le due varianti?</p><p>Si noti che non ricordo se disse che la stessa cosa valeva anche per "a" vs. "ad", ma suppongo che una volta scelto se mettere o meno la "d" convenga essere coerenti.</p>
titulo: "e" vs. "ed" seguito da vocale diversa da "e"

cuerpo: <p>Il tuo insegnante aveva ragione. <a href="http://www.accademiadellacrusca.it/it/lingua-italiana/consulenza-linguistica/domande-risposte/d-eufonica">Accademia della Crusca</a>, come al solito:</p><blockquote>  <p>L'uso della 'd' eufonica, secondo le indicazioni del famoso storico della lingua Bruno Migliorini, dovrebbe essere limitato ai casi di incontro della stessa vocale, quindi nei casi in cui la congiunzione <em>e</em> e la preposizione <em>a</em> precedano parole inizianti rispettivamente per <em>e</em> e per <em>a</em> (es. <em>ed ecco, ad andare, ad ascoltare</em>, ecc.).</p></blockquote><p><a href="http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/d-eufonica-prontuario_%28Enciclopedia-dell%27Italiano%29/">Attenzione</a> ai seguenti casi: </p><ul><li>sequenze come <em>ed editori, ad Adamo, ad adattare</em> e simili (quando la vocale successiva è seguita a sua volta dalla <em>d</em>) vanno evitate;</li><li>ci sono locuzioni fisse dove l'uso della d eufonica è praticamente cristallizzato anche fra vocali di diverso timbro: <em>ad eccezione di, ad esempio, ad ogni buon conto, ad essi</em>.</li></ul><p><a href="http://books.google.se/books?id=S-x-hxAL7PQC">Manuale di redazione</a> di Mariuccia Teroni (2007, Apogeo Editore, pagina 133) spiega gli altri dettagli.</p>

<p>Come si legge sulla <a href="http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/maiuscola_%28Enciclopedia-dell%27Italiano%29/">Treccani</a>:</p><blockquote>  <p>Dopo il punto interrogativo e il punto esclamativo l’uso della  maiuscola non dipende da una regola fissa, benché la prassi più  diffusa tra gli scriventi sia quella di scrivere una maiuscola (va  notato inoltre, che il correttore ortografico del programma Word  riconduce sempre a maiuscola). L’impiego varia da caso a caso a  seconda dell’intenzione dello scrivente di segnalare o meno una pausa  forte, con interruzione di periodo; e lo stesso vale dopo i puntini di  sospensione. </p></blockquote>

<p>I've investigated my own question a bit and I believe I can answer it fully now.</p><p>Mattino, mattina and pomeriggio are <em>nouns</em> and not <em>adverbs</em>. They don't have a double noun/adverb form like <em>oggi</em> or <em>domani</em> (I can say "Ci vediamo domani", but also "penso al domani").</p><p>When I say <em>"Ci vediamo di mattina"</em> or <em>"Ci vediamo domani pomeriggio"</em>, <em>"di mattina"</em> and <em>"domani pomeriggio"</em> form a "complemento avverbiale di tempo". However this is logical analysis which is not what the question is about.</p><p>Grammatically speaking, <em>"mattina"</em> and <em>"pomeriggio"</em> remain nouns, and that can be seen in the (relatively archaic) usage of the words in the form <em>"ci vediamo la mattina"</em> or <em>"Ci siamo incontrati un pomeriggio"</em>.</p><p>Nouns take articles, adverbs don't. For the same reason <em>"ci vediamo pomeriggio"</em> is incorrect, as the lack of an article identifies <em>"pomeriggio"</em> as an adverb, but there is no such form of the word.</p>

<p>No, "sono dietro a..." it's not a widely understood phrase. The correct Italian form is to use the verb "stare" followed by the gerund.</p><p>Furthermore the quite similar phrase "sono indietro a..." means a very different thing: "I'm behind in...", so I would not assume that people understand what you mean.</p>

<p>In Italian, the subject of a sentence is normally implicit.</p><blockquote>  <p>Ho incontrato Luigi e mi ha detto di salutarti.</p></blockquote><blockquote>  <p>Siamo andati a Roma per il weekend.</p></blockquote><blockquote>  <p>Sono andate via senza dire niente; non so a che ora tornino.</p></blockquote><p>This is not source of confusion, since a verb is normally declined differently for each person, plural or singular.</p><p>Does making the subject explicit change the meaning of the sentence, or does the sentence have the same meaning? Is it used as emphasis?</p><blockquote>  <p>Io ho incontrato Luigi e mi ha detto di salutarti.</p></blockquote><blockquote>  <p>Noi siamo andati a Roma per il weekend.</p></blockquote>
titulo: If the subject of a sentence is normally left implicit, what does adding it to a sentence mean?

cuerpo: <p>The Italian-English dictionaries undoubtedly translate <em>al riguardo di</em> as "about (smth.)", "regarding smth." (for example, <a href="http://www.wordreference.com/iten/al%20riguardo" rel="nofollow">here</a> and <a href="http://it.bab.la/dizionario/italiano-inglese/al-riguardo-di" rel="nofollow">here</a>). A short search on Google brings more than 1 mln. cases with the same meaning.<br>However, the Treccani <a href="http://www.treccani.it/vocabolario/riguardo/" rel="nofollow">dictionary</a> gives only one example of usage for <em>a/al riguardo</em>: </p><blockquote>  <p><em>a riguardo di, al riguardo di</em>, in paragone di, rispetto a: <em>la luna è molto piccola a riguardo della terra</em></p></blockquote><p>The same description and examples are given in <a href="http://books.google.se/books?id=c_ssAAAAYAAJ" rel="nofollow">Voci e maniere di dire italiane additate a'futuri vocabolaristi</a> di Giovanni Gheradini (p.507):</p><blockquote>  <p><em>A riguardo di o Al riguardo di</em>. Si usa col valore <em>A paragone di, a proporzione di</em>.</p></blockquote><p>On the other hand, Dizionario fondamentale della lingua italiana di Giacomo Devoto e Gian Carlo Oli says:</p><blockquote>  <p>A riguardo di, in riguardo di, nei riguardi di, loc. prep. con il valore di 'per quel che concerne' [...], oppure di 'a paragone di' [...].<br>  (no mention of <em>al riguardo</em> at all)</p></blockquote><p><a href="http://forum.accademiadellacrusca.it/phpBB2/viewtopic.php?t=369&amp;postdays=0&amp;postorder=asc&amp;start=0" rel="nofollow">This</a> discussion shows that if you ask five different people, you'll hear six different opinions. Though, at the end of the day, they seem to agree that <em>al riguardo</em> is equivalent to <em>a tale riguardo</em> and means "a questo proposito", while <em>a riguardo di</em> keeps the meaning "in paragone di, rispetto a."</p><p><strong>TL;DR</strong> There are contradictory entries in several dictionaries. Thus, I'm looking for an authoritative opinion on:</p><ul><li>whether both <em>a riguardo di</em> and <em>al riguardo di</em> still have the same meaning of "in comparison with", and/or</li><li>whether the meaning of one or both of these phrases has changed over years (when? how?), so that <em>a riguardo di</em> is now out of use, while <em>al riguardo di</em> attained the meaning "with regard to."</li></ul><p>Could anybody help me to clarify it? Confirm any of these claims, have some evidence, grammar rules, something to rely on?</p>
titulo: "Al riguardo di" and "a riguardo di"

cuerpo: <p><em>Io ho incontrato Luigi</em> is not ungrammatical, but is used only to give special emphasis to the fact that <em>I</em> met Luigi. So</p><blockquote>  <p>Io ho incontrato Luigi e Marcella ha incontrato Laura</p></blockquote><p>or</p><blockquote>  <p>Io ho incontrato Luigi e gliene ho dette quattro</p></blockquote><p>(meaning the no one else did). Otherwise, the pronoun is not used. A different situation is for the third person pronoun that's used more frequently.</p><blockquote>  <p>Luigi scese le scale e andò verso Marcella. Egli l'amava, ma non gliel'aveva mai rivelato.</p></blockquote><p>Here <em>egli</em> is necessary to disambiguate the meaning (in spoken language and more and more also in written language it would be <em>lui</em>). Note the difference:</p><blockquote>  <p>Scesi le scale e andai verso Marcella. L'amavo, ma non gliel'avevo mai rivelato. </p></blockquote><p>No <em>io</em>, which would sound clumsy.</p>

<blockquote>  <p>a riguardo di, al riguardo di, in paragone di, rispetto a: la luna è  molto piccola a riguardo della terra</p></blockquote><p>This is quite old fashioned, I had to think a bit to understand the sense. </p><p>"A riguardo di" can be replaced "a confronto di", but also this expression is not very used and now we prefer to say "controntato con" or "paragonato a". But "a riguardo di" sounds really form XIX century.</p><blockquote>  <p>A riguardo di, in riguardo di, nei riguardi di, loc. prep. con il  valore di 'per quel che concerne' [...], oppure di 'a paragone di'  [...].</p></blockquote><p>Used as preposition "a riguardo di" is also quite an old way to say. Normally you can just use "riguardo" like just "regarding" in English.</p><p>So my suggestion is that, when you are translating an Italian text, if you can replace <em>riguardo</em> with <em>proposito</em> (<em>a proposito di</em>) then you can use "about smth" or "regarding smth" without problems, otherwise you are in the Treccani case.</p><blockquote>  <p>A <strong>riguardo</strong> della tua domanda […].</p>    <p>A <strong>proposito</strong> della tua domanda […].</p>    <p><strong>Regarding</strong> your question […].</p></blockquote><p>but</p><blockquote>  <p>La tua domanda a <strong>riguardo</strong> della mia ha molte più risposte […].</p>    <p>La tua domanda a <strong>proposito</strong> della mia ha molte più risposte […]. </p></blockquote><p>In this case the sense of the sentence changes, so in English it will become something like:</p><blockquote>  <p>Your questions <strong>compared</strong> with the mine has much more answers […].</p></blockquote>

<p>When I stay in Rome I hear people using "a" in a strange way, especially in cases in which a criticism or an insult is involved.</p><p>For example:</p><blockquote>  <p><em><strong>a</em></strong> vedi questo</p>    <p><em><strong>a</em></strong> burino</p>    <p><em><strong>a</em></strong> st***zo</p></blockquote><p>and so on.</p><p>Can anyone explain what the reason and the historical origin of that “a” are? And, also, what does it precisely mean?</p>
titulo: Why do people from Rome use "a" when criticism is involved?

cuerpo: <p>Si tratta di un vocativo, e non è necessariamente limitato a degli insulti.</p><p><a href="http://it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grammatica_del_dialetto_romanesco">Wikipedia</a>, ad esempio, cita:</p><blockquote>  <p>Ah Varte', ando vai?</p></blockquote><p>che possiamo rendere con</p><blockquote>  <p>Ehi Walter, dove vai?</p></blockquote><p>Altri esempi si possono trovare su questa pagina di <a href="http://roma.andreapollett.com/S8/dialett3.htm">Roma virtuale</a></p><p>Ad esempio</p><blockquote>  <p>A rega',...</p></blockquote><p>ossia</p><blockquote>  <p>Ragazzi,...</p></blockquote><p>Il <a href="http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/vocativo_%28Enciclopedia-dell%27Italiano%29/">vocativo in italiano</a> è probabilmente meno usato, ed è reso in varie forme con il <a href="http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/complemento-di-vocazione_%28La_grammatica_italiana%29/">complemento di vocazione</a></p>

<p>It is simply an interjection, the Roman exactly corresponding to Tuscan – and so Italian – “<a href="http://www.treccani.it/vocabolario/o2/" rel="nofollow">o</a>”, which strengthens an exclamation that follows (not to be confused with “<a href="http://www.treccani.it/vocabolario/oh/" rel="nofollow">oh</a>”).</p>
<p>Can anyone explain the reason why the verb "tenere" take the form "tengo", as in "io tengo", rather than the form "tegno", which sound more natural?</p>
titulo: Why is "tengo" and not "tegno"?

cuerpo: <p>Why does "tegno" sound more natural and why do you think that should be the form? Let's see the etymology. The verb comes, obviously, from Latin, and more precisely from <strong>tĕnēre</strong>. The first two from the verb conjugation are <strong>tĕnĕo, tĕnes</strong>.</p><p>It's easier for it to become <em>tengo</em> than <em>tegno</em>, which even loses the root <em>ten-</em> and therefore fails to deliver the proper meaning. </p><p>The root is the part that delivers the meaning of a word, so it's quite important. As far as Linguistics is concerned, it's hard to always explain the <em>why</em>, since unless you have more data, the reasons can be many and they can change for each case. </p>

<p>You could get away with "dopodopodomani" (<a href="https://www.google.com/?q=%22dopodopodomani%22#q=%22dopodopodomani%22">no, really</a>) in very informal speech, but it is far more common to refer to it as either "tra tre giorni" or just by the weekday ("Martedì").</p>

<p>In English you can use a number of different styles to add parenthetical remarks. For example:</p><ul><li>Juventus<i>, as you may know,</i> has won the most Scudetti.</li><li>Some would say it's 29 <em>(and technically they're right)</em>.</li><li>Others however claim it's 31 <em>— although they're usually die-hard Juventus supporters</em>.</li></ul><p>Is the dash style of parenthetical remarks also allowed by Italian grammar? I know I've casually used it from time to time and no one seemed confused by it, but that doesn't make it <em>right.</em></p>
titulo: Does Italian allow "—" for parenthetical use?

cuerpo: <p>Traditional Italian usage admits the m-dash in couples only. To rewrite one of your examples: "Juventus – as you may know – has won the most Scudetti." The single dash to introduce a clause at the end of a sentence is quite recently borrowed from English, but doesn't belong to usual Italian punctuation.</p><p>To quote from Bice Mortara Garavelli, <em>Prontuario di punteggiatura</em>, Laterza 2003:</p><blockquote>  <p>Come marca iniziale di una parentetica inserita alla fine di una frase si può trovare una lineetta priva della lineetta terminale correlativa. Tradizionalmente, per un inserto che si trovi in tale posizione, si preferiscono alle lineette le parentesi (una in apertura e una in chiusura seguita dal punto finale), oppure la virgola iniziale [...].</p></blockquote>

<p>Al di fuori di dizionari e simili, esiste qualche testata o editore che faccia un uso anche sporadico della "ó"?</p><p><em>(se non ho inteso male, non esiste nessun caso in cui è obbligatoria, dunque l'unico uso possibile è se si vuole a tutti i costi disambiguare termini quali bótte e bòtte)</em></p>
titulo: Qual è lo stato attuale della "ó"?

cuerpo: <p>Alcuni dizionari riportano il verbo votare, nella sua accezione più comune, quella che si riferisce all'esprimere preferenza elettorale per un partito o per un candidato, sia come transitivo che come intransitivo.</p><p>Per esempio, <a href="http://dizionari.corriere.it/dizionario_italiano/V/votare.shtml">il dizionario del Corriere della Sera</a> afferma che sia corretto dire:</p><blockquote>  <p>Io voto <em>per</em> il candidato x;</p></blockquote><p>e anche</p><blockquote>  <p>Io voto il candidato x.</p></blockquote><p><a href="http://www.treccani.it/vocabolario/votare2/">IL vocabolario Treccani</a> non riporta esplicitamente esempi nella direzione della seconda frase qui citata, usando invece, nel senso specificato, solo la frase con preposizione.</p><p>Vorrei sapere se l'uso di <em>votare</em> così come è indicato nella seconda frase è di nuova fattura (un uso di recente accetazione), se le due forme siano equivalenti, e in quale misura o contesto.</p>
titulo: Uso transitivo del verbo "votare" in senso elettorale

cuerpo: <p>Often times, computer programs in English tend to give feedback on what they are and aren't doing in an impersonal form:</p><ul><li>Cannot locate the internet server or proxy server</li><li>Unable to unlink old file (permission denied)</li><li>Crunching the latest data, just for you. Hang tight…</li><li>Reticulating splines...</li></ul><p>...or in a personal form in the person of the program itself:</p><ul><li>Firefox could not download the search plugin from...</li><li>Office could not create the work file</li><li>Windows is unable to install to the selected location</li></ul><p>The latter set of wording works kind of okay in Italian, but the former doesn't and tends to be translated using periphrases such as:</p><ul><li><em>[è] Impossibile</em> trovare il server...</li><li>Elaborazione dei dati <em>in corso...</em></li></ul><p>...but the literal translation alternative is even worse:</p><ul><li>Non posso trovare il server...</li><li>[sto] Elaborando i dati...</li></ul><p>What's the preferred, least awkward way to phrase (or rather: translate) these messages?</p>
titulo: What form should be used when showing messages to a user on a computer screen in Italian?

cuerpo: <p>Standard Italian, the official language of Italy and the one Italian people speak (often along with their own local languages -or dialects-), derives from the Florentine subset of Vulgar Latin.</p><p>With the collapse of the Roman Empire, the barbaric invasions and the consequent merging with other languages (and also for other reasons), Latin developed in the so called <em>romance languages</em>, which came from the vulgar (i.e., spoken by common people) versions of Latin itself.</p><p>In particular, the vulgar spoken in Florence and nearby was chosen to be standard Italian. What was the exact reason behind this historical linguistics choice? Why not other local versions of vulgar Latin?</p><p>Was it because at that time a massive stream of literary works was flourishing in the area of Tuscany? It is known that in Sicily there was this same phenomenon, namely Vulgar Sicilian had created a set of literary works, praised by Dante Alighieri himself.</p><p>So, I would like to know whether the choice was an arbitrary one or there are reasons I'm not aware of.</p>
titulo: Why was the Florentine Vulgar Latin chosen as the basis for standard Italian?

cuerpo: <p>"Votare" derives from <a href="http://www.etimo.it/?cmd=id&amp;id=19591&amp;md=34850ce0e4507fd040cf19dafbafa174" rel="nofollow">"promettere con voto"</a> where "voto" has the original meaning of "solemn promise" (<em>cf. "voto del silenzio", "devoto"</em>) and comes from the Latin <a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/voveo#Latin" rel="nofollow">"vov&egrave;re"</a>  (<em>cf. "to vow for"</em>).</p><p>The original meaning is mostly used with the reflexive form of the verb "votarsi", to (de)vote oneself, and this also makes it evident that a transitive form of the verb is acceptable and of old origin.</p><p>More interesting is to see if the intransitive form is a later way of using the verb. An <a href="https://books.google.com/ngrams/graph?content=votare+per%2Cvotare&amp;case_insensitive=on&amp;year_start=1500&amp;year_end=2000&amp;corpus=22&amp;smoothing=3&amp;share=&amp;direct_url=t4%3B%2Cvotare%20per%3B%2Cc0%3B%2Cs0%3B%3Bvotare%20per%3B%2Cc0%3B%3BVotare%20per%3B%2Cc0%3B.t1%3B%2Cvotare%3B%2Cc0" rel="nofollow">ngram for "votare per"</a> is not different enough from "votare" to draw any conclusions, although it shows a slighty earlier start for the verb in general in comparison with the "per" form. What is more interesting is that the usage of either form has become much more common since the Risorgimento in the 1850's.</p><p><img src="http://i.stack.imgur.com/AvDpb.png" alt="ngram votare per vs votare"></p><p>On the other hand "votare un" vs. "votare per un" also show very similar <a href="https://books.google.com/ngrams/graph?content=votare+per+un%2Cvotare+un&amp;year_start=1800&amp;year_end=2000&amp;corpus=22&amp;smoothing=3&amp;share=&amp;direct_url=t1%3B%2Cvotare%20per%20un%3B%2Cc0%3B.t1%3B%2Cvotare%20un%3B%2Cc0" rel="nofollow">ngrams</a>. I think that all we can deduce is that the transitive form is more commonly used, but I don't think there's enough difference to support they hypothesis that one is more recent than the other.</p><p><img src="http://i.stack.imgur.com/TXkfe.png" alt="&quot;votare un&quot; vs. &quot;votare per un&quot;"></p>

<p>Very short answer: It just happened so.</p><p>Short answer: The poetic and narrative monuments written by Dante, Petrarca, and Boccaccio put them and their variety of Italian as a model to many later writers and critics. But it was not so automatic: there were centuries of debate, starting mostly during the Renaissance, with Pietro Bembo and many others, and with some turning points, among which the choice of Alessandro Manzoni to “risciacquare i panni in Arno” (even if his influence on Italian at large is sometimes overstated). Plus, Florentine being the “official” language of Italy has largely been a question for literate people, while less literate ones just spoke whichever variety of Italian they learned at home.</p><p>Long answer: There are whole libraries on the history of Italian and how it came to be like it is now, and especially about the so-called “<a href="http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/questione-della-lingua_%28Enciclopedia-dell%27Italiano%29/">Questione della lingua</a>”.</p>

<p>The oldest vocabulary I have on hand, a 1948 Zingarelli, gives as a definition “Dare il voto” (hinting at the intransitive use) as well as “Approvare col suo voto” (hinting at the transitive one) and records transitive uses, such as “la lista del blocco ... la proposta”, but I guess the use is not much older.</p><p>Following the idea by Sklivvz, a search on <a href="http://tinyurl.com/madp2n5" rel="nofollow">Ngram viewer</a> for “votare per un candidato” vs. “votare un candidato” suggests that the transitive form is more recent, with almost no results before WWII, while the intransitive one was well in use in the 1850s.</p><p>Finally, in the <a href="http://vocabolario.sns.it/html/index.html" rel="nofollow">Vocabolario della Crusca</a>, “votare” only appears (as variant of “botare”) in the meaning of “to vow” (and, of course, the homograph “votare” meaning “to empty” also appears).</p>

<p>There <em>can</em> be some cases where <code>ó</code> should be used: if one wants to reproduce the French pronunciation, <em>bordó</em> would be better than <em>bordò</em> to mean the wine; nowadays the French spelling seems to be preferred (see the <a href="http://www.treccani.it/vocabolario/bordo_res-a2efc577-0011-11de-9d89-0016357eee51/" rel="nofollow">entry in the Treccani dictionary</a>)</p><p>Perhaps a ‘more Italian’ word in the same situation is <em>borderó</em>, but of course its pronunciation is influenced by the fact that all Italian words ending in tonic <em>o</em> have the open sound. Dictionaries spell it as <em>borderò</em>.</p><p>Distinguishing between <em>bòtte</em> and <em>bótte</em> in written language seems not to be so important, the context will make it clear if punches or barrels are involved.</p>

<p>I generally lean towards the impersonal form in Italian. I think English can afford to use the personal form since it has the neutral gender (<strong><em>it</em></strong>), which is lacking in Italian. Using the personal form in Italian generally requires a gender to be defined. This is often arbitrary and in most cases just it doesn't feel right. Is Firefox a guy? Is Opera a lady? I don't know and I don't even want to care. Let's stay impersonal, whenever possible</p><p>Now, either using the impersonal or impersonal form, trying to literally translate English idioms is probably not doing any good. Idioms are meant to be translated with idioms, as long as the core meaning is preserved.</p><p>Let's take for instance the message</p><blockquote>  <p>Crunching the latest data, just for you. Hang tight…</p></blockquote><p>Any close-to-literal translation I can think of would be spectacularly awkward and it would indeed be an example of <em><a href="http://it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doppiaggese">Doppiaggese</a></em>.</p><p>If I were responsible for translating such a message, I would rather focus on</p><ul><li><strong>meaning</strong>: data is being computed. It will take a few moments.</li><li><strong>tone</strong>: colloquial, almost playful</li></ul><p>and try to convey both of them using Italian idioms, whenever possible, or just the meaning if the form cannot be preserved faithfully.</p><p>Something like</p><blockquote>  <p>Stiamo elaborando i dati più recenti. Un attimo solo...</p></blockquote><p>About the example:</p><ul><li>I decided to use <em>stiamo</em> and be somewhat personal, since the original message was very colloquial.</li><li>I skipped the <em>just for you</em> as I couldn't think of a non-awkward translation. That's ok since the original meaning has been preserved, although some of the tone is being lost.</li><li><em>Hang tight</em> could be maybe translated with <em>Tieniti forte</em>, but its purpose in the original message is to transmit the information: "This is going to take a while. Please wait.", so I decide to go with a kind of plain (but still colloquial) <em>Un attimo solo</em>. Again I chose meaning over form.</li></ul>

<p>The verb <em>trasalire</em> should be conjugated (I report the Indicative present tense) as </p><blockquote>  <p>Io trasalisco; Tu trasalisci, Egli trasalisce ...</p></blockquote><p>But since the verb may be perceived as a composite of <em>salire</em>, it is often used with its conjugation:</p><blockquote>  <p>Io trasalgo; Ti trasali; Egli trasale ...</p></blockquote><p>I'm sure this is not the only case of this phenomenon. Do you know to which extent this mechanism of compositional usage of a root is accepted by the speaking community and the official grammars?</p>
titulo: Degree of acceptance of conjugation of verb according to root

cuerpo: <p>I think it all depends whether the speaker "hears" the root. For me it is really difficult to see "salire" in "trasalire", for example; on the other side, I jump when someone says "il papa *benediva la folla", since "benedire" for me is "bene dire", and so I say "il papa benediceva la folla".</p>

<p>Non mi è mai capitato di vedere usata ó, a meno naturalmente non si abbia un nome spagnolo come Pedro Almodóvar.</p><p>Einaudi continua a usare í e ú (foneticamente più corrette di ì e ù), ma credo sia l'unico editore.</p>

<p>I would think a major factor was the <em>prestige</em> of the literary works from the area of Firenze. And this prestige might have reinforced the use of <em>Toscano</em>  as a kind of <em>lingua franca</em> among certain people on the pensinsula  way before <em>Regno d'Italia</em> came about. Most people however would of course only speak their local language/dialect, something that didnt really change until the advent of compulsory education.</p><hr><p><strong>Edit 1</strong></p><p>IF literary Toscano had lacked this prestige and the political unification of the peninsula had still  been driven by the <em>Regno di Sardegna</em>, then the standard of Italian would have been <em>Piemontese</em>, or if the unification had been driven by the <em>Regno delle Due Sicilie</em> then the base would have been some form of <em>Napolitano</em>,</p><p><em>On the other hand</em> the literary prestige of Toscano might also be seen <em>as one of the driving forces behind the unification as such</em>. Without this and the notion that there was such a thing as a common 'Italian' culture then the unification might not have taken place at all!</p><hr><p><strong>Edit 2</strong></p><p>That Toscano had a literary prestige did not necessarily imply that it was widely spoken at all.</p><p>Yes, there were other languages in the 13th and 14th century that was widely used like the <em>Provençau</em> of the troubadours and of course all the different regions and states had their own traditions, and also literary models. And for official purposes there was always Latin.</p><p><em>Rather Toscano was <strong>promoted</strong>  as a language of culture by Pietro Bembo and other umanisti during the 16th century</em> and spread by the use of <strong><em>printed books.</em></strong></p><p>Why did Bembo actively promote the literary use of Toscano?</p><p>He grew up in Venice, traveled widely  with his father the ambassador, including a stay in Firenze where he learned Toscano; he studied Greek in Messina, worked in Ferrara, was official historian of the Republic, and ended up as a Cardinal in Rome.</p><p>Because of his travels he had first-hand experience of different language in the north, center and south. I think his preference for Toscano as a common literary language was  <em>linguistic</em>; Toscano belonged/belongs to the <em>central group of languages</em>, being <em>neither northern nor southern</em>. He <strong><em>might</em></strong> have thought that this would make Toscano easy to understand and acquire for writers from all over the peninsula, from Turin to Palermo.</p>
<p>What's the historical origin that makes us write <em>1.000.000,00</em> and not <em>1,000,000.00</em> (like in English) or <em>1 000 000,00</em> (like in French)?</p>
titulo: Why in Italian should I use periods to separate units of thousands in large numbers?

cuerpo: <p>Belgium, Denmark, Germany, Italy, Romania, Sweden and most of Europe use the dot as a thousands separator, but the space is adopted as well. Even if it must be said that the International Standard recommends spaces in lieu of dots or commas.</p><p>As stated on <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decimal_mark">this wikipedia page</a>, before the invention of printing, a line ( ¯ ) was used over the digits. After printing, the countries/nations chose marks for convenience and according to what others had already chosen to avoid confusion. This means that it basically was an arbitrary decision, no particular reasons were behind it, apparently.</p>

<p>You shouldn't, except perhaps when writing by hand.</p><p>Separating thousands with periods is cause for ambiguities. When I was young, I was taught to use a <em>raised</em> dot like in <code>123˙456</code>, not a period; probably different teachers use different conventions. The main reason I see for a dot instead of a thin space is that usually numbers were written on <em>carta a quadretti</em>, so one digit per square.</p><p>When printing, use a thin space:</p><blockquote>  <p>1 000 000</p></blockquote><p>It's just as readable and not confusing. I'd even say it is <em>more</em> readable.</p><p>This is recommended by UNI/ISO, as this quote from the book by Roberto Lesina, <em>Il nuovo manuale di stile</em>, Zanichelli 2009 (p. 174): </p><blockquote>  <p>La spaziatura è il solo metodo universalmente corretto per la separazione fra migliaia. L'uso di altri separatori, quali il punto [...] può portare a grossolani malintesi. [...] Per questi motivi, anche l'ISO sconsiglia l'uso del punto e della virgola come separatori di migliaia», citing «ISO 31-0, Quantities and units, General principles.</p></blockquote><p>I know of no “official” statement that baseline periods are to be used in Italian.</p><hr><p>Now, <em>why</em> did this convention enter into common practice? The answer is really easy: typewriters didn't have raised dots. The influence of typewriters on the way we write now has been great: for tens of years, we had only printed, typewritten and handwritten texts, the middle category being prominent in business.</p><p>The raised dot had the same fate as ‘È’, that became <code>E'</code>, or the digits 0 and 1, that became <code>O</code> (oh) and <code>l</code> (ell), or the guillemets: disparition.</p><p>The question might be phrased: why should we use undirected <code>"</code> instead of inverted commas or guillemets? The answer would be the same. By the way, guillemets were hardly found on typewriter keyboard and they are disappearing.</p>

<p>Sull'edizione online de 'La Stampa' di oggi, con riferimento agli eventi concernenti le azioni di un folle che ha tentato di uccidere alcuni passanti a Parigi, si legge:</p><blockquote>  <p>Quest’ultimo è l’unico ad aver parlato all’attentatore, e la polizia <strong><em>lo sta torchiando</em></strong>.</p></blockquote><p>Sarei interessato a sapere se il giornalista usa correttamente il verbo <strong><em>torchiare</em></strong>, atteso che non ho mai sentito nessuno dire <strong><em>lo sta torchiando</em></strong>, ma, invece, più volte ho sentito <strong><em>lo sta mettendo sotto torchio</em></strong>.</p><p>Se, invece, l'uso giornalistico del verbo <strong><em>torchiare</em></strong> dovesse essere accettabile, sapreste spiegare il perché?</p>
titulo: Utilizzo dell'espressione "lo sta torchiando" in luogo di "lo sta mettendo sotto torchio"

cuerpo: <p>L'utilizzo è corretto. Il significato di <em>torchiare</em> è esattamente quello di <em>mettere sotto torchio</em>, e l'esempio che citi è anche <a href="http://www.treccani.it/vocabolario/torchiare/">riportato dal dizionario Treccani</a>:</p><blockquote>  <p><strong>torchiare</strong> v. tr. [der. di <em>torchio</em>]; cfr. lat. tardo <em>torcŭlare</em>, der. di <em>torcŭlum</em>: v. <em>torchio</em>] (io <em>tòrchio</em>, ecc.). – Mettere sotto il torchio, comprimere o spremere col torchio: t. le vinacce, le olive (v. torchiatura). Con uso fig., sottoporre a domande pressanti, serrate: <em>il professore, all’esame, l’ha torchiato per un’ora</em>; <strong><em>la polizia ha torchiato a lungo l’indiziato</em></strong>; anche, spremere sottoponendo a esosa pressione fiscale: <em>categorie sociali particolarmente torchiate dal fisco</em>.</p></blockquote>

<p>Girando per l'Italia ho sentito dire "dagli un colpo di telefono". Sapreste dire se tale espressione è piuttosto comune o meno? O se, diversamente, viene intesa nel suo significato letterale "colpiscilo con il telefono"?</p><p>Sarei anche interessato a conoscere l'origine di questa espressione. </p>
titulo: Origine e diffusione dell'espressione “dare un colpo di telefono”

cuerpo: <p>l'espressione è comune, almeno al nord.Una possibilità è che si sia partiti dall'accezione di <em>colpo</em> come «rumore prodotto da un colpo: <em>sentire i colpi del martello</em>; detonazione: <em>colpo del cannone</em>» (dal De Mauro)</p>

<blockquote>  <p>Sapreste dire se tale espressione è piuttosto comune o meno?</p></blockquote><p>Posso garantire che l'espressione è comune nel Nord Italia, di dove sono originario, e penso anche che sia molto diffusa nel resto del Paese.</p><blockquote>  <p>O se, diversamente, viene intesa nel suo significato letterale "colpiscilo con il telefono"?</p></blockquote><p>Decisamente no, in nessun contesto che mi possa venire in mente. Il fatto che la frase sottintenda una comunicazione a distanza, rende ancora meno plausibile un'interpretazione letterale.</p><p>Se per qualche buffa coincidenza dovessi colpire qualcuno con un telefono, direi qualcosa del tipo</p><blockquote>  <p>L'ho colpito con il telefono.  </p></blockquote><blockquote>  <p>Gli ho dato un colpo con il telefono.</p></blockquote><p>(notare l'uso di <em>con</em> al posto di <em>di</em>)</p><p>Circa l'etimologia, ho due ipotesi:</p><ul><li><p>come già accennava mau nella sua risposta, può essere che ci sia un riferimento ad antiche forme di comunicazione, come dare un <em>colpo di cannone</em>, per esempio come avvertimento. Oppure si può pensare alla comunicazione tramite <em>colpi di tamburo</em>.</p></li><li><p>altrimenti può essere un riferimento al procedimento fisico di effettuare una chiamata con i primi telefoni, in cui era necessario attaccare e risollevare la cornetta per passare tramite il centralino. Tale gesto (data anche la pesantezza dei primi apparecchi telefonici) poteva essere percepita come un <em>colpo</em>.</p></li></ul>

<p>Sapreste dirmi qual è la distribuzione geografica dei termini "fioraio", "fiorista" e "fioreria"?<br>Come noto, i termini si riferiscono alle attività di vendita dei fiori.</p><p>Sapreste dirmi, al di là degli usi locali, quale sarebbe il più appropriato termine?</p>
titulo: Sapreste dirmi qual è la distribuzione geografica dei termini 'fioraio', 'fiorista' e 'fioreria'?

cuerpo: <p>The traditional distinction is that <em>il <strong>fioraio</strong> vende fiori freschi, il <strong>fiorista</strong> fabbrica e vende fiori artificiali</em> (Eugenio Treves, <em>...Si dice?...</em>, Ceschina 1961, and some dictionaries). In practice, nowadays <em>fiorista</em> is felt as somewhat upper scale, as if a <em>fioraio</em> sold just any old flower while a <em>fiorista</em> sold elegant flower compositions.</p>

<p>Take a look to these examples</p><blockquote>  <p>mio padre</p>    <p>mia moglie</p>    <p>mia zia</p>    <p>mio suocero</p>    <p><strong>le</strong> mie zie</p>    <p><strong>i</strong> miei suoceri</p>    <p><strong>il</strong> mio amico</p>    <p><strong>la</strong> mia collega</p>    <p><strong>le</strong> mie vicine</p></blockquote><p>These are correct expressions.</p><p>Less correct and more childhood seems:</p><blockquote>  <p><strong>il</strong> mio papà</p></blockquote><p>You can also try the same with indefinite articles.</p><p><strong>In which cases do I need to use the article in front of a possessive adjective and in which cases don't I?</strong></p><p>Do you know the rule? I never found it even if I'm Italian!...</p>
titulo: Possessive adjective with or without article for personal relationships

cuerpo: <p>La locuzione "colpo di ..." in italiano è molto comune e non si esaurisce con "colpo di telefono". Ci sono: colpo di fulmine, colpo di scena, colpo di sole, colpo di fortuna, ecc. Si tratta di probabile francesismo; cfr. coup de foudre, un coup de chance, un coup d'état, un coup de Jarnac, ecc.</p>

<p>You can omit the article when the name is <strong>singular</strong> and you're talking about a relationship in the sense of kinship so:</p><ul><li><em>padre</em>, <em>moglie</em>, <em>zia</em>, <em>suocero</em> go without article</li><li><em>zie</em>, <em>suoceri</em> with article (plural)</li><li><em>amico</em>, <em>collega</em>, <em>vicine</em> with article (not connections by blood, marriage or adoption).</li></ul><p>As you guessed, <em>papà</em>, like <em>mamma</em> and <em>babbo</em>, make exceptions to this rule and allow the article when singular.</p>

<p>According to Serianni, <em>Italiano</em>, Garzanti 1997 (p. 126):</p><blockquote>  <p>Con un sostantivo plurale l'articolo è obbligatorio: «le nostre madri», «i suoi figli», «i miei nonni». Ugualmente necessario è oggi l'articolo con l'aggettivo possessivo <em>loro</em>: «la loro moglie», «il loro fratello».</p>    <p>Con <em>padre</em>, <em>madre</em>, <em>figlio</em>, <em>figlia</em> l'articolo si omette [...]. L'articolo va espresso, invece, con le varianti affettive <em>babbo</em>, <em>papà</em>, <em>mamma</em>, <em>figliolo</em>, <em>figliola</em> [...]. Nell'italiano familiare, specie fuor di Toscana, sono tuttavia ben saldi i tipi <em>mia mamma</em> e <em>mio papà</em> [...].</p>    <p>Con altri singenionimi l'uso toscano predilige l'articolo, ma altrove è comune l'omissione, ben rappresentata, del resto, anche in scrittori toscani [...]: «a mia sorella» (Cassola), «tua nonna» (Pratolini) [...]. L'articolo è però necessario:</p>    <p><em>a</em>) con gli alterati: «la mia sorellina» (Cassola [...]), «alla tua nonnina» (Pirandello, <em>Novelle per un anno</em>);</p>    <p><em>b</em>) con <em>patrigno</em>, <em>matrigna</em>, <em>figliastro</em>, <em>figliastra</em> [...];</p>    <p><em>c</em>) con i termini che indicano un rapporto sentimentale che non rientra, o non rientra ancora, nei vincoli di parentela: <em>fidanzato</em>, <em>fidanzata</em>, <em>ragazzo</em>, <em>ragazza</em>, <em>bello</em>, <em>bella</em>, <em>moroso</em>, <em>morosa</em>, <em>amante</em>, ecc. [...];</p>    <p><em>d</em>) quando, in costrutti con valore enfatico, il possessivo sia posposto: «il nonno mio» [...].</p></blockquote><p>Summing up: before a noun in the plural or a singular noun with the adjective <em>loro</em>, the article is always used; with <em>padre</em>, <em>madre</em>, <em>figlio</em>, <em>figlia</em> it is always omitted; with other nouns it is either compulsory (cases <em>a</em> - <em>d</em>) or mostly used, especially in Tuscan use, but with some oscillations elsewhere (such as <em>la tua nonna</em> / <em>tua nonna</em>).</p>

<p>In handwritten Italian, double quotes are used almost universally for reported speech. The matter is less standardised in print. Distinct publishing houses have distinct guidelines, but AFAIK they all fall into three cases:</p><ol><li>Those using guillemets (<em>«…»</em>) and reserving double quotes for other functions.</li><li>Those using upper double quotes (<em>“…”</em>).</li><li>Those using long dashes (<em>—</em>), whose exact length is a matter for typographic debate.</li></ol><p>The first case (<em>«…»</em>) is the most common in newspapers.</p><p>The second case (<em>“…”</em>) is used mostly on websites, including the website of major newspapers (weird enough, <em>La Repubblica</em> uses the guillemets on paper and the double quotes on the Web, and even worse, they use the non-curly version: "…").</p><p>The third case (<em>—</em>) is the choice of some major publishers (e.g. Einaudi), like it or not it has to be mentioned.</p><p>Single quotes (<em>‘…’</em>) are sometimes used for nested quotations or to quote a sentence but not as reported speech, e.g.:</p><blockquote>  <p>Riprenditi pure tutti i tuoi ‘non so’. [Take back all your maybes.]</p></blockquote><p>It's important to remember that different set of rules are equally acceptable as long as they are used in a consistent way, Italian is much less standardised than most European languages and this particularly affects punctuation, italics etc. that are left to the taste, style and tradition of individual publishers.</p>

<p>Just for reference, check this image search: <a href="https://www.google.it/search?q=volantino+1948+vota&amp;tbm=isch" rel="nofollow">https://www.google.it/search?q=volantino+1948+vota&amp;tbm=isch</a> Apparently, most leaflets for the 1948 elections were using the transitive form.</p><p>There is also another form that "sounds transitive" while it's not, like <em>Vota comunista</em> or <em>Vota liberale</em>, in which "comunista" and "liberale" are used as a sort of adverb. It's like <em>Vesti giovane</em> and similar commercial slogans. In English, you have <em>Think pink</em>.</p>

<p>Come già espresso sia nei commenti sia nella risposta di Gabriele si tratta di un'evoluzione verso il <em>politically correct</em> di termini che hanno una connotazione negativa. Nel campo delle malattie sordo diventa audioleso, cieco diventa non vedente e handicappato diventa diversamente abile mentre nell'ambito lavorativo spazzino (o anche <em>netturbino</em>) diventa operatore ecologico, bidello diventa operatore scolastico e così via.</p><p>Questa evoluzione potrebbe anche essere nata da un tentativo di riqualificazione di lavori considerati umili o degradanti (<a href="http://books.google.it/books?id=fjoqAQAAIAAJ&amp;q=%22operatore%20ecologico%22&amp;dq=%22operatore%20ecologico%22&amp;hl=it&amp;sa=X&amp;ei=KtCMUqfMDIfX0QW6wYDQDA&amp;redir_esc=y" rel="nofollow">Studi di lessicografia italiana, Volumi 17-18</a>), o di riduzione del conflitto sociale "<em>con strategie simboliche che mascherano l'impotenza (o la malevola indifferenza) di chi dovrebbe aiutare fattivamente queste persone a migliorarsi in salute o a guadagnare di più.</em>" (cit. <a href="http://books.google.it/books?id=Rj8dfTrr6CAC&amp;pg=PA388&amp;dq=%22operatore%20ecologico%22&amp;hl=it&amp;sa=X&amp;ei=ss6MUqHxHrL50gX3zIFQ&amp;redir_esc=y#v=onepage&amp;q=%22operatore%20ecologico%22&amp;f=false" rel="nofollow">Principi di sociologia</a>)</p>

<p>Wikipedia lists <a href="http://it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plurale_delle_parole_in_-io" rel="nofollow">some rules</a> and suggests that the plural form of <em>olio</em> is <em>olii</em>.<br>I used to think that <em>oli</em> sounds (and writes) better, and <a href="http://www.dizionario.rai.it/poplemma.aspx?lid=32480&amp;r=977" rel="nofollow">Dizionario d'ortografia e di pronunzia</a> confirms that.<br><a href="http://www.treccani.it/vocabolario/olio/" rel="nofollow">Treccani</a>, however, suggests yet another plural form, with circumflex: <em>ol&icirc;</em>.</p><p>Any rule of thumb I could use?</p>
titulo: Plural form of "olio"

cuerpo: <p>One should always check and double-check waht Wikipedia says, but in this particular case, I'd agree with its distinction between compulsory <em>-ii</em> in the case of a stressed <em>i</em> in <em>-io</em>, and multiple possibilities (<em>-i</em>, <em>-ii</em>, and <em>-î</em>) for an unstressed one.</p>

<p>La parola <em>testone</em> sta ad indicare, <a href="http://www.treccani.it/vocabolario/testone/" rel="nofollow">secondo i vocabolari</a> (tra le varie cose) una persona testarda e ostinata, e in traslazione anche una persona di scarsa intelligenza. Credo che abbia un senso di bonario sfottò.</p><p>Posto che credo che l'uso di questa parola non sia omogeneo tra le regioni, ma che abbia una maggiore diffusione in alcune, vorrei sapere:</p><ol><li>dove è più usato;</li><li>da dove viene l'antonomasia per cui l'accrescitivo del sostantivo "testa", che vorrebbe identificare una grossa testa, diventa nel significato invece una "testa dura", cioè una persona che non cambia idea o atteggiamento facilmente.</li></ol>
titulo: Motivo dell'antonomasia "testone" nella sua derivazione da "testa" e diffusione della parola

cuerpo: <p>There are some cases where the addition of a prefix can generate a homograph and therefore ambiguity is introduced.</p><p>Consider the verb <em>sentirsi</em> (to feel, but also to get/keep in touch):</p><p><em>Si sentiranno per i dettagli del progetto</em> (They will get in touch to design the project).</p><p>With the addition of the prefix "ri-" (for expressing iteration) one more, very different meaning would come up: </p><p><em>Si risentiranno per i dettagli del progetto</em> could become</p><ul><li>a. They will get in touch <em>again</em> to design the project (<em>ri</em> + <em>sentirsi</em>, see the meaning above);</li><li>b. They will feel offended by how the project was designed (<em>risentirsi</em>: to take offence, to feel offended).</li></ul><p>Of course there are more verbs I could bring as example (<em>prendere</em> -> <em>ri</em> + <em>prendere</em> vs <em>riprendere</em> is the first I can think about); I'd like to find an answer that covers them all, not just know how to disambiguate these specific sentences.</p><p>That said, is there any correct way to disambiguate, or should one always rephrase the sentence to make the context clearer?</p><p>I would use a hyphen (<em>ri-sentiranno</em>) to stress the prefix (and consequently the concept of iteration), but it looks a bit odd to read, at least to my eyes - and it's definitely wrong, as I understand from the answers above.</p>
titulo: Homographs generated by prefixes: how to disambiguate?

cuerpo: <p>Using <em>î</em> instead of <em>ii</em> is something that was once done, but nowadays that is not done anymore, at least on everyday usage. Between <em>olii</em> and <em>oli</em>, I would expect the latter to be used more often than the former, at least because it requires you to  write less letters, and generally there is no confusion about what <em>oli</em> means. (It would not be taken as plural of <em>olo</em>, since that is not an Italian word.)</p><p><em>Lo Zingarelli</em> reports just two plural word for <em>olio</em>: <em>oli</em> and <em>olii</em>.</p>
<p>Use 'si risentiranno <strong><em>sui</em></strong> dettagli del progetto' when you want to mean (a), otherwise, without further context, just as you explained, you could be misunderstood.</p>

<ol><li><p>'non condivido le ragioni <strong>di cui</strong> mi parli'</p></li><li><p>'non condivido le ragioni <strong>delle quali</strong> mi parli'</p></li></ol><p>Can anyone explain what the difference between (1) and (2) is?</p><p>According to me, there is no difference, but I'm under the impression that 'di cui' has a singular connotation, even if I cannot say that it is singular or that it is used more proficiently when it is referred to something perceived as singular.</p>
titulo: Difference between 'di cui' and 'delle quali'

cuerpo: <p>I agree that there can be ambiguity, but the hyphen is never used in cases like this.</p><p>The verb <em>risentirsi</em> (intransitive pronominal in the terminology of the Treccani dictionary) can <a href="http://www.treccani.it/vocabolario/risentire/">mean</a></p><blockquote>  <p>c. Reagire bruscamente, con irritazione e animosità, a un rimprovero o ad altri atti e comportamenti ritenuti ingiusti e offensivi: <em>non è il caso di risentirsi per una piccola osservazione</em>; <em>si è risentito di quell’incauta allusione</em>; <em>mi sono risentito a torto con te</em>; <em>è un carattere che si risente facilmente</em>; <em>risentirsi con qualcuno</em> (e più gravemente <em>contro qualcuno</em>), manifestargli il proprio risentimento.</p></blockquote><p>which is quite like the English <em>to resent</em>. Thus the sentence <em>si risentiranno per i dettagli del progetto</em> can very well be interpreted as <em>they'll resent the project details</em>.</p><p>I think that <em>si sentiranno ancora</em> is a better form; specifying the action can be another way: <em>si risentiranno per definire i dettagli del progetto</em> can hardly be given a meaning connected to resentment. However, the context might clear up the matter and make ambiguity unlikely: many phrases are ambiguous only if out of context, when the meaning of the words cannot be inferred from other information.</p>
<p>In Italy we never use olî. Also olii is not so common, even if it's better than oli.</p>

<p>To give a brief answer I can say I'm not sure if there is a formal better way to be used, but in spoken language both forms are used and none of them is frowned upon.For my personal experience, always talking about spoken language, the plural form "delle quali" is quite more formal than the singular form "di cui", but it could also be a regional matter.</p>

<p>When used with <em>complementi indiretti</em>, <em>cui</em> stays for <em>la quale</em>, <em>il quale</em>, <em>le quali</em>, <em>i quali</em>. </p><blockquote>  <p>La ragazza di cui ti parlavo è stata licenziata.</p></blockquote><p><em>Di cui</em> is not used only for the singular, nor implies the word is perceived as singular.</p>

<p>Both forms may be used interchangeably. In such a short sentence I'd prefer "di cui", while in a longer sentence like "non condivido le ragioni per le quali/per cui hai deciso di convocarmi stamattina" I'd prefer "delle quali", but I believe it's a matter of taste.</p>

<p>I'd add that if an adjective follows, like "oli vegetali", the form with a single "i" is commoner (curiosly, a quick googling shows that "olii vegetali" is mainly used by people which write about organic products and the like)</p>

<p>We can derive a general rule (with loads of exceptions, like everything in this language) from this case. When the expected plural form of a word contains a non-stressed double <em>i</em>, like "olio" -> "olii", "principio" -> "principii", there's a tendency to drop the second <em>i</em>: "oli", "principi" (Ngrams for "<a href="https://books.google.com/ngrams/graph?content=olii&amp;year_start=1900&amp;year_end=2008&amp;corpus=22&amp;smoothing=10&amp;share=&amp;direct_url=t1;,olii;,c0">olii</a>" vs "<a href="https://books.google.com/ngrams/graph?content=oli&amp;year_start=1900&amp;year_end=2008&amp;corpus=22&amp;smoothing=10&amp;share=&amp;direct_url=t1;,oli;,c0">oli</a>" confirm this graphically). However, some speakers do retain a memory of the double <em>i</em> in their pronunciation of such words, the <em>i</em> is slightly longer.</p><p>To tell a "single-<em>i</em>-that-used-to-be-double" from an ordinary single <em>i</em> the circumflex accent can be used and this is standard Italian grammar. This makes sense particularly when one needs to disambiguate, for example "principî" (plural of "principio", principle) as opposed to "principi" (plural of "principe", prince); this is the solution used in the Italian Constitution that includes a chapter called <em>Principî fondamentali</em>. Another solution in this case is the tonic accent: "principî" can be unambiguously written as "princìpi" because the other word is read as "prìncipi".</p><p>Conclusion: the three forms ("olii", "oli" and "olî") are equally acceptable, but as you can imagine the circumflex accent is unusual and most people wouldn't even be able to type it on their keyboard. AFAIK, this is the only case in which a circumflex accent can be used in Italian words not borrowed from foreign languages or dialects, I guess most Italians wouldn't even realise that in their language this accent exists.</p><p>Notice that the situation is entirely different with <em>stressed</em> plurals in <em>-ii</em> (e.g. "sgocciolìo" -> "sgocciolii"). In this case the double <em>i</em> is pronounced clearly by all speakers (the first <em>i</em> is stressed) and is compulsory. The opposite applies to nouns ending in <em>-cio</em>, <em>-glio</em>, <em>-scio</em> etc. where the <em>i</em> is not really used as a vowel: the plural form requires one <em>i</em>.</p>

<p>Both OK, "di cui" (and "per cui", "in cui" etc.) is shorter and invariant therefore it's more commonly used in spoken language and sounds less formal. Sometimes using "le quali" or the other forms with gender and number ("i quali", "il quale", "la quale") clarifies which is the noun referenced by the subordinate sentence, e.g.</p><blockquote>  <p>...la sconfitta di Napoleone, per cui ho pregato con tutte le mie forze.</p></blockquote><p>Did I pray for Napoleon or for his defeat?</p><blockquote>  <p>...la sconfitta di Napoleone, per la quale ho pregato con tutte le mie forze.</p></blockquote><p>Now you know (but if Napoleon were a woman, you'd still be confused).</p>

<p>Easy: a big head is a thick head!</p><p>In the South most words related with the head are created out of "capa" (from Latin "caput", head) instead of "testa" (Latin, "vase"). "Capa" and its derivatives are not part of standard Italian, but the masculine noun "capo" with the same meaning is. In the North you can find "crapa", whence "crapone" and similar forms with the same meaning as "testone", "capa tosta" etc.</p><p>In general I warn foreigners against any attempt at deriving general rules about Northern/Southern usage of words. Too messy and very often the divide is not just North vs South, it's about regions, provinces, sometimes even cities, and there's also a blurred line between regional speech and dialect (or dialect-derived Italian words). What can be more reasonably learned is which words can be understood everywhere, whatever their regional "flavour" is, and which cannot (e.g., "capacchione" or "testina" have no obvious meaning for all speakers).</p>

<p>As a side note: there's wide agreement about Tuscan literature having been very important in the birth of Italian literature and this is the reason why Florentine became the basis of modern Italian. But why was Tuscany so interested in literature in Italian? Because Tuscany had a very high concentration of "free cities" that represented, together with the maritime republics (one of which was also in Tuscany, Pisa), the first embryos of merchant capitalism and the new social class of the modern age, the bourgeoisie. This raised the cultural level of that area and at the same time the interest of the cultured milieu of Tuscany in the formation of a national culture and a national market.</p>

<p>A volte il presente indicativo dei verbi in "ire" è soggetto a grossi problemi di coniugazione, come per esempio "Cucire" che a volte viene portato a "Io cucisco" (anziché il corretto "Io cucio").Eppure alcuni verbi in "ire" si coniugano esattamente in questo modo, ad esempio "Patire" che diventa "Io patisco" e non "Io pato".Detto questo, esiste una regola che permetta di capire già dall'infinito dei verbi se andranno coniugati con il finale in "isco" oppure no?</p><p>[ENG]Sometimes the present form of verbs ending in "ire" is source of big conjugation problems, for example the verb "Cucire" sometimes is wrongly conjugated with "Io cucisco" (instead of the correct "Io cucio").But some verbs ending in "ire" are conjugated exaclty in thi way, for example "Patire" which becomes "Io patisco" and not "Io pato".This said, is there a rule of thumb to know from the infinite form if it will be conjugated with the ending "isco" or not?</p>
titulo: Esiste una regola generale per la coniugazione dei verbi in "ire"?

cuerpo: <p>Verbs ending in "<strong>ire</strong>" are the so called "<strong>third conjugation</strong>" which derives from second, third and fourth Latin conjugations. </p><p>In the 80-85% of the cases, <a href="http://it.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verbi_incoativi" rel="nofollow">according to this source on Wikipedia</a>, the verbs of this conjugation are called "incoativi": they are those whose conjugation may get an -isc element between root and ending and then there is no unique pattern of conjugation for them. </p><p>In this sense they are irregular in Italian and there is no specific rule to apply to discover it, but there are several lists of irregular verbs, as an example you can see <a href="http://it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terza_coniugazione" rel="nofollow">Wikipedia</a>.<br>You can also discover if they are regular or not by using some <a href="http://grammatica-italiana.dossier.net/coniugatore-verbi.htm" rel="nofollow">online tools</a> for automatical conjugation.<br>If you are interested in some more technical explainations on the origin of this conjugation, <a href="http://www.accademiadellacrusca.it/en/italian-language/language-consulting/questions-answers/coniugazione-verbi-come-capire-obbedire-ecc" rel="nofollow">Accademia della Crusca</a> dedicated an article.</p>

<p>The word <em>paese</em> means both <em>country</em> and <em>town</em>, in Italian.</p><p>What happens when the distinction is important? For example, today I saw a photo and wanted to ask my friend "Is this your town?". I ended using <em>città</em>, even though it wasn't a city, because I wanted her to understand that I wasn't talking about her country.</p><p>How do Italians get around this problem?</p>
titulo: How to disambiguate between the two possible meanings of 'paese'?

cuerpo: <p><em>Paese</em> is used for a quite small town, or village, indeed, but it can be ambiguous for Italians too, unless the context helps to clear the meaning. If I just said “<em>Il mio paese è il più bello del mondo</em>”, I could be boasting either about my country or my village.</p>

<p>It's simple: there's no direct way to work around the ambiguity.</p><p>You have one word for two different things:</p><blockquote>  <p><em>Paese</em> as town (small place where people live);</p>    <p><em>Paese</em> as a country (nation, state).</p></blockquote><p>The actual meaning is explicated by the context, unless you are in a particular case where you can use synonyms (<em>nazione</em> or <em>stato</em> for the second meaning).</p><p><em>Paese</em> as a town could be forcedly replaced by altered nouns like <em>paesino</em>, or <em>paesello</em>, in case you can't eliminate the ambiguity by other means.</p>

<p>Spesso, quando sono nel nord Italia, sento l'espressione "che la metà basta", per esempio nelle seguenti frasi:</p><blockquote>  <p>C'è un chiasso che la metà basta.</p></blockquote><blockquote>  <p>Sono così nauseato che la metà basta.</p></blockquote><p>È l'espressione <em>de quo</em> usata anche nel sud d'Italia? Se non lo è, quale espressione è usata al Sud che è equivalente per colore e tono?</p><p>Quasi dimenticavo di spiegarne il significato; eccolo con riferimento alle frasi di cui sopra:</p><blockquote>  <p>C'è un chiasso infernale.</p></blockquote><blockquote>  <p>Sono incredibilmente nauseato.</p></blockquote>
titulo: Uso di "che la metà basta" nel Sud Italia

cuerpo: <p>There isn't any way to disambiguate one use of the word with the other one; it all depends from the context.</p><p>In your case, since you are watching a photo, that helps: If you are looking a photo showing a town, then <em>È questo il tuo paese?</em> would be understood as "Is this your town?" not as "Is this your country?"<br>If, differently, you were watching the map of a country showing the full country, then <em>È questo il tuo paese?</em> would be understood as "Is this your country?" if you are not pointing at a specific town shown on the map (e.g. the capital of that country).</p><p>In other cases, there are set phrases for which the meaning is not ambiguous: In <em>un Paese democratico</em>, <em>paese</em> would be understood to mean <em>country</em>, not <em>town</em>; that is also true for <em>essere al servizio del paese</em>, <em>Paese nemico</em>, or <em>il paese quest'anno voterà due volte</em>. While <em>paese</em> is often written capitalized, it can still mean <em>country</em> even when it is not capitalized.</p><p>As side note, <em>paese</em> has also a third meaning: vast territory, generally inhabited and cultivated.</p>

<p>Sento che alcune persone, che hanno ottime capacità di memorizzazione, dicono 'ho un cervello memorioso'.</p><p>"Memorioso" sembra avere una sonorità interessante, tanto che forse può essere considerata una parola <em>doc</em> così come le altre.</p><p>Cosa sapreste dirmi in merito? Usate o conoscete questa parola?</p>
titulo: È "memorioso" una parola ormai comunemente accettata?

cuerpo: <p>This might be better answered in a history or linguistic forum; but since I stumbled upon your question while seeking help for myself, I'm giving you an educated opinion, which shouldn't be taken as any more than that.</p><p>For me, it seems obvious that this answer to the question, "Why does Ancient Greek have a higher degree of mutual intelligibility with Modern Greek, while Italian has diverged sharply from Latin?" is tied to the history of the Roman Empire (<strong>especially for Greek</strong>)</p><p>The analogy of 'Ancient Greek is to Modern Greek as <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_Latin">Classical Latin</a> is to Italian' is, at best, flawed. A better analogy would be: 'Ancient Greek is to Modern Greek as <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vulgar_Latin"><strong>Vulgar Latin</strong></a> is to modern Romance languages'. If you want to be more specific, a better analogy would be: 'Ancient Greek is to Modern Greek as <em>Italian</em> is to <strong>the Vulgar Latin spoken in the Apennine Peninsula'</strong>. </p><p>Many people assume incorrectly--not saying this applies to you--that Italian is the closest living relative of Latin. Phonologically and orthographically, Italian is no closer to Latin than any other Romance language (just ask a Spanish speaker). It's nearly impossible to select any one Romance language as being the "closest to Latin." </p><p>As I said above, this question is rooted in the histories of the Eastern and Western halves of the <strong>Roman Empire</strong>, specifically to <strong>the stability of the East</strong> and <strong>the numerous foreign invasions of the West</strong> after the Western half fell (e.g. Gothic influence in Italia). Western Europe was also subject to a series of invasions (and the Plague of Justinian, which decimated the population). Just to name a few examples, there were invasions by Germanic tribes, Huns, Magyars, Mongols, etc. </p><p>I'm fluent in Spanish, have studied Latin for six years, and am in the process of learning Italian with the help of my Italian family (Italian as in in Italy). I'm giving you an answer based <strong><em>only</em></strong> on my own perception and my knowledge of Western history; but my perception, like yours, is also colored by my experience.</p><blockquote>  <p>first of all, is my impression correct? Or it's just a byproduct of me being mother tongue Italian (I can spot more easily the differences and subtleties when comparing against my own language)?</p></blockquote><p>You seem to miss the external factors/pressures that caused Vulgar Latin dialects to diverge into separate languages, <strong>largely due to both the isolation of each region from one another and the very large influx of foreign invaders in Western Europe</strong>. Don't forget that at the time these languages began to develop, Western Europe entered the Dark Age.</p><p>But yes, of course your knowledge of Italian makes it easier to spot differences and patterns in Latin. Native speakers of other Romance languages might disagree with both of us as to which language is closest to Latin; <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Romanian_language#Historical_grammar"><em>Romanian</em></a> speakers--although I wouldn't agree--might say that Romanian is the closest living language to Latin, and <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Romanian_language#Classification">Wikipedia</a> also makes this connection regarding structure/grammar, for what it's worth. </p><p>And since you've mentioned grammatical case, Romanian is the only one of the major living Romance languages to preserve both grammatical case and the <em>neuter gender,</em> which is absent from most other Latin-based languages. </p><p>All five of the major Romance languages have undergone major spelling reforms, thus making your question harder to answer. The five most widely-spoken Romance languages all have <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Romanian_language"><em>language academies</em></a>, so all have had major spelling reforms since the fall of the Western half of Rome.</p><blockquote>  <p>if so, what historical situations determined this situation? In particular, how did it happen that koiné (200 B.C.) is still mostly understandable by Greeks, while we Italians have serious problems with anything before the "sao cco kelle terre" (963 A.D.)?</p></blockquote><p>My best <em>educated guess</em> would be that the similarities between Ancient Greek, Koiné, and Ancient Greek are due to the fact that <strong>the Roman Empire lasted well into the modern era.</strong> Remember that <strong>Greece was <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Byzantine_Greeks">Rome</a></strong> until it was captured by the Ottoman Empire in the 15th century, and that <a href="http://www.romanity.org/htm/fox.01.en.what_if_anything_is_a_byzantine.01.htm">Greeks</a> referred to themselves as <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Byzantine_Empire"><em>Romaioi</em></a>. While it was subject to foreign invasions, <strong>the Eastern Roman Empire was very stable compared to the chaos that ensued in Western Europe</strong> after the fall of the <em>Western Roman Empire</em>.</p><p>In other words, the <strong>Eastern Roman Empire (Greece) preserved the structure/syntax/lexicon of Greek as the lingua franca of the Empire shifted from Latin to Greek.</strong> Note that the Renaissance in Europe began close to the fall of Rome, and the revival of Greek and Roman literature was largely due to the preservation of Greek/Roman culture in the Byzantine/Roman Empire. (this is why most medical terminology is derived from Greek). That is, <strong>while Western Europe was in chaos and in flux, the Eastern half of the Empire flourished for another thousand years.</strong> That's probably the biggest reason for the lack of preservation of Latin.</p><p>So in essence, my <strong>opinion</strong> is that the <strong>political stability</strong> of what is referred to as the Byzantine Empire today is largely responsible for the preservation of Greek and explains why there is a significantly higher level of mutual intelligibility between Ancient and Modern Greek as opposed to Latin and the Romance languages.</p><blockquote>  <p>finally, what would be a more correct comparison? Modern Greek is to Ancient Greek what Italian is to ... ? (maybe Dante/Petrarca's Italian?).</p></blockquote><p>As I've stated above, a better analogy would be <em>as Italian is to Italic Vulgar Latin.</em></p>

<p>I've been learning Italian for the last year. While being fluent in Spanish helps tremendously, there is one infamous sound that is lacking from both English and my dialect of Spanish: gli.</p><p>I understand that <em>gli</em> is a palatal approximate and that it is supposed to sound something similar to a Spanish 'l' and a 'y'. My understanding is, however, that it is to be pronounced as one consonant. The classic example for English speakers is to use the 'l' in million, but to me that's just a 'y'. Someone suggested that I try saying it like Botelli in Spanish, but that comes out as a double 'y' for me, which I know is wrong (honestly, -lli is odd for a Spanish speaker; In my dialect it would be a double 'y').</p><p>Basically these are my questions:</p><ol><li>Is this one consonant or is it geminated? When I think of the 'l' sound in million, to me, it sounds geminated. I distinctly hear an 'l', but I'm not sure if I'm mishearing it.</li><li>How is the tongue positioned for this sound? I've been trying to pronounce it as an 'l' with the back of my tongue touching my soft palate instead of the tip of my tongue touching the alveolar ridge as it normally would be for 'l'. Is this correct?</li><li>Am I correct that the 'gli' article is pronounced differently? In other words, if I were to say gli figli, are those two completely different sounds?</li></ol><p>I'm not sure that I'll ever master this sound, but I'd like to try to improve it at least.</p>
titulo: Can anyone help me with the proper pronunciation of the lateral palatal approximante (aka 'gli' trigraph)?

cuerpo: <ol><li><p>If by "geminated" you mean that we have gemination, i.e. the consonant is doubled or has different length, then no, we don't. It's a whole different sound than "ll" in Italian. First, it's a <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palatal_lateral_approximant">Palatal lateral approximant</a>, in that page you can hear a sample of what it sounds like.</p><p>It's basically the sound you write as <em>ll</em>  in Castillan Spanish (from Spain), as in <em>llamar</em>.</p></li><li><p>Not sure how to best describe it, but from the L position, I take the tongue back a little bit and make the tip of it round, or at least this is what it feels like to me.</p></li><li><p>No, <em>gli</em> and <em>figli</em> have the same pronunciation, but you should say <em>i figli</em>. Also note that GL before A, E, O, and U is pronounced as two distinct sounds, G and L. Also at the beginning of a word, e.g. <em>glicerina</em>.</p></li></ol>
