cuerpo: <p><a href="http://italian.stackexchange.com/questions/1446/uso-corretto-della-locuzione-ne-ne-con-la-preposizione-senza/1447?noredirect=1#comment1932_1447">It seems</a> that "senza A e B" is not acceptable in the Italian language, but "senza A o B" is.</p><p>Can anyone explain why?</p><p>As far as I can tell, I often hear people saying, for example:</p><blockquote>  <p>Sono venuto senza giacca e cravatta.</p>    <p>Questi alimenti sono senza coloranti e conservanti.</p>    <p>Poverino, l'hanno operato senza bisturi ed anestesia.</p>    <p>Le strutture scolastiche campane sono ancore senza assistenza e servizi di trasporto per le persone diversamente abili.</p>    <p>Purtroppo moltissimi giovani sono senza laurea ed esperienza.</p></blockquote><p>and so on.</p><p>Are all they wrong?</p>
titulo: Is "senza A e B" acceptable?

cuerpo: <p><a href="http://meta.italian.stackexchange.com/questions/125/is-italian-language-still-alive/127#127">Rispondendo ad una domanda su <em>meta</em></a>, ho scritto "sull'orlo del precipizio", che, come noto, è una espressone figurata.</p><p>Poi, ho pensato di sostituire "precipizio" con "collasso" e, quindi, scrivere "sull'orlo del collasso", ma nel fare ciò mi sono chiesto se fosse corretto lasciare "sull" o usare "all".</p><p>Non so, ma ho l'impressione che "sull'orlo del collasso" non sia quanto di meglio è possibile scrivere perché "sull", a mio giudizio, tende a conferire materialità ad un "orlo" che il <em>collasso</em>, a differenza del <em>precipizio</em>, effettivamente non ha, mentre "all" no.</p><p>Così opinando, "all" sarebbe più corretto di "sull". Confermate? O in questo caso sarebbe possibile modificare solo parzialamente l'espressione iniziale senza che ciò comporti dissonanze?</p>
titulo: 'sull'orlo del collasso' contro 'all'orlo del collasso'

cuerpo: <p>I'm a little bit ahead of my Italian lessons, but I hear people using forms of <em>cosare</em>, but don't fully understand it. I'm trying to figure out what it means in English (or even Spanish, although English is my native tongue). The closet thing I could think of was do (when used generically, not as an auxiliary)</p><p>I understand that it's used in <em>Che cosa?</em> to mean <em>What?</em>, but I don't understand why it's necessary. I'd always thought that it meant <em>What happened?</em>, but my grandfather (born in Abruzzo, but a terrible teacher!) says it just means <em>What?</em></p><p>I'm not entirely sure whether <em>cosa</em> is used as a noun or a verb in that question, but it seems like it would be a verb.</p><p>It reminds me of the <em>do</em> in the English <em>Let's do lunch</em>, but my grandfather said that idiom really doesn't translate into Italian very well. He suggested <em>Facciamo il pranzo</em>, but said that it would be <em>Cosiamo il pranzo</em> if I <strong>insisted</strong> on using <em>cosare</em>. Even though he didn't like that, he said I can use it generically for any verb, and he did give me some examples, but I don't understand it semantically.</p><p>I've tried figuring this out using Google Translate by translating sentences from both English and Spanish, but Google doesn't recognize the word <em>cosare</em>.</p><p>For example, I started with <em>Possiamo mangiare il pranzo di domani?</em> I then substitued <em>cosare</em> for <em>mangiare</em> and got <em>Can we cosare tomorrow?</em> </p><p>I thought that maybe it just doesn't translate well into English, so I tried translating it into Spanish first (in my head, not with the translator). I replaced first <em>comer</em> with <em>cosare</em> and then <em>almorzar</em> as an alternate and got <em>¿Podemos cosare mañana?</em> in Spanish for both. I tried using a 3rd phrasing in Spanish with the original question and got <em>avere</em> for the verb, but I ended up with another meaningless translation, which you could probably guess.</p><p>After getting frustrated, I decided maybe I should try something more basic and tried entering <em>Coso quello</em> for <em>Voglio quello</em>, but it still just gives me the translation of <em>Coso that</em> in English, and <em>CosA ese</em> in Spanish. That would mean <em>thing that</em> in English, but it's nonsense in Spanish too.</p><p>I tried <em>Io coso buono</em> for <em>Io sono buono</em> and <em>Coso bene</em> for <em>Sta bene</em>, and got <em>good thing I</em> for <strong>both</strong>, at which point I decided that was about as basic as I could possibly get and gave up.</p><p>Are there any English phrases, idioms, words, or expressions that can approximate the meaning of <em>cosare</em> in Italian? Am I at least attempting to use this verb properly?</p>
titulo: Is ‘cosare’ equivalent to the generic use of ‘do’ in English?

cuerpo: <p>First, <em>cosa</em> in <em>Che cosa?</em> is indeed a noun, used to reinforce the question. Since <em>cosa</em> means generally any object or action (analogue to "something" or "anything" in English), you can omit it without losing the meaning:  </p><blockquote>  <p>Che? Cosa? Che cosa?<br>  What?<br>  Che (cosa) sta succedendo?<br>  What's (that, that is) happening?</p></blockquote><p>The verb <em>cosare</em> is used only if you don't remember the proper word to describe an action. In English, it'd be like saying "do that thing," assuming that your listener knows or can guess what you are talking about. You can't translate it directly with "to do" or "to have."  </p><blockquote>  <p>Ieri ho cosato una cosa.<br>  Yesterday I, you know, did that, you know, a thingy.</p></blockquote><p>It's better not to use <em>cosare</em> in any other context and certainly not to try to use it as generic "to do," unless you intend it to be ironic. Taking your example, <em>cosiamo il pranzo</em>: it's unclear whether you'd mean <em>facciamo il pranzo</em> "let's have lunch," <em>saltiamo il pranzo</em> "let's skip lunch" or, maybe, <em>buttiamo il pranzo</em> "let's throw the meal away."<br> Famous Italian comedian Paolo Cevoli, for instance, has made popular the sentence:</p><blockquote>  <p>Non lo so, però c'ho ragione e i fatti mi cosano!<br>  I don't know anything about it, but I'm right and the facts do me you-know-what!</p></blockquote><p>In this case, an intended expression would be <em>i fatti mi danno ragione</em> "the facts support me." But since it's not clear from the verb <em>cosare</em> what exactly those facts do, it might as well be <em>i fatti mi contraddicono</em> "the facts disprove my opinion." The uncertain meaning of <em>cosare</em>, hence, results in a joke.  </p>

<p>Vorrei sapere qual è la reale diffusione della parola "tegoline", l'equivalente veneto di "fagiolini", e se nel resto d'Italia si dica realmente "fagiolini" o si usino altri sinonimi. </p><p>Vivendo nel nord-est ho sempre sentito e detto "tegoline", e anzi pensavo fosse una parola dell'italiano standard, fino a quando non mi sono resa conto del contrario. Fino a qualche anno fa non sapevo neanche che esistesse la parola "fagiolini"...Mi chiedo come si distribuiscano geograficamente i due termini e se ne esistano altri.</p>
titulo: "tegoline" vs "fagiolini"

cuerpo: <p><a href="http://www.treccani.it/vocabolario/tegoline/">http://www.treccani.it/vocabolario/tegoline/</a></p><blockquote>  <p>tegoline s. f. pl. [der. di tega]. – Nome <strong><em>veneto</em></strong> dei fagiolini o cornetti, legumi forniti dalla pianta Vigna unguiculata (sinon. Vigna sinensis), leguminosa orticola, forse originaria dell’Africa tropicale e diffusa nella regione mediterranea già durante l’Impero Romano. </p></blockquote><p>Quindi si conferma che è un sostantivo di uso essenzialmente regionale. Ma la conferma più importante, secondo me, viene dal marketing: un marchio diffuso su tutto il territorio nazionale come la Findus vende i <a href="http://www.findus.it/it-it/prodotti/cerca-per-marca/findus/fagiolini_primavera/">Fagiolini Primavera</a>, non le "Tegoline Primavera".</p>

<p>Sono corrette entrambe diciamo che l'utilizzo del <strong>"sia...sia"</strong> è tradizionalmente più corretto in quanto l'uso del <strong>"sia...che"</strong> è entrato in auge dalla metà dell'Ottocento; prima addirittura il <strong>"sia"</strong> veniva coniugato ("siano...siano","fosse...fosse") (Della Valle, Valeria, and Giuseppe Patota. Il salvaitaliano. Vol. 20. Sperling &amp; Kupfer, 2000. pp.172-172). <a href="http://www.accademiadellacrusca.it/it/node/591">Alcuni sostengono</a> che in particolari casi sia anche più univoca in quanto il <strong>"sia"</strong>  ha molto spesso un valore coordinativo-aggiuntivo mentre il <strong>"che"</strong> può essere utilizzato come pronome oltre che come congiunzione. Per esempio:</p><blockquote>  <p>I forum vengono utilizzati sia dagli italiani che hanno una lingua complicata e che non  hanno una buona istruzione che dai giapponesi che hanno una scrittura  molto difficile.</p></blockquote><p>L'uso del <strong>"sia"</strong> potrebbe chiarire maggiormente il costrutto.</p><blockquote>  <p>I forum vengono utilizzati sia dagli italiani che hanno una lingua complicata e che non  hanno una buona istruzione sia dai giapponesi che hanno una scrittura  molto difficile.</p></blockquote><p>In realtà anche in questi casi mi sembra che il senso si riesca a carpire in entrambe le versioni sopratutto se ci aiutiamo con le virgole! </p>

<p>Io sono veneta di origine, ma vivo in Lombardia ormai da 30 anni. Qui nessuno mi capirebbe se chiedessi delle <em>"tegoline"</em>, ma allo stesso tempo io mi rifiuto di utilizzare il vocabolo <em>"cornetti"</em>, per cui confermo che il vocabolo <strong><em>"fagiolini"</em></strong> è una parola passepartout, nel senso che nessuno mi ha mai chiesto chiarimenti quando l'ho usata in giro per l'Italia, mentre <em>"tegoline"</em> per me resta un vocabolo legato all'infanzia.</p>

<p>I don't think one should prefer <em>all'orlo</em> to <em>sull'orlo</em> in any case. They have perhaps slightly different meanings: <em>sull'orlo del baratro</em> might suggest you are even looking down the chasm, while <em>all'orlo</em> might not bear this additional idea.</p><p>Just sensations, perhaps.</p><p>What's really bad is the ‘squared metaphor’. In my opinion <em>all'orlo del collasso</em> means nothing (and <em>sull'orlo</em>, either). <em>Sembrava sull'orlo del collasso</em> can better be <em>Sembrava vicino</em> (or <em>prossimo</em>) <em>al collasso</em>. The influence of a well known movie title has made this phrase ubiquitous; but it's ugly nonetheless.</p><p>By the way, <em>sull'orlo del collasso</em> outscores <em>all'orlo</em> by 561000 to 54200 on Google.</p>

<blockquote>  <p>Questa questione è superabile al verificarsi della condizione X o anche al verificarsi della condizione Y.</p></blockquote><p>Cosa significa la frase testé trascritta? </p><ol><li><p>Che la questione è superabile al verificarsi della sola condinzione X.</p></li><li><p>Che la questione è superabile al verificarsi della sola condinzione Y.</p></li><li><p>Che la questione è superabile al verificarsi di entrambe le condizioni X e Y.</p></li></ol><p>Ci fosse solo "<strong><em>o</em></strong>" sarebbe chiaro, ma la locuzione "<strong><em>o anche</em></strong>", cioé la 'o' seguita da 'anche', non mi consente di capire.</p>
titulo: Cosa significa 'o anche' in 'Questa questione è superabile al verificarsi della condizione X o anche al verificarsi della condizione Y'?

cuerpo: <p>Credo che un Google Ngram possa essere utile per capire l'utilizzo della parola  nella produzione scritta:<img src="http://i.stack.imgur.com/aJQJ2.png" alt="enter image description here"></p><p>Ovviamente si tratta di una parola dialettale che trova i rispettivi analoghi negli altri dialetti italiani. Abbiamo <a href="http://www.dialettando.com/dizionario/detail.lasso?id=49860" rel="nofollow">per esempio</a> per il ligure "fasulèini", il romagnolo "fasulén", il molisano "fascellite", e forse anche sopratutto con il più diffuso "cornetti" anch'esso accettato ma con diffusione regionale molto differente.</p><p>I veneti sono penalizzati (rispetto, per esempio, ai sardi per cui la traduzione di fagiolino è "aioleddu") dal fatto che non sono presenti fonemi riconducibili strettamente al dialetto veneto, il che può non rendere così palese la sua origine dialettale e indurre molti veneti all'errore di ritenerla una parola appartenente all'italiano corrente. </p><p>Forza tegoline!</p>

<p><em>Questa questione</em> is really ugly. <code>;-)</code>.</p><p>The meaning is clear: either condition X or condition Y is sufficient.</p><p>The way the sentence is built may induce the idea that condition X is the most probable; but it's clear from <em>anche</em> that the <em>o</em> is not to be intended in exclusive sense. </p><p>If it had been <em>e anche</em>, then interpretation 3 would be the only acceptable one. Many people (wrongly) feel that <em>o</em> only means the Latin <em>aut</em>; but it's undoubtedly usable and used in the sense of <em>vel</em>. So in many cases people resort to <em>o anche</em> or even to the horrible <em>e/o</em>.</p>

<p>"che" and "cosa" are interchangeable and they can also be used both at the same time</p><blockquote>  <p>A: I broke it!<br>  B: what?</p>    <p>A: l'ho rotto!<br>  B: cosa? (pronoun)</p>    <p>A: l'ho rotto!<br>  B: che? (pronoun) (less common, depends on a zone)</p>    <p>A: l'ho rotto!<br>  B: che cosa? (pronoun + noun)</p></blockquote><p>"cosare" is terrible, and you should totally avoid using it, it doesn't have a real meaning and it doesn't have any rules, it's just a verb that can be used potentially as a substitute of any verb.</p>

<p>I understand that in italian the letter "e" can make two different vowel sounds:</p><ul><li><strong>[ɛ] like the e in bet</strong></li><li><strong>[e] like the a in chaos</strong></li></ul><p>Recently, I was caught off guard by an Italian song where the singer sang "vedo". Since I had learned to pronounce it as [vedo], I was surprised to hear it sung as [vɛdo]. (which is correct?)</p><p>The rules I learned only pertained to particular conjugation endings like:</p><pre>       Imperfect -ERE     rimanevo | rimanɛvamo    —————————————————————    rimanevi | rimanɛvate    —————————————————————    rimaneva | rimanevano    We will eat: mangɛrɛmo   We would eat: mangɛremmo</pre><p>When encountering new words, are there any rules of thumb for figuring out which sound to use?</p>
titulo: Pronounce "e" like [ɛ] or [e]?

cuerpo: <p>The unstressed <em>e</em> is always pronounced closed ([e] in IPA). The classical example of a minimal pair is <em>pesca</em>, which is</p><ul><li><p>['pɛsca] when it means “the peach”</p></li><li><p>['pesca] when it means ”fishing”</p></li></ul><p>But regional pronunciation varies; in Northern Italy, both words usually have the closed <em>e</em>. In several local pronunciation schemes in Calabria there's no distinction between the two sounds.</p><p>How can one distinguish between the two sounds? By etymology. For instance, <em>neve</em> (snow) comes from Latin <em>nives</em>, so we can predict a closed vowel: ['neve]. On the contrary, <em>vento</em> (wind) comes from <em>ventus</em> and so an open vowel is used: ['vɛnto]. The numeral <em>venti</em> (twenty) originates from <em>viginti</em>, so the <em>e</em> is closed. Similarly, Latin's diphthong <em>ae</em> produces [ɛ].</p><p>However, it's fairly common to hear ['vento] for wind and ['vɛnti] for twenty and etymology can also be misleading. I'm not able to say ['neve], to be honest, and it's always ['nɛve] for me, because that's how it's pronounced in my region.</p>

<p>Certe volte mi chiedo, è corretto dire </p><blockquote>  <p>... sarebbe potuto essere diverso ...</p></blockquote><p>o, si dovrebbe dire</p><blockquote>  <p>... avrebbe potuto essere diverso ...</p></blockquote><p>C'è una regola che governa questo costrutto? E se c'è, si applica anche a</p><blockquote>  <p>... sarebbe dovuto essere diverso ...</p></blockquote><p>e, correlativamente, a</p><blockquote>  <p>... avrebbe dovuto essere diverso ...</p></blockquote><p>?</p>
titulo: "avrebbe potuto essere diverso"

cuerpo: <p>In realtà, è una questione abbastanza intricata. Generalmente, si sceglie l'ausiliare del verbo retto dal servile, per esempio: <em>avrebbe potuto mangiare</em> (come "avrebbe mangiato"); <em>è dovuto andare</em> (come "è andato").<br>Però se il verbo servile è seguito dal verbo <em>essere</em>, si usa l'ausiliare <strong><em>avere</em></strong>, per esempio: <em>avrei voluto essere presente, avrebbe dovuto essere diverso</em>.</p><p>La situazione cambierebbe, se vi fosse anche la presenza di un pronome personale o riflessivo atono (<em>mi, ti, gli/le, ci, vi, si</em>) o di particelle atone come <em>ci/vi</em> (locative, presentative, fraseologiche):<br>- si usa l'ausiliare <em>essere</em> in caso di anticipazione del pronome (<em>gli sarebbe potuto essere utile; ci saremmo dovuti essere tutti</em>),<br>- <em>avere</em> in caso di posticipazione del pronome (<em>avrebbe potuto essergli utile; avremmo dovuto esserci tutti</em>). </p><ul><li><a href="http://www.accademiadellacrusca.it/it/lingua-italiana/consulenza-linguistica/domande-risposte/ausiliare-verbi-servili">Accademia della Crusca 1</a></li><li><a href="http://www.accademiadellacrusca.it/en/italian-language/language-consulting/questions-answers/scelta-ausiliari">Accademia della Crusca 2</a></li><li><a href="http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/verbi-ausiliari_%28Enciclopedia-dell%27Italiano%29/">Enciclopedia dell'Italiano (2010)</a></li><li><a href="http://www.treccani.it/magazine/lingua_italiana/domande_e_risposte/grammatica/grammatica_367.html">Treccani</a></li></ul>

<p>La frase è ambigua in modo irresolubile. Il chiarimento che chiedi riguarda lo statuto di verità della proposizione complessiva in funzione della verità delle due proposizioni costituenti. Se ci fosse solo "o" non sarebbe comunque risolta in quanto la disgiunzione italiana "o" non distingue tra aut (o esclusivo) e vel (non esclusivo) propri dell'uso latino (come giustamente messo in luce da @egreg). Il termine "anche" non è un connettivo logico bensì una particella copulativa che accresce quanto si è già detto; ovvero, in questo contesto, indica l'aggiunta di un'altra condizione ma non è dirimente in quanto non chiarisce la natura della connessione logica postulata.</p>

<p>I'm interested in languages and dialects and have heard that Sardinian is one of the most distinct varieties spoken in Italy.</p><p>I would like to ask whether most Italian speakers would consider Sardinian to be a dialect or a separate language?</p><p>And what would Sardinians / Sardinian speakers think?</p><p>Would a person from a distant part of Italy understand a person speaking Sardinian?</p>
titulo: Is Sardinian regarded as a dialect or a language of its own?

cuerpo: <p>Sardinian is a language of its own, derived directly from Latin. So Italian and Sardinian can be considered "siblings". There are some terms in common, and my guess here is that since Sardinian is oral in nature (lack of writings during its history), many words have been lost or forgotten (for example, the word for rainbow is <strong>arcu 'e sole</strong>, but I doubt many know it).</p><p>What happened is that due to its isolation, since it's spoken in an island, the language evolved much less and slower compared to Italian. </p><p>For example, in Italian we had the loss of <em>-um/-us</em> endings replaced by <em>-o</em>, but as far as Sardinian is concerned, only the finals were dropped, leaving a lot of words with <em>-u</em>. This might not be a valid general rule since we say "Sardinian" for convenience, but the truth is that there are many varieties across the island, the closer a village/town is to yours, the closer the language. So someone from the north wouldn't understand what someone from the south speaks. </p><p>There are also differences in grammar. An example is the possessive which is usually put after the noun that it affects.</p><p>As I said, some terms are in common, but generally someone from other parts might not understand it, if any. For example:</p><blockquote>  <p><strong>it.</strong> Cosa stai dicendo?<br>  <strong>en.</strong> What are you saying?<br>  <strong>sar.</strong> Itte sese nande? (This should be read as "itte sernande")</p></blockquote><p>Nande comes from "narrere" (to say), which is the same verb as "narrare" (to tell a story) in Italian. </p><p>Note that many things in this answer refer to the variety I speak, so others Sardinians might disagree about words or expressions. However the rest, which is what your question is about, is true for everyone.</p>

<p>I (politely) disagree with the statement: "that 'senza A e B' is not acceptable in the Italian language, but 'senza A o B' is." Overlooking the fact that the expression is commonly used, as you correctly reported, reason is the following: "e" and "o" are logical connectors so you could build equivalent statements  manipulating the original one by means of logical rules. So cannot be true that, given two propositions P and Q, being P e Q  not acceptable, P o Q is correct. This could seen this way:</p><p>NOT (P e Q) &lt;=> NOT(P) OR NOT(Q)</p><p>This way we should have two <em>equivalent</em> assertions, the first not acceptable, the second perfectly acceptable.  How this could be possible?</p>

<p>Volevo capire l'utilizzo della maiuscola sugli aggettivi che fanno riferimento ad un nome di un luogo, nella fattispecie: una regione.</p><p>Per esempio io scriverei "autostrada veneta" e non "autostrada Veneta", oppure "pianura lombarda" e non "pianura Lombarda". Volevo sapere qual'è la forma corretta, e se per caso valesse anche in questo caso la regola che "Lombardo o Veneti" indica il riferimento ad un abitante o agli abitanti della regione.</p><p>Inoltre anche gli aggettivi riferiti a parti di regione sono abbastanza controversi per esempio vedo scritto  con la lettera maiuscola non solo "Alto Adige" ma anche "Alto Vicentino", "Bassa Padovana", "Alto Milanese" o addirittura "Basso Veneto". Qual è quindi la regola generale?</p>
titulo: Maiuscola per gli aggettivi con riferimento ad una regione ( pianura lombarda, autostrada veneta,Alto Milanese)

cuerpo: <p>il nome di un toponimo è in maiuscolo mentre l'aggettivo (o il nome degli abitanti) è in minuscolo, e fin qua direi che si è tutti d'accordo. In denominazioni come Alto Milanese chi usa il maiuscolo intende (implicitamente) che almeno per lui il territorio indicato è molto specifico. In effetti se si parla di "milanese" inteso come territorio che gravita su Milano la maiuscola non la si usa mai. Diciamo che se uno scrive "alto milanese" nessuno alza un sopracciglio.</p>

<p>I'd say that neither of them is better than "né".<br>I think in English you would use "nor", right? (I went without a jacket nor a tie). This is much better translated as "né": "Ci sono andato senza giacca né cravatta".<br>(Just note that "ne" and né" are two different words).</p>

<p>The verb "Cosare" doesn't really exist in Italian. Or, at least, it isn't used. To translate the English verb "to do" in Italian, we use the verb "fare"; the verb "fare" is used to indicate generic actions. For example,<br><em>Facciamo matematica</em> is a generic form for <em>Studiamo matematica</em>.<br>In this sense, the verb "cosare" is simply unused.<br>For this reason, Google doesn't give a translation for "cosare".<br>Used as "che cosa?" or "cosa?", it is equivalent to "what?", and its sense is neither of verb nor of noun, because in this context it is an adverb.</p>

<p>It is somehow a common rule in Italian to find many verbs negated with the <em>s-</em> prefix (e.g. <em>smonta</em>, <em>sparecchia</em>, <em>sposta</em>). </p><p>Does <em>sfiga</em> ("bad luck, misfortune") etymologically come from <em>figa</em> (<em>vagina</em>) or is just a coincidence? My impression is that <em>sfigato</em> (and, by extension, <em>sfiga</em>) is some sort of "man without a lady" (thus "unfortunate") and that this was its origin.</p><p>I have always wondered about the coincidence of those two terms.</p>
titulo: Does "sfiga" come etymologically from "figa"?

cuerpo: <p>Your impressions are confirmed by the Treccani dictionary. The word <em>fica</em> is mostly used in the variant <em>figa</em> in Northern Italy. Then <em>sfigato</em> is somebody without any attractiveness and, by extension, someone who is unlucky.</p><p>From this <em>sfiga</em> in the sense of “misfortune” was derived.</p><blockquote>  <p><strong>sfigato</strong> agg. [der. di <em>figa</em>, variante settentr. (ma largamente diffusa) di <em>fica</em>, col pref. s- (nel sign. 4); è più probabile che <em>sfiga</em> sia tratto da <em>sfigato</em>, che non viceversa]. – Nel linguaggio giovanile, sfortunato, iellato (anche con riferimento non a circostanze occasionali, ma a condizioni sociali, economiche e sim.): <em>sono sempre stato s.</em>; e con uso sostantivato: <em>non è facile trovare uno s.</em> (o <em>una s.</em>) <em>come te</em>; anche, privo di attrattive, di fascino, insignificante: <em>non portarti dietro la solita amica s.</em>; <em>mi ha invitato in un localetto davvero sfigato</em>.</p></blockquote><p>Contrary to the dictionary, I'd say that's what after “anche” should be the first meaning; not by usage, but historically.</p>

<p>I noticed that in Italian usually there is only one gender for one word, but there are some exceptions I thought were because of "bad native speakers". One of this exception is "tavolo" / "tavola". What's the explanation and the etymology behind this divergence?</p>
titulo: How come there are two gender forms, "tavola" and "tavolo"? Which one is proper?

cuerpo: <p>"Tavolo" is table as the furniture item. "Tavola" has (at least?) two separate meanings: a table set to eat, and "board". The etymology is actually the same, from the latin tabula.  </p><p>I'm looking for some concrete info on when "tavolo" and "tavola" did split from the common ancestor, but so far I found zilch (0) info, sorry. <a href="http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/alternanza-di-genere-e-di-significato_%28La_grammatica_italiana%29/">Treccani</a> in "Alternanza di genere e significato" just comments</p><pre><code>"A volte l’alternanza non produce sostanziali cambiamenti di significato,ma dà origine soltanto a diverse sfumature"</code></pre><p>which translates to "Sometimes the gender switch does not result in a substantial change in meaning, but just originates nuances." - and that's as far as I could go, sorry.</p>

<p>Interestingly, "fare la figa" is to make a good luck sign, which is to close your fist with the tip of your thumb sticking out between your index and middle fingers, like <a href="http://www.antiques.com/classified/1112452/Antique-Rare-silver-FIGA-charm-pendant-and-small-figa-on-wrist" rel="nofollow">&lt; here ></a>.I can't confirm, but it would be an interesting link if "sfiga" would be related to the fact that "figa" also meant "luck" sometimes in the past.</p>

<p>I come from a language that preserves the original names of cities and especially personality names, so I was very surprised to find in Italian translation of this particular substantive types. I even once had an argument with one Italian friend about Bruto; he didn't understand that his original name was Brutus.</p><p>A few examples: cities - Munich (Monaco), Stuttgart (Stoccarda), Paris (Parigi), Frankfurt (Francoforte), historical figures - Louis XIV (Luigi XIV), Henry VIII (Enrico VIII) or other names - Michael (Maicol)  etc. In English there isn't any great figure called John Brown (Giordano Bruno), so why the Italian language creates such confusion by doing the reverse?</p><p>I'm not referring to the slight gender adaptations like Dublin (Dublino), but to the very brutal ones like Munich, which I actually confused with the french Monaco for very long time. </p><p>My question: is this a rule, it is done nowadays as well, or it refers just some old adaptations and why it is done? I think there is a loss of meaning in this adaptation and I had difficulties discussing with Italians about famous historical figures because of this.</p>
titulo: Why translate cities and person names?

cuerpo: <p>This is done in every language: </p><ul><li><strong>English</strong> - Rome</li><li><strong>Russian</strong> - Рим, Людовик XIV</li><li><strong>Finnish</strong> - Rooma, Ludvig XIV</li><li><strong>German</strong> - Rom, Ludwig XIV</li></ul><p>The reason for this is the same everywhere I suppose. Not everyone knows every language pronunciation, actually far from that, so nouns get adapted by the speakers to make them easier to say and refer to.</p>

<p>Following your example:<br> - To somebody who just spoke something very vulgar, you can ask "Oxford?" ("Did you go to Oxford?") [I swear we say it].<br> - About somebody who's not really good-looking, "Non è un Adone" ("He's not an <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adonis" rel="nofollow">Adonis</a>")<br> - Not sure if this fits your requirements, it's a saying that originates from the game of <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Briscola" rel="nofollow">briscola</a>: if somebody's got no decisional power at all, you can say "Conta come il due di coppe quando comanda bastoni" (He's worth like the 2 of cups when the trump is clubs - that being among the lowest-power cards in the deck).  </p>

<p>Every language adapts foreign names to its phonetic system and its morphology, both proper and common names (<em>Munich</em> > <em>Monaco</em> is not that different from <em>beefsteak</em> > <em>bistecca</em>) to be able to pronounce and use them.</p><p>Re “other languages have slight modifications”, would you consider Firenze > Florence, Napoli > Naples, Livorno > Leghorn, where at most 2 or 3 phonemes survive, slight modifications? Not to mention España > Spain and so on.</p><p>Finally, have you ever checked the German name of “Munich”...?</p>

<p>That <em>München</em> in Italian becomes <em>Monaco</em> is not really strange: looking in Wikipedia we discover that</p><blockquote>  <p>Its native name, <em>München</em>, is derived from the Old High German <em>Munichen</em>, meaning "by the monks' place". The city's name derives from the monks of the Benedictine order who founded the city; hence the monk depicted on the city's coat of arms.</p></blockquote><p>I'm not sure you'll recognize the famous Italian city that Czechs call <em>Benátky</em>. I don't know what's your native language, but all languages I know of do such adaptations.</p><p>Every language has its own way to adapt foreign words; big towns (mostly capital cities, and there were <em>many</em> of them in Europe) and famous people are good candidates for such adaptations.</p><p>The results are quite strange. For instance, København becomes</p><ul><li>Copenaghen (Italian)</li><li>Kopenhagen (German)</li><li>Copenhagen (English)</li><li>Kopenhaga (Albanian)</li><li>Copenhague (Spanish)</li><li>Copenhague (French)</li></ul><p>For Italian one should remember that Latin used to be the European <em>lingua franca</em> and adapting words from Latin to Italian was too easy. So <em>Brutus</em> and <em>Caesar</em> become <em>Bruto</em> and <em>Cesare</em>. By the way, <em>Caesar</em> (as a title) became <em>Kaiser</em> in German and <em>Царь</em> in Russian.</p><p>There are stranger adaptations than <em>München</em> > <em>Monaco</em>. The Bavarian city of <em>Regensburg</em> is called in Italian <em>Ratisbona</em>. The Latin name of the town (which was founded by the Romans) was <em>Castra Regina</em>. Its modern name means “fortress by the Regen”, the river is named after the Roman town. Why <em>Ratisbona</em>? Because there was a Celtic village nearby called <em>Radasbona</em> or something like that and the town, for some time, was called with the Celtic name and so came to be known in Europe.</p><hr><p>The tendency to adapt the phonetics of foreign names is weaker than it was, say, forty years ago, when still the “official” name of New York was <em>Nuova York</em>. Traditional names are retained, of course: it would sound strange hearing <em>Vado a Paris e poi a London</em>.</p><p>But nobody speaks about <em>il principe Guglielmo</em>, to mean the present Duke of Cambridge. However, it's always <em>il principe Carlo</em> for his father. Maybe it depends on the easiness of adapting the name: the former and the present Kings of Belgium are <em>Alberto</em> and <em>Filippo</em>, in Italy. I don't know how the present King of the Netherlands is referred to in newspapers, but he's probably <em>Willem-Alexander</em>. Apart from monarchs, the tendency is to retain the original name for contemporary famous people.</p>

<p>What's the origin of the rule that composes the adverbial forms finishing in <em>-mente</em> (e.g. <em>velocemente</em>, <em>normalmente</em>, <em>assolutamente</em>, <em>diversamente</em> etc).</p><p>Is it somehow connected to <em>mente</em> (Latin <em>mens</em>, English <em>mind</em>) substantive?</p>
titulo: What's the origin of the "-mente" postfix? Is it connected to the "mente" substantive?

cuerpo: <p>Yes, it is. It continues the ablative form of Latin <em>mens</em>, which is indeed <em>mente</em>. So <em>felicemente</em> would have started meaning something like “in a happy state of mind.” (See for example the <a href="http://www.treccani.it/vocabolario/mente_res-efa0db69-0025-11de-9d89-0016357eee51/" rel="nofollow">Treccani article about “-mente”</a>.) </p>

<p>You are on the right track. It is indeed true that those words ending in <em>-mente</em>, which are always adverbs derived from adjectives, take their origin in the Latin <em>mens</em> (<em>mind</em>, but also <em>spirit</em>, <em>intelligence</em>, <em>thought</em>).</p><p>This is because in Latin itself, a construction like "A + mente" meant "with an A mind," where A is an adjective. </p><p>Starting from this, the word <em>mente</em> came, in Italian, to be attached directly to the adjective to create a new adverb. </p><h3>Sources</h3><ul><li><p><a href="http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/formazione-degli-avverbi_%28La_grammatica_italiana%29/" rel="nofollow">Treccani on the formation of adverbs</a></p></li><li><p><a href="http://www.zanichellibenvenuti.it/wordpress/?p=2072" rel="nofollow">Zanichelli on adverbs</a></p></li></ul>

<p>My conversation manual included the word <em>assai</em> very often as an equivalent for <em>troppo</em>, <em>molto</em>, etc. When I got in Italy one of my friends from there, of Neapolitan origin, said that is a Neapolitan word, not used in Italian and it is considered <em>vulgar</em> to use it, because of its peasant connotations. I heard it numerous times on TV and the shows weren't about history/ethnology, but nowadays subjects. Also other friends from Veneto didn't knew its meaning. So what's the story with this word?</p>
titulo: Is using "assai" in Italian considered vulgar language?

cuerpo: <p>What on Earth makes them think it is “vulgar”? It is a regular, non-regional Italian word (it appears in Petrarca, Leopardi etc. and is used for instance even in musical notation: <em>allegro assai</em> etc.). As for many words, it is used more or less in different parts of Italy (or, for other words, in different strata of population, or by different age groups): this are matters studied by sociolinguistics.</p><p>A point to be careful about: Its original meaning is <em>enough</em> (from Latin <em>ad satis</em>), but it has been used for centuries in the sense of “much, very.”</p><p>(As always happens for the meaning of single words, most of the story can be read in <a href="http://www.treccani.it/vocabolario/assai/" rel="nofollow">the relevant article of any good dictionary</a>.)</p>

<p><em>Assai</em> it's a sort of superlative and it's absolutely not vulgar. It comes from the Latin word <em>satis</em> that means <em>very</em> or <em>much</em> depending on the usage. In Southern Italy, it is often used as an adverb with the same meaning. For example:</p><p><em>[Corret usage]</em> Un uomo assai famoso (<em>A very famous man</em>.)<br><em>[Southern Italy usage]</em> Io ho mangiato assai. (<em>I ate too much</em>.)</p><p>TL;DR: No, it's not a vulgar.</p>

<p>I know from older and southern Italian friends that in their childhood they used the <code>"voi"</code> pronoun (like <code>"vous"</code> in French) as a polite form to address other persons. So how come this switched nowadays to the "Lei" form, a choice I must confess I found it always bizarre and always avoided it  because it seemed to me more impolite to address someone like if it wouldn't be present and potentially insulting males by referring them as females, than to actually use <code>"tu"</code> for everybody. So who dictated the sudden change?</p>
titulo: Who decided the switch from "voi" to "Lei" in the 20th century?

cuerpo: <p>Your friend is wrong when he says that this word is a regionalism. It is usually used as an adverb meaning "much, very", intended to reinforce an adjective:</p><blockquote>  <p>assai bello = very beautiful</p></blockquote><p>It may also be used in the sense of "many" in front of a noun (so, taking the value of an adjective). Beware, it's an old usage, mostly considered wrong nowadays (except than probably in the South):</p><blockquote>  <p>assai persone = many people</p></blockquote><p>Moreover, a third usage exists. You can indeed use it to mean "much" as an adverb:</p><blockquote>  <p>Ho fatto assai per te = I did much for you </p></blockquote><p>All this is perfectly fine in Italian (and that's why you hear it very often). </p><p>This said, I understand (a bit) what your friend meant. In Naples and the neighborhood, the word is used <em>after</em> an adjective (in the same sense outlined in my first example here), and this is a regional usage. It is anyway wrong to say that it does not exist in Italia. If the one from Veneto didn't know the word, it's his/her fault. </p><p>As for the etymology, the word comes from <em>ad satis</em>, Latin, meaning "enough" and indeed its original meaning has been shifted from "enough, in a sufficient way" to "much" (<a href="http://www.etimo.it/?term=assai" rel="nofollow">you can read the Italian etymology dictionary here</a>).</p>

<p>Both are still used, but "voi" is spoken only in south Italy. Using "Lei" it's more confidential and it's reported to the other "person" aspect, while "voi" is more polite, used for people at a topper level of you.</p>

<p>As for the relative difference in the usage or the two courtesy pronouns "Lei" and "Voi", I point out the answer in </p><p><a href="http://italian.stackexchange.com/questions/1238/darsi-del-tu-and-del-lei/1364#1364">&quot;Darsi del tu&quot; and &quot;del lei&quot;</a></p><p>The main idea outlined is that nowadays' standard Italian uses only <em>tu</em> as the informal friendly pronoun, and <em>Lei</em> as the courtesy one, so that <em>Voi</em> has almost disappeared, except than in some conservative usage in the South (mainly used to address old people). </p><p>As for the history: first of all <em>Voi</em> is much older (needless to say, it's the more intuitive). <em>Lei</em> comes from the 15th century usages like "vostra maestà/vostra Signoria" (possessive adjective related to "voi" with a feminine noun), which then originated the use of "Essa" (so, feminine) as courtesy pronoun and which then became "Lei".</p><p>Much later, during the Fascist years, the usage of <em>Lei</em> was discouraged through the imposition of the <em>Voi</em> as a rule (people were asked to rewrite things to change pronouns). This is because the nationalist regime believed that "Lei" came from the years of the Spanish domination over Italy (<a href="http://www.treccani.it/magazine/lingua_italiana/domande_e_risposte/grammatica/grammatica_118.html">this is not true, as we said</a>). </p><p><a href="http://www.accademiadellacrusca.it/en/italian-language/language-consulting/questions-answers/pronomi-cortesia">A detailed outline of all this here</a>.</p><p>This attempt hasn't had the result of eradicating <em>Lei</em> anyway. So, the difference between the two forms has a long history and the reason why it is still used in some dialects is because they probably didn't pass through the 15th century change. </p><p>I also want to report the answer by Indro Montanelli to this same question, <a href="http://www.corriere.it/solferino/montanelli/00-12-14/01.spm">here</a>. </p>
<p>As a foreigner I have always found the expression 'rompere le scatole' to be very funny. I know its meaning and I was wondering where it comes from.</p>
titulo: How was the expression 'rompere le scatole' born?

cuerpo: <p>The only info I could find on the net (<a href="http://freeforumzone.leonardo.it/lofi/modi-di-dire-riciclati-/D9639335.html" rel="nofollow">here</a> and <a href="http://www.netwargamingitalia.net/forum/threads/il-gergo-dei-soldati-italiani-nella-grande-guerra.14326/" rel="nofollow">here</a>) seem to point to the fact that during WWII, "to break the boxes" would refer to take ammo from their carton boxes, that is, an attack was imminent. It would be very cool if it was true, but both links lack any real source, so "caveat lector" ;)</p>

<p>for surnames of European people until XVII century, remember that the people themselves often "translated" their surname into Latin: for example, <strong>Gerhard Kremer</strong> is usually known as <strong>Gerardus Mercator</strong>. Italian people then used to think that Latin is just an old way to speak Italian, so they use the modern form and say "Mercatore".</p><p>For given names, during Fascism there was a strong force toward italianization of names (just to give an example, my father was born in 1934 and his name was Valter, not Walter, because W was not an Italian letter); the habit went until the late Sixties, with the anchorman Ruggero Orlando who talked of <strong>Nuova</strong> York instead of New York, but now the use is declining.</p><p>As for city names, the other commenters had shown that it is a common thing.</p>

<p>I know that both <code>"ti raccomando"</code> and <code>"mi raccomando"</code> are used with the sense of <code>"I recommend you"</code>, but to me, coming from outside, the use of the "mi" form seems illogical and should be translated as <code>"I recommend to myself"</code> (so if I need to recommend something to me, I don't need to speak to another person, I can just have a nice monologue in my head :) . So my questions are: is the "mi" form correct and it was born from a grammatical mistake gone mainstream or is something more subtle that I, as a foreigner, don't catch?</p>
titulo: Which one is correct: "ti raccomando" vs "mi raccomando"?

cuerpo: <p>In current language the valid form (And the only one i've ever heard) is certainly "mi raccomando" like in this sentence:</p><p>"Mi raccomando, fai attenzione"or"Fai attenzione, mi raccomando!"or"Mi raccomando," + {Do something}</p><p>While "ti raccomando" is limited to the use:</p><p>"Ti raccomando questa persona""Ti raccomando di usare questa marca"</p><p>which is used to give an advice about something or someone that "you" should use, based on "my" experience.</p>

<p>It came to my attention very fast the extensive use of "schifo", "fa schifo" in everyday language and TV, mostly in situations that actually don't cause disgust. I connected immediately to the <a href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-15619543" rel="nofollow">same trend that happened in the English</a> language since 1800's. I wanted to know if it is a recent thing, a reaction to everyday's stressful life, a manifestation of discontent about the Italian political situation exacerbated by the rise of TV. Is it an older phenomenon?</p><p>I also noticed an overload of those two terms in very peculiar situations. I remember only these:</p><pre><code>Questa cacciavite fa schifo.Questo è un schifo di televisione. - both with the meaning of not working properly</code></pre><p>Is this extension of meaning a recent phenomenon as well?</p>
titulo: Overuse and overload of "schifo", "fa schifo". Is it a recent thing?

cuerpo: <p>Please note that "mi raccomando" and "ti raccomando" have slightly different meanings, following that both the Italian "raccomandare" and the English "to recommend" come from "to entrust" in Latin.  </p><ul><li><p>"Ti raccomando" is used when you're just suggesting a course of action: "Ti raccomando di prendere l'ombrello prima di uscire" (although "ti consiglio" is more common now); if your listener doesn't grab an umbrella, bad for him, you warned him;  </p></li><li><p>"Mi raccomando" is used when you have something at heart, and you pledge the listener to follow your advice ("please trust me"). "Mi raccomando, prendi l'ombrello prima di uscire!"; if your listener doesn't grab an umbrella, the poor lad might get wet and catch a cold.</p></li></ul><p>So a parent will most often say "mi raccomando" to a child, while a sign will read "si raccomanda" (e.g. "si raccomanda ai viaggiatori di non lasciare i bagagli incustoditi".<br>It would take a scorned parent to say "ti raccomando" ("do what you please, but don't come back crying if you don't follow my advice and things turn out for the worse").<br>On the other side it would be weird to have a sign read "mi raccomando, state attenti ai bagagli", because signs are impersonal. You can't really feel somebody being sorry about your stolen luggage "on the other side" of the sign.</p>

<p>The unusual reflexive construction of <em>raccomandare</em> is explained by its original meaning of <em>raccomandare</em> as “entrust”. So one could <em>raccomandare qualcuno (o la propria anima, o sé stesso) a qualcun altro, a Dio</em> etc. The phrase <em>mi raccomando</em> (especially <em>a Dio</em>) became fixed – and its original meaning forgotten – to mean little more than “please”, just like in English such phrases as “pray” (as in “and what, pray, was the purpose of that?”).</p><p>The <em>ti raccomando</em> construction is somewhat more transparently connected to the original meaning of “to entrust, to commend”.</p>

<p>The increasing use of the word <code>schifo</code> and derivative terms is not uncommon in everyday life in Italy, whereas it is true that it is more common to hear it on TV and that is mainly because the commonly spoken language (even in formal contextes) is being leveraged towards dialectal and colloquial forms.</p>

<p>As egreg has noted, <em>scatole</em> is currently used as an euphemism. There are other expression that use <em>scatole</em> as a replacement for <em>testicles</em>, like 'averne piene le scatole' or 'andare fuori dalle scatole'. <a href="http://dizionari.corriere.it/dizionario-modi-di-dire/S/scatola.shtml" rel="nofollow">Here</a>, <a href="http://dizionarioitaliano.it/scatola/" rel="nofollow">here</a>, and <a href="http://www.treccani.it/vocabolario/scatola_%28Sinonimi-e-Contrari%29/" rel="nofollow">here</a> you can find references. However, I am not sure about the origin of the expression. Maybe it was not strictly linked to the meaning 'testicles'.</p><p>The expression was already used in the XIX century. The following quote is from Primiero, Antonio Prospero, Philippe Joseph Simon, and Badon Edmond, <em>I figli della calunniata. Dramma in 5 atti</em>, 1844.</p><blockquote>  <p>Ast. Andiamo, già fra vicine ed amiche... </p>    <p>Raim. Fra vicine ed amiche già... ci possiamo rompere le scatole tutto il santo giorno, non è vero?</p></blockquote>

<p>I can't find much information about this expression. Obviously the meaning is clear (being lazy), but I was wondering about its origin. I just found some unconvincing sources on yahoo answers, but nothing more. Anyone knows something about it?</p>
titulo: Where does the expression "battere la fiacca" come from?

cuerpo: <p>How come in Italian the same word is used to express the action of offering/inviting and afterwards to respond to the person who thanked you. What's the origin of it and how come the verb "to pray" is used for this?</p>
titulo: How was the double meaning/use of "prego" in the sequence "prego-grazie-prego" born?

cuerpo: <p>I know some people who use it as a first name and others who use it as a last name. There is also a place in Italy called <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Castell%27Alfero" rel="nofollow">Castell'Alfero</a> which I understand to mean "The castle of Alfero".</p>
titulo: Does the name "Alfero" mean anything?

cuerpo: <p>I don't have any official reference for this, but from a logic perspective it means "la prego", it being a warm and polite invitation to accept an offer (a door held open, for instance).</p><p>In the same way, when someone says "Grazie", "Prego" is an invitation to stop thanking - again, polite - because the gratitude has been acknowledged.</p>

<p>It is a variant form of Alfiero, a name of Germanic origin deriving from <em>athala</em>, "nobility", and <em>faraz</em>, "who guides"; so, all in all, something like “noble guide”. See <a href="https://it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alfiero" rel="nofollow">https://it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alfiero</a></p>

<p>Here is a relevant, reliable source: <a href="http://www.accademiadellacrusca.it/it/lingua-italiana/consulenza-linguistica/domande-risposte/perch-fiacca-si-batte" rel="nofollow">http://www.accademiadellacrusca.it/it/lingua-italiana/consulenza-linguistica/domande-risposte/perch-fiacca-si-batte</a> .</p><p>It's military jargon, like "battere la carica", "battere la ritirata", etc., and it originated in Piedmont at the end of the nineteenth century.</p><p>"Fiacca" means "stanchezza", "spossatezza", "lack of energy". It comes from "fiacco", and this from Latin "flaccus-a-um", meaning "stanco" (<a href="http://www.treccani.it/vocabolario/fiacco1" rel="nofollow">here</a> and <a href="http://www.treccani.it/vocabolario/fiacco_%28Sinonimi-e-Contrari%29/" rel="nofollow">here</a>).</p><p>So, "battere la fiacca" means "being strenuously committed to … let laziness/idleness/indolence/tiredness prevail" (the contrary of a military attack).</p>

<p>I'd like to suggest "Alfiere" as a possible derivation for such name. As of the above claim of Germanic origin, according to "Wiktionary" (source: <a href="http://it.wiktionary.org/wiki/alfiere" rel="nofollow">http://it.wiktionary.org/wiki/alfiere</a>), the word comes from the Spanish alférez, which in turns comes from the Arabic al-faris (knight).</p>

<p>"Schifo" is a very ancient word, used in Italian literature since the very beginning, Dante Alighieri, Francesco Petrarca, etc. It is from French "eschif" and this from Franconian "skiuh(j)an", meaning "aver riguardo", "caring".</p><p>A reference <a href="http://www.treccani.it/vocabolario/schifo1/" rel="nofollow">here</a>.</p><ul><li>Dante Alighieri (1265-1321): "mettine giù, e non ten vegna schifo, | dove Cocito la freddura serra".</li><li>Francesco Petrarca (1304-1374): "vidi … Laura mia con suoi santi atti schifi | Sedersi in parte".</li><li>Giovanni della Casa (1503-1556): "non sono da fare in presenza degli uomini le cose laide, o fetide, o schife".</li><li>Gasparo Gozzi (1713-1786): "una nuvola di zanzare molestatrici, e schife".</li><li>Giuseppe Parini (1729-1799): "e tu schifo rifuggi | Ogni vivanda".</li><li>Giacomo Leopardi (1798-1837): "le altre cose moderne che prima mi pareano squisite, mi parvero schifissime".</li><li>Giovanni Verga (1840-1922): "la ragazza … aveva a schifo poi di lavare i piatti e imbrattarsi le mani in cucina".</li><li>Italo Calvino (1923-1985): "il rospo proprio le metteva schifo".</li><li>Giovanni Testori (1923-1993): "Dài e dài, lo schifo gli distruggeva tutto, voce, sogni, allegria, forza e gli faceva venir voglia di sputar addosso a tutti e a tutto".</li></ul><p>Just for fun, try to google this: "schifo site:<a href="http://www.liberliber.it" rel="nofollow">http://www.liberliber.it</a> filetype:pdf". It returns 536 occurrences, from the most diverse contexts.</p>

<p>In the south of Italy (I'm talking about Naples especially), "Lei" is used only if you want just to be distant, not too direct. This happens when you are talking with some stranger at the same level (age, socially, etc) as you, but you have to keep in mind that it is considered not polite.</p><p>Instead, you HAVE TO use "Voi" if you are talking with someone, who, in some way, "deserves respect", for example your boss, an elder person, a police officer, parents of your spouse, a priest, etc. </p>

<p>It's clear that gestures are particularly rich in Italian's way of communication, and this is often observed by foreigners. But some of them are shared with other countries, while others seem to be more peculiar.</p><p>Is there an "official vocabulary" of Italian gestures? Can they be regarded as an addition to the spoken language?</p>
titulo: Are gestures a recognized part of the Italian language?

cuerpo: <p>Searching for "dizionario dei gesti" or similar I obtained some results (for example a book by "Caon Fabio"), but I never heard of an 'official' dictionary.</p>

<p>Lots of people share an interest, at different levels, on this topic. Some (mostly random) info from the internet:</p><ol><li><a href="http://www3.varesenews.it/italia/l-italiano-dei-gesti-lingua-conosciuta-in-tutto-il-mondo-266933.html" rel="nofollow">L'italiano "dei gesti", lingua conosciuta in tutto il mondo</a></li><li><a href="http://www.pearltrees.com/#/N-s=1_9316379&amp;N-play=0&amp;N-u=1_1525981&amp;N-p=90437631&amp;N-f=1_9316379&amp;N-fa=9315871" rel="nofollow">L'importanza dei gesti nella lingua italiana</a></li><li><a href="http://europass-blog.europass.it/parlare-senza-parole-2/" rel="nofollow">Cultura italiana – Gesti italiani: Parlare senza parole</a></li><li><a href="http://italopolis.italieaparis.net/articles/gli-italiani-parlano-con-le-mani-295/" rel="nofollow">Gli italiani parlano con le mani</a></li><li><a href="http://www.scudit.net/mdgesti3.htm" rel="nofollow">DUE PAROLE SUL LINGUAGGIO DEI GESTI</a></li><li><a href="http://www.loccidentale.it/node/127604" rel="nofollow">Perché amiamo i gesti caldi e spontanei della lingua italiana</a></li><li><a href="http://blogdisilviaspatafora.wordpress.com/2013/07/16/i-gesti-italiani-parlare-con-le-mani/" rel="nofollow">I gesti degli italiani: parlare … con le mani</a></li><li><a href="http://solima.media.unisi.it/i_gesti_delle_mani.htm" rel="nofollow">I Gesti delle Mani: al confine di  universi linguistici e limiti nella comunicazione</a></li><li><a href="http://www.eurocosm.com/eurocosm/appec/pdcd/handsignals/handsigsI.asp" rel="nofollow">Linguaggio italiano delle mani</a></li><li><a href="http://isitintercultural-it.over-blog.com/article-quando-un-gesto-vale-piu-di-mille-parole-96840941.html" rel="nofollow">Quando un gesto vale più di mille parole</a></li><li><a href="http://www.repubblica.it/cultura/2013/07/01/news/italiani_eccellenza_nel_linguaggio_dei_gesti_il_nyt_parlate_con_le_mani_come_con_la_voce-62213239/" rel="nofollow">Italiani, l'arte del linguaggio dei gesti. Il Nyt: "Parlate con le mani come con la voce"</a></li><li><a href="http://host.uniroma3.it/docenti/poggi/cursitopdf/poggipanero.pdf" rel="nofollow">LA MULTIMODALITÀ DELLA COMUNICAZIONE IN LINGUE E CULTURE DIVERSE</a></li><li><a href="http://www.google.com/url?sa=t&amp;rct=j&amp;q=&amp;esrc=s&amp;source=web&amp;cd=18&amp;cad=rja&amp;ved=0CHcQFjAHOAo&amp;url=http%3A%2F%2Fweb.hanu.vn%2Fit%2Ffile.php%2F1%2Fmoddata%2Fforum%2F15%2F3382%2FLa_comunicazione_non_verbale_ed_i_gesti_italiani.pdf&amp;ei=8ruyUpaTFYigiQfry4HwDw&amp;usg=AFQjCNE8fNcSRfNmPug0VGYYfakHNAGTqg&amp;sig2=wFMNbQVBbuz0XcYBSQ064A&amp;bvm=bv.58187178,d.dGI" rel="nofollow">LA COMUNICAZIONE NON VERBALE ED I GESTI ITALIANI</a></li><li><a href="http://lup.lub.lu.se/luur/download?func=downloadFile&amp;recordOId=1583892&amp;fileOId=1583895" rel="nofollow">La competenza passiva di gesti simbolici italiani tra studenti d’italiano presso l’Università di Lund</a></li><li><a href="http://lup.lub.lu.se/luur/download?func=downloadFile&amp;recordOId=1331449&amp;fileOId=1331450" rel="nofollow">La gestualità, forme alternative di comunicazione</a></li></ol><p>Some of the links above present a list of gestures that are considered "typically Italian". Whether or not this is a cliché I can't say. </p><p>By <a href="http://scholar.google.com/scholar?hl=en&amp;q=gestures%20italy&amp;btnG=&amp;as_sdt=1,5&amp;as_sdtp=" rel="nofollow">googling on Scholar</a> more elaborated ideas can be obtained, I don't think it would be on topic to discuss them here as the possible answers are very many and mostly subjective - and this is not a forum.</p>

<p>I always thought that <em>dimenticare</em> follows the same past forming rule as other mind verbs like <em>pensare</em> (<em>ho pensato</em>), <em>ragionare</em> (<em>ho ragionato</em>), <em>credere</em> (<em>ho creduto</em>).  </p><p>In Italy I encountered the form <em>mi sono dimenticato</em> and I was puzzled. Why is this form used? Why is it reflexive? Which one is the correct form and why?</p>
titulo: Which one is correct: "ho dimenticato" or "mi sono dimenticato"?

cuerpo: <p>"mi sono dimenticato" is not a special form of past, it's the regular past of the pronominal verb "dimenticarsi"; "dimenticare" (transitive) and "dimenticarsi" (intransitive, with "di" preposition) have usually similar meaning, but with some differences of usage.</p><blockquote>  <p>Accanto alla forma attiva, è frequente la coniug. pronominale dimenticarsi, che si costruisce sia transitivamente (per es.: mi son dimenticato il libro, mi son dimenticata la lezione), con sign. non dissimile dalla forma attiva (ho dimenticato il libro, ho dimenticato la lezione), sia intransitivamente con la prep. di, e in questo caso ha spesso sign. diverso: mi son dimenticato del libro (non mi sono ricordato di comperare, di portare, di mandare il libro); mi son dimenticato della lezione (m’è passato di mente che dovevo andare alla lezione, che era l’ora della lezione e sim.). Seguito da di e l’infinito può avere la coniug. attiva o pronominale senza diversità di sign.: ho dimenticato (o mi son dimenticato) di scrivergli; dimenticavo (o mi dimenticavo) di dirti un altro particolare.</p></blockquote><p><a href="http://www.treccani.it/vocabolario/dimenticare/" rel="nofollow">http://www.treccani.it/vocabolario/dimenticare/</a></p>

<p>Let's count in Latin from one to twenty:</p><blockquote>  <p>ūnus/ūna/ūnum, duo/duae/duo, trēs/tria, quattuor, quīnque, sex, septem, octō, novem, decem,</p>    <p>ūndecim, duodecim, tredecim, quattuordecim, quīndecim, sēdecim, septendecim, duodēvīgintī, ūndēvīgintī, vīgintī</p></blockquote><p>As pointed out by symbiotech, "octodecim" and "novemdecim" were also used in Latin, but they didn't survive. On the other hand, as pointed out by martina, "<a href="http://www.garzantilinguistica.it/ricerca/?q=diciassette" rel="nofollow">dĕcem (et) sĕptem</a>" was also a common form for "septemdĕcim".</p><p>In Attic Greek it was:</p><blockquote>  <p>ΕΙΣ/ΜΙΑ/ΕΝ (heis/mia/en), ΔΥΟ (dúō), ΤΡΕΙΣ/ΤΡΙΑ (treis/tria), ΤΕΤΤΑΡΕΣ/ΤΕΤΤΑΡΑ (téttares/téttara), ΠΕΝΤΕ (pénte), ΕΞ (héx), ΕΠΤΑ (heptá), ΟΚΤΩ (oktṓ), ΕΝΝΕΑ (ennéa), ΔΕΚΑ (déka),</p>    <p>ΕΝΔΕΚΑ (héndeka), ΔΩΔΕΚΑ (dódeka), ΤΡΕΙΣΚΑΙΔΕΚΑ (treiskaídeka), ΤΕΤΤΑΡΕΣ ΚΑΙ ΔΕΚΑ (téttares kaì déka), ΠΕΝΤΕΚΑΙΔΕΚΑ (pentekaídeka), ΕΚΚΑΙΔΕΚΑ (hekkaídeka), ΕΠΤΑΚΑΙΔΕΚΑ (heptakaídeka), ΟΚΤΩΚΑΙΔΕΚΑ (oktōkaídeka), ΕΝΝΕΑΚΑΙΔΕΚΑ (enneakaídeka), ΕΙΚΟΣΙ(Ν) (eíkosi(n))</p></blockquote><p>Now let's count in Italian</p><blockquote>  <p>uno, due, tre, quattro, cinque, sei, sette, otto, nove, dieci,</p>    <p>undici, dodici, tredici, quattordici, quindici, sedici, diciassette,  diciotto, diciannove, venti.</p></blockquote><p>But numbers from eleven to twenty could also have been, just hypothetically of course (adding accents for clarity's sake):</p><blockquote>  <p>diciùno, diciaddùe, diciattré, diciacquàttro, diciaccìnque, diciassèi, diciassètte, diciòtto, diciannòve, vénti</p></blockquote><p>or</p><blockquote>  <p>undici, dodici, tredici, quattordici, quindici, sedici, settèndici, ottòdici, novèndici, venti.</p></blockquote><p>In Spanish it is:</p><blockquote>  <p>uno, dos, tres, cuatro, cinco, seis, siete, ocho, nueve, diez,</p>    <p>once, doce, trece, catorce, quince, dieciseis, diecisiete, dieciocho, diecinueve, veinte</p></blockquote><p>In Portuguese:</p><blockquote>  <p>um, dois, três, quarto, cinco, seis, sete, oito, nove, dez,</p>    <p>onze, doze, treze, catorze, quinze, dezasseis, dezassete, dezoito, dezanove, vinte</p></blockquote><p>In French:</p><blockquote>  <p>un, deux,trois, quatre, cinq, six, sept, huit, neuf, dix,</p>    <p>onze, douze, treize, quatorze, quinze, seize, dix-sept, dix-huit, dix-neuf, vingt</p></blockquote><p>Following martina's hint here are the number words from one to twenty in Romanian:</p><blockquote>  <p>unu, doi, trei, patru, cinci, şase, şapte, opt, nouă, zece,</p>    <p>unsprezece, doisprezece, treisprezece, paisprezece, cincisprezece, şaisprezece, şaptesprezece, optsprezece, nouăsprezece, douăzeci</p></blockquote><p>I find Latin, Italian, Spanish, Portuguese and French constructions for number words bizarre and inconsistent (whereas in Romanian it seems they are perfectly consistent - thanks martina for her hint - as well as in Ancient Greek). Is there any academic work on the history of number words in Latin/Italian/Spanish/Portuguese/French where the origin of number words from eleven to nineteen is tracked down, documented, explained, discussed?</p>
titulo: Italian number words from eleven to nineteen - history of a bizarre, inconsistent construction

cuerpo: <p>There are other similar forms:</p><ul><li><p><em>mangiare</em>: <em>ho mangiato una mela</em> as opposed to <em>mi sono mangiato una mela</em></p></li><li><p><em>perdere</em>: <em>che cosa ho perso?</em> as opposed to <em>che cosa mi sono perso?</em></p></li></ul><p>Note that <em>perdersi</em> has also a reflexive meaning, like in <em>mi sono perso nel bosco</em> (I got lost in the wood). A translation of <em>che mi sono perso?</em> would be “What did I lose?”, there's no difference in English; it would be used, for instance, by someone that arrives lately to a meeting and asks what has happened before his/her arrival. Note that <em>che cosa ho perso?</em> would sound rather strange in this context.</p><p>The form <em>mi sono mangiato una mela</em> used to be frown upon in schools, but it's legitimate Italian and conveys a different idea about <em>why</em> I ate an apple.</p><ul><li><p><em>ho mangiato una mela</em> just states the fact,</p></li><li><p><em>mi sono mangiato una mela</em> can mean that I <em>wanted</em> to eat an apple or that I was quite satisfied in eating it.</p></li></ul><p>A similar difference is between <em>ho dimenticato</em> and <em>mi sono dimenticato</em>: the former is ‘objective’, while the latter is ‘subjective’. For <em>dimenticare/dimenticarsi</em> the difference is not so great as for <em>mangiare/mangiarsi</em>. In any case, the medial form (not to be confused with the reflexive, although they share the conjugation) puts greater emphasis on the subject than on the object.</p>

<p>I found a <a href="http://forum.wordreference.com/showthread.php?t=2422247" rel="nofollow">similar question</a>, where this is suggested by user CapnPrep as a possible answer:</p><blockquote>  <p>Octodecim and novendecim/novemdecim do exist, although they are not  the preferred forms in Classical Latin. I think the explanation is the  same as why one might prefer to say  "ten to six, quarter to six"  instead of "five fifty, three quarters after five". Or if you're 19  years old,you might prefer to say "I'm almost 20" instead of   "I'm in  my teens". When you get close to the next round number, it is natural  to use it as the new reference point, in anticipation.</p></blockquote><p>My only addition to his answer, since in Latin this happens only with 18, 19 numbers, is that it can be related to the age of maturation, the age when a young man was enrolled in the army. In the days before Augustus this was 16 years, but after his rule the age of enrollment was increased to 18. So maybe this way of mentioning 18 as "20 without 2" was some sort of suggestion "that you are mature enough now", "you are considered a man" etc.</p>

<p>How come the feminine sounding suffix <em>-ista</em> is used for referring jobs such as <em>autista</em>, <em>commercialista</em>, <em>economista</em>, <em>giurista</em>, and <em>apprendista</em>?</p><p>I think that when the words for these jobs were originally created, they were predominantly practiced by man. Is it considered a grammatical mistake to use <em>commercialisto</em>, <em>economisto</em>, or <em>giuristo</em> etc when referring to a male practicing that job?</p>
titulo: Why was the "-ista" suffix used for traditionally male jobs? Is it correct to use "-isto" variant?

cuerpo: <p>Not everything that ends with -a is feminine and not everything that ends with -o is masculine, so don't get mislead by that. The suffix -ista is neuter, it's valid for both sexes and this means that, of course, *economisto and *giuristo are not valid words.</p><p>The suffix comes from Latin <em>-ista(m)</em>, which in turn comes from the Greek <em>-istḗs</em>. It is called <em>agentivo</em> in Italian, and it is used for all types of jobs, some examples are those you listed.</p><p>If you can understand some Italian, you could check <a href="http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/suffissi_%28Enciclopedia_dell%27Italiano%29/">Suffissi</a> and <a href="http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/nomi-denominali_%28Enciclopedia_dell%27Italiano%29/">Nomi denominali</a> in the Treccani site.</p>

<p>I heard a few times the use of the suffix <em>-issimo/issima</em> with substantives and couldn't find an immediate appropriate translation, so I thought it must be metaphorical way of speaking. I don't remember many examples, but recently I stumbled upon the <em>in gambissima</em> expression. Is it grammatically correct to attach the suffix to substantives in some cases? Are there any other examples of this practice?</p>
titulo: Is it correct to attach the superlative suffix to substantives? Like "in gambissima"?

cuerpo: <p>In the past we had <em>il campionissimo</em>, that is, Fausto Coppi. He was so good in cycling that calling him <em>campione</em> was too reductive. Probably the term was coined under the influence of <em>il generalissimo Franco</em> (taken from Spanish, of course).</p><p>Such a usage of the superlative with nouns rather than adjectives has its roots in sport journalism, where people is often in search for astonishing words.</p><p>The phrase <em>in gambissima</em> is a joke for saying that someone is <em>in gamba</em>, that is, in good health (or, by extension, good in something) at a very high grade. So it is the superlative of an an adverb, which is not so uncommon, actually, for instance <em>benissimo</em> and <em>malissimo</em>.</p><p>Thus <em>sta benissimo</em> can become <em>è in gambissima</em>.</p>

<p>Non so se si possa generalizzare, e forse ci sono differenze regionali d'uso, ma ho l'impressione che 'nulla' sia più determinativo di 'niente'.</p><p>Per esempio, ritenete che la frase 'non ho nulla da dire' abbia lo stesso significato di 'non ho niente da dire'?</p><p>Oppure ritenete che con 'nulla' si esprima una completa chiusura dell'argomento, mentre con 'niente' il parlante lasci la possibilità di un'ulteriore interlocuzione? </p>
titulo: 'nulla' vs. 'niente'

cuerpo: <p>Nel contesto indicato nella domanda, non c'è differenza tra "nulla" e "niente". In tutti e due i casi, chi scrive (o dice) quelle frasi intende che non c'è niente che debba dire; niente è detto (anche implicitamente) a proposito di quanto la stessa persona possa dire in futuro.</p><p>Generalmente parlando, "nulla" è usato in contesti dove "niente" non è usato; per esempio, parlando del concetto filosofico, la frase usata è "il nulla".</p>

<p>È possibile utilizzare  i punti di sospensione "…" per omettere di scrivere l'intero elenco di elementi di un insieme? Utilizzarli in pratica al posto di locuzione come <strong>"etc. etc."</strong>. Non trovo molti riferimenti a riguardo nelle grammatiche.  Quale delle seguenti opzioni è la più corretta?</p><p>Con lo spazio:</p><blockquote>  <p>i quadrupedi (cani, gatti, cavalli …) </p></blockquote><p>Senza spazio:</p><blockquote>  <p>i quadrupedi (cani, gatti, cavalli…)</p></blockquote><p>Con la virgola:</p><blockquote>  <p>i quadrupedi (cani, gatti, … )</p></blockquote>
titulo: Punti di sospensione per un elenco: come utilizzarli in italiano

cuerpo: <p>"Nulla" e "niente" hanno il medesimo significato, tuttavia è vero che "nulla" sia percepibile come di peso differente e farei risalire il ciò sia ai differenti domini in cui "nulla" rimane maggiormente usato dando la sfumatura di 'vuoto', come dice @kiamlaluno, quali la filosofia e la letteratura, sia all'uso maggiore che "Niente" pare avere nelle espressioni gergali e comunque non formali (forse questa seconda motivazione è probabilmente correlata alla prima)</p>

<p>Sì se la progressione è identificabile dai primi elementi esplicitati. Inoltre andrebbe ripetuto il separatore di interpunzione (nel tuo caso la virgola) dopo l'ultimo elemento e di conseguenza esso dovrebbe essere seguito da uno spazio.</p><p>Quindi </p><pre><code>i quadrupedi (cani, gatti, … )</code></pre><p>è la forma corretta (anche se quei soli due elementi dell'elenco non mi paiono così rappresentativi della classe quadrupedi)</p>

<p>Bice Mortara Garavelli nel suo <em>Prontuario di punteggiatura</em>, Laterza 2003 (pag. 113) descrive tra gli usi dei puntini di sospensione quello di “far capire che un elenco può continuare indefinitamente (il loro valore è quello di <em>eccetera</em> e di espressioni consimili)” e quindi il loro uso è senz'altro ammissibile. Non fa esempi di questo uso specifico, ma visto che lo fa rientrare nel discorso generale dei possibili usi dei puntini di sospensione, evidentemente anche qui vanno usati come in tutti gli altri casi, e cioè senza lo spazio prima...</p><hr><p>Aggiungo che oggi ho sfogliato in libreria il libro di Simone Fornara <em>La punteggiatura</em> (Carocci 2010) e lì trovo che in un esempio di elenco con i puntini mette la virgola seguita dai puntini senza spazio.</p><p>Nel complesso deduco che la norma non sia unica, forse perché l'uso dei puntini di sospensione per generalizzare un elenco è più recente e informale e meno “canonico” dell'etc. e simili, e quindi non ha un trattamento univoco.</p>
<p>Is there a difference in context or connotation between the verbs 'vuotare' and 'svuotare', both meaning 'to empty'?</p>
titulo: Difference between 'vuotare' and 'svuotare'

cuerpo: <p>The verbs 'vuotare' and 'svuotare' indicate the same action and can be used both to define the action of emptying something, or in figurative sense (i.e. <em>In estate la città si svuota / vuota</em>)</p><p><a href="http://www.treccani.it/vocabolario/svuotare/" rel="nofollow">Here</a> you can find a definition of 'svuotare'. <a href="http://www.treccani.it/vocabolario/vuotare/" rel="nofollow">Here</a> you can find a definition of 'vuotare'.</p>
<p>In my experience (native language speaker) <em>svuotare</em> is a bit stronger and less technical. Also, the initial 's' sounds almost onomatopoeic, giving a definite emphasis.</p>
<p>Does anyone have a clue about the origin of the saying: "Donna barbuta, sempre piaciuta" and what its real meaning is? </p>
titulo: Origin and meaning of the saying "Donna barbuta, sempre piaciuta"

cuerpo: <p>It's probably just a proverb used to comfort some woman that does have "a problem" with excessive facial hair. Note that some people use a slightly different version: <em>donna baffuta, sempre piaciuta</em>, which seems to support this view, since that's usually where some women might have "excessive facial hair". The <a href="http://it.wiktionary.org/wiki/donna">wiktionary</a> gives this explanation and I cannot think of anything else.</p><p>However saying it is surely poor taste.</p>

<p>When uttered by a woman, which of the following sentences is correct?</p><blockquote>  <p>Non riesco a camminare dritta.</p></blockquote><blockquote>  <p>Non riesco a camminare dritto.</p></blockquote><p>My feeling is that, since <em>dritto</em> is the way of walking (in a straight line), that is what should be used, not <em>dritta</em>.</p>
titulo: "Non riesco a camminare dritta" versus "non riesco a camminare dritto"

cuerpo: <blockquote>  <p>Non riesco a camminare <em>dritta</em></p></blockquote><p>significa che non sta con la schiena dritta, si tratta di un predicativo del soggetto e l'aggettivo si concorda in genere e numero col soggetto, come sempre.</p><blockquote>  <p>Non riesco a camminare <em>dritto</em></p></blockquote><p>significa invece che non riesce a camminare tenendo una direzione che non si curvi. Qui "dritto" è un avverbio di modo, non modificabile.</p>

<p>They are both correct, and they are both used in common speaking. The main difference between these two forms is that with <em>ho dimenticato</em> you emphasize the object (what I forgot), instead <em>mi sono dimenticato</em> puts the emphasis on the subject (me).</p><p>So, for example, you will say <em>"Scusa mi sono dimenticato dell'appuntamento"</em> because you want to highlight that you forgot the meeting. In the other hand, you will say <em>"Ho dimenticato l'appuntamento e ora devo chiedere scusa"</em>, in this case you emphasize the cause, why you will have to apologize.</p><p>Event thought, they are both used, and also in my examples both forms can fit.</p>

<p>I observed that Italian journalists use to coin new words using the suffix '-poli', as in <em>tangentopoli</em>, <em>sanitopoli</em>, <em>concorsopoli</em> and so on.</p><p>I cannot think of a case in which those new words, which are conied day-by-day in reference to limitless cases of corruction, have a positive connotation.</p><p>So my question is: Is it possible that Italian journalists use those <em>poli</em>-words evoking, etymologically, a parallel with the Disney's Paperopoli? If not, can anyone explain what the origin of this 'poli' is?</p>
titulo: 'tangentopoli', 'concorsopoli', 'sanitopoli', and so on

cuerpo: <p><a href="http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/poli_%28La-grammatica-italiana%29/" rel="nofollow"><em>-poli</em> is</a> a <a href="http://www.treccani.it/vocabolario/suffissoide/" rel="nofollow">suffixoid</a>; it comes from Greek <em>polis</em> (<em>city</em>), and it is used as a suffix: <em>baraccopoli</em> (city of slums), <em>tangentopoli</em> (city of corruption), etc.</p><p>Actually <em>Paperopoli</em> is a good example of a positive use of the suffix <em>-poli</em>, although this is <a href="http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/poli_%28La-grammatica-italiana%29/" rel="nofollow">generally</a> used to coin terms of negative connotation.</p><p><em>Fonopoli</em>, the name of Renato Zero's project, is another case where <em>-poli</em> is used to coin a positive connotation word.</p><p>Other words without a negative connotation are: <em>metropoli</em>, <em>acropoli</em>, <em>necropoli</em>, <em>cosmopoli</em>, <em>megalopoli</em>.</p>

<p>This <em>-poli</em> device was born when the “Tangentopoli” scandal was at its beginnings in 1992, when Milan was considered “the city of bribes.” After that, almost every scandal was boringly named with a <em>-poli</em> suffix.</p><p>The suffix has been used in the past, as witnessed by <em>Constantinopolis</em> (Greek <em>Κωνσταντινούπολις</em>), the town founded by emperor Constantine near <em>Byzantium</em> (Greek <em>Βυζάντιον</em>), currently İstanbul, Turkey. The Italian translation <em>Paperopoli</em> of Disney's Duckburg came quite late and with many models from the past.</p>
<p>It's worth to mention <em>non è proprio una cima</em>, a popular and sarcastic way to say <em>he/she is quite an idiot</em>.</p>

<p>It is referred to the past when women could not shave themselves (aside the rich ones). In those circumstances this sentence was used to comfort this kind of unappeal (even if in these days thrends seem to revert :) )</p>
