<p>The past participle used with <em>avere</em> and the <em>passato prossimo</em> as tense doesn't change basing on the gender and the plurality. You say <em>ho messo a posto il frullatore</em> and <em>ho messo a posto i temperini nel cassetto</em>.</p><p>Since there is <em>li</em>, the past participle is declinated basing on the plurality of the object.</p>

<p>Are <em>accordo</em> and <em>intesa</em> perfect synonyms, or are there cases where one is used instead of the other one? For example, in the following sentences, could I replace <em>accordo</em> with <em>intesa</em>?</p><blockquote>  <p>Abbiamo firmato un accordo per mantenere la proprietà degli immobili in Via Marconi.</p></blockquote><blockquote>  <p>C'è un accordo tra di noi: non faccio concorrenza a te se tu non fai concorrenza a me.</p></blockquote><blockquote>  <p>Siamo d'accordo: domani firmiamo il contratto di locazione.</p></blockquote>
titulo: "Accordo" versus "intesa"

cuerpo: <p>In American English, the following sentences correctly use the punctuation.</p><blockquote>  <p>She told me "Don't talk to me like that!"</p></blockquote><blockquote>  <p>She told me "I love you."</p></blockquote><blockquote>  <p>When I hear "she is coming," I run in the opposite direction.</p></blockquote><p>How would the translation in Italian of those sentences use the punctuation? In particular:</p><ul><li>Should I add a period after the quote in the first example?</li><li>Is it correct to put the period inside the quote as in the second example?</li><li>Does the comma in the third example go inside or outside the quote?</li></ul>
titulo: Punctuation inside quotes

cuerpo: <p><em>Accordo</em> and <em>intesa</em> do overlap in meaning when used as “agreement”, though <em>accordo</em> is used more regarding to opinions and intentions and <em>intesa</em> with ideas and sentiments [from Sabatini Coletti dictionary]. They also have other meanings which do not overlap — for example, <em>accordo</em> can mean “chord” and <em>intesa</em> can mean “harmony” (between persons).</p><p>In the first two of your examples, <em>accordo</em> is used as synonim of “contract” and “pact” respectively, and as such can not be substituted with <em>intesa</em>.</p><p>In the last example, one could use <em>intesa</em>, though the form would need to be changed slightly (“abbiamo un’intesa”).</p>

<p>In the same order:</p><ul><li>It depends (different Italian publishers have different rules for this; I think I can quote sources for both uses).</li><li><p>No (but even here there is not a universal consensus). I'd write:</p><blockquote>  <p>Mi disse “Ti amo”.</p></blockquote><p>But if a whole sentence or sequence of sentences are within quotes, the final period should be within as well (just like for brackets).</p></li><li>Outside, definitely.</li></ul>

<p>They are synonyms, indeed, and sometimes <em>accordo</em> could be replaced with <em>intesa</em>. The meaning could shift, however:  </p><ul><li><em>Abbiamo firmato l'accordo</em> means usually the final agreement, while <em>Abbiamo firmato l'intesa</em> can mean also the protocol of intentions.</li><li><em>C'è un accordo tra di noi</em> - we always do something in this way, <em>C'è un intesa tra noi</em> - we are on the same page or we have good relations (including working relations).</li><li><em>Siamo d'accordo</em> - we have agreed upon it, <em>Siamo d'intesa</em> - we have agreed how we do it.</li></ul><p>There are some more examples <a href="http://www.treccani.it/vocabolario/intesa/" rel="nofollow">here</a>.</p>

<p>Quoted from 'Pinocchio' by Collodi:</p><blockquote>  <p>Fatto sta che i tre torsoli, <strong>invece di</strong> essere gettati fuori dalla finestra, vennero posati sull'angolo della tavola in ...</p></blockquote><p>Please, explain why Collodi uses <strong>invece di</strong> rather than 'invece che' vs. 'piuttosto di' vs. 'piuttosto che' and clarify whether these expressions, in that context, are interchangeable or not. </p>
titulo: 'invece di' vs. 'invece che' vs. 'piuttosto di' vs. 'piuttosto che'

cuerpo: <p>In Italian, like in many other languages, many words are obtained by putting together two other words (noun, adjectives, verbs). For example, "capostazione" (stationmaster) is the person which is "the master of the station" (a capo della stazione). Pluralization of such name may be sometimes tricky: for example, the plural of "capostazione" is "capistazione". Is there a rule of thumb?</p>
titulo: Plural of compound names

cuerpo: <p>I'm unsure when I should say</p><blockquote>  <p>'mi <strong><em>dà</em></strong> due etti di mortadella'</p></blockquote><p>or</p><blockquote>  <p>'mi <strong><em>dai</em></strong> due etti di mortadella'</p></blockquote><p>.</p><p>Can anyone explain what the difference between using 'dà' and using 'dai' is?</p>
titulo: 'mi dà due etti di mortadella' vs. 'mi dai due etti di mortadella'

cuerpo: <p>Both pairs are interchangeable, that is</p><ul><li><em>invece di</em> is equivalent to <em>invece che</em> (the former is more common, <a href="http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/invece-di-o-invece-che_%28La_grammatica_italiana%29/">La grammatica italiana</a>) </li><li><em>piuttosto di</em> is equivalent to <em>piuttosto che</em> (the latter is more common, while the former is mainly used in the phrases such as "Piuttosto di niente, è meglio piuttosto!" - "Better anything than nothing," <a href="http://www.grandidizionari.it/Dizionario_Italiano/parola/p/piuttosto.aspx?query=piuttosto">Grande dizionario italiano</a>)</li></ul>

<p>Short answer: If the grocer is a friend or you intend to be quite friendly, use “dai”, else use “dà”.</p><p>Slightly longer answer: In Italian there are two main ways of addressing other people. With relatives, friends and, in some cases, same-age or same-profession people, you use second-person “tu” (roughly corresponding to being on first-name terms); with strangers, you tend to use third-person “lei” (or, more formally, “Lei”). It is roughly parallel to French “tu” and “vous”, if this helps.</p><p>In your case, “dai” is the second person of “dare”, so you are treating the grocer with familiarity, while “dà” is the third person, and you are keeping your distance.</p>

<p>It depends on whether you address another person in a formal (<em>lei</em>) or informal (<em>tu</em>) way.<br><em>Mi dà</em> - you ask in third person (<em><strong>lei</strong> mi dà qualcosa</em>), which means you assume all formalities are in place.<em>Mi dai</em> - you ask in second person (<em><strong>tu</strong> mi dai qualcosa</em>), as if you were equal or even friends.</p>

<p>Should one prefer <em>«…»</em>, <em>&ldquo;…&rdquo;</em> or <em>&lsquo;…&rsquo;</em>?</p><p>I.e., suppose one has to write reported speech, which one one should choice or prefer, 1., 2. or 3.?</p><ol><li>Qualcuno disse «Eppur si muove!»</li><li>Qualcuno disse &ldquo;Eppur si muove!&rdquo;</li><li>Qualcuno disse &lsquo;Eppur si muove!&rsquo;</li></ol>
titulo: Should one prefer «…», “…” or ‘…’?

cuerpo: <blockquote>  <p>Giulietta: «Quale devo dare?» </p>    <p>a) Romeo: «Dà questa».</p>    <p>b) Romeo: «Da' questa».</p></blockquote><p>Which one is grammatical, a) or b)?</p><p>As far as I can tell in "Da' questa" "Da'" is different from "Dà" because it is the contracted form of "Dai". Am I right?</p>
titulo: Is 'Dà questa' correct, or should it be 'Da' questa'?

cuerpo: <p>The guillemet (<em>«&hellip;»</em>) is the traditional quotation mark used in Italian, but it has been nowadays replaced from the double quotes (<em>&ldquo;&hellip;&rdquo;</em>). The single quotation marks (<em>&lsquo;&hellip;&rsquo;</em>) are used for nested quotations.</p><p>Depending on the newspaper, you could still see the guillemet being used for quotations.</p><h3>Reference</h3><ul><li><a href="http://italian.about.com/od/grammar/a/aa101508a.htm" rel="nofollow">Use of Italian Quotation Marks</a></li></ul>

<p>Yes, you are right. With clearer subjects:</p><ul><li><em>Dà</em> is the third singular person of the indicative mood.</li></ul><blockquote>  <p>“Giulietta dà questa”</p></blockquote><ul><li><em>da'</em> is the second singular person of the imperative mood.</li></ul><blockquote>  <p>“[Giulietta,] da' questa!”</p></blockquote><p>The second form is correct. </p><p>To disambiguate, since “[Giulietta] dà questa a lui” can be a valid sentence with a different meaning and we might not have the context of the conversation, and since apostrophes and accents are (sadly) often confused, using an exclamation mark for the imperative modes might help.</p>

<p><em>Da'</em> is the short form for <em>dai</em>, and it is used only in Tuscan, or literary.<br><em>Dai</em> is the second singular person for the <em>modo indicativo, tempo presente</em>  and the <em>modo imperativo</em> (or <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jussive" rel="nofollow"><em>jussive mood</em></a>); <em>dà</em> is the third singular person for the <em>modo indicativo, tempo presente</em>. The accent is required to avoid confusion with <em>da</em>, the preposition.</p><h3>Reference</h3><ul><li><a href="http://www.wordreference.com/conj/itverbs.aspx?v=dare" rel="nofollow">Coniugazione di dare</a></li></ul>

<p>So, there are some specific rules according to how the compound noun is created.</p><p><a href="http://dizionari.corriere.it/dizionario-si-dice/P/plurale-dei-nomi-composti.shtml" rel="nofollow">This source</a>, from the dictionary of one of the most important italian newspapers, lists them. In the following, <em>adj</em> stays for "adjective", <em>v</em> for verb, <em>adv</em> for adverb, <em>prep</em> for preposition and <em>sub</em> for "substantive".</p><ol><li>Nouns composed as <em>adj + sub</em> make the plural pluralizing only the second;</li><li>Nouns composed as <em>adj + adj</em> make the plural pluralizing only the second; </li><li>Nouns composed as <em>sub + adj</em> make the plural pluralizing both;</li><li>Nouns composed as <em>sub + sub</em> of the same gender make the plural pluralizing only the second;</li><li>Nouns composed as <em>sub + sub</em> of different gender make the plural pluralizing only the first;</li><li>Nouns composed as <em>v + plural sub</em> make the plural without any change;</li><li>Nouns composed as <em>v + singular masculine sub</em> make the plural pluralizing only the second;</li><li>Nouns composed as <em>v + singular feminine sub</em> make the plural without any change;</li><li>Nouns composed as <em>v + v</em> make the plural without any change;</li><li>Nouns composed as <em>adv or prep + sub</em> make the plural pluralizing the noun if the composite has the same gender of the component and without any change in the opposite case.</li></ol><p>Please note that the composite noun may change gender with respect to the component nouns/noun.</p><p>Moreover, there are exceptions to the rules. The cited source reports plenty of examples of rules and exceptions.</p><p>I report some examples here, in the same order used in the list above. The first column is the singular, the second is the plural.</p><ol><li>bassorilievo --- bassorilievi</li><li>bassofondo --- bassifondi</li><li>terracotta --- terrecotte</li><li>pescecane --- pescecani</li><li>pescespada --- pescispada</li><li>portapenne --- portapenne</li><li>copricapo --- copricapi</li><li>posacenere --- posacenere</li><li>saliscendi --- saliscendi</li><li>A. sottufficiale --- sottufficiali / B. sottoscala --- sottoscala</li></ol><p>Remember, there are unfortunately plenty of exceptions. We natives apply them without even knowing them, as in other cases. Do not be afraid of making mistakes, you can be sure only if you meet the word as many times as you need to learn it along with its plural.</p>

<p>Is the pluralization of Latin words accepted or even correct, unlike the pluralization of those coming from other languages?</p><p>For example, "<em>sono stato in due bars</em>" would sound odd in Italian, but it's quite common to hear someone correcting somebody else for saying "<em>i curriculum</em>" instead of "<em>i curricula</em>" (the correct Latin pluralization for this noun).</p><p>Is this addressed by any linguistic reference? Is it more of a cultural issue instead?</p>
titulo: Pluralization of Latin words

cuerpo: <p>Nowadays there is not a fixed rule. I translate into Italian for several publishers and journals, and the guidelines are about equally divided among those prescribing «&hellip;» and those prescribing “&hellip;”. Single quotes, on the other hand, are almost always reserved for quotes within quotes and the like.</p>

<p>No, pluralization of the Latin words, as well as any other foreign words is generally not accepted in Italian (e.g., memorandum, referendum). <em>Il curriculum/i curricula</em> makes a famous exception (see <a href="http://www.accademiadellacrusca.it/it/lingua-italiana/consulenza-linguistica/domande-risposte/plurale-curriculum">Accademia della Crusca</a>); though, there are some modern dictionaries that suggest <em>i curriculum</em>.</p><p>From La Grammatica Italiana di Dardano e Trifone (Zanichelli, 1995, p. 194): </p><blockquote>  <p>«Le grammatiche e i dizionari sono abbastanza compatti nel consigliare  il mantenimento della forma del singolare anche al plurale».<br>  The  grammar rules and dictionaries unitedly recommend keeping the singular  form also as plural.</p></blockquote><p>Italiano di Serianni (Garzanti, 1997, p. 106): </p><blockquote>  <p>«In che modo formano il plurale i nomi stranieri terminanti in  consonante? In generale, il nome resta invariato»<br>  What is a plural  form of the foreign words ending with a consonant? Generally speaking,  the word remains unchanged.</p></blockquote><p>Italiano, Corso di sopravvivenza di Birattari (Ponte alle Grazie, 2000, p. 250):</p><blockquote>  <p>Vale per le parole latine quel che si è detto per le parole straniere  in generale: in italiano sono invariabili. Quindi il plurale di  curriculum è i curriculum.<br>  What is said above is valid for the Latin words in the same way as for other foreign words: in Italian, they don't change. Thus, the plural form of curriculum is i curriculum.</p></blockquote>

<p>I agree that the two forms are interchangeable.</p><p>Moreover, at least according to <a href="http://goo.gl/p7JHWQ" rel="nofollow">Google nGram</a>, <em>invece di</em> was more common during Collodi's times compared to <em>piuttosto che</em>.</p><p>I would generally avoid the usage of <em>piuttosto di</em> altogether (aside from the specific example cited by @I.M. and possibly a few more).</p>

<p>I would say to use «&hellip;» when reporting a direct speech or a dialogue, while &ldquo;&hellip;&rdquo; when reporting an indirect one. </p><p>You usually find «&hellip;» in Italian books, while &ldquo;&hellip;&rdquo; is very often used in newspapers when using someone else's textual words thoughts in the writer arguments.</p><p>I give you two examples:</p><ol><li><p><strong>Novel style</strong></p><blockquote>  <p><em>Disse Galileo uscendo di prigione: «Eppur si muove!». «Non dica fesserie!», rispose il Papa.</em></p></blockquote></li><li><p><strong>Newspaper style</strong></p><blockquote>  <p><em>Il ministro dell'economia Saccomanni afferma che &ldquo;abbiamo bisogno di ridurre il deficit&rdquo; al fine di &ldquo;rilanciare la crescita della nostra economia&rdquo;.</em></p></blockquote></li></ol><p>In this last case the words between &ldquo;&hellip;&rdquo; could have been said during an interview of minister Saccomanni, but used by the journalist in a condensed form fitting its article.</p>

<p>My dictionary translates 'magari' as 'maybe'. However, I know that it can be used as interjection to mean something like "I wish!". My question is, when it's used in a sentence like this:</p><blockquote>  <p>Magari ci vediamo stasera</p></blockquote><p>Is does this mean "maybe we'll see each other tonight" or does it mean "hopefully we'll see each other tonight"? Or is it somewhere <em>between</em> 'maybe' and 'hopefully'?</p>
titulo: Meaning of "magari"

cuerpo: <p>It can mean both as you correctly say and it is open to interpretation, it's hard to answer your question out of a specific context. This phenomenon happens in other languages as well. Just know that it does have a double meaning and try to understand what's being said given your specific context.</p>

<p>I've noticed in some Italian TV shows that, especially when the characters announce themselves, they don't say:</p><p><strong>io sono [Title] [Name]</strong></p><p>but rather</p><p><strong>[Title] [Name] sono</strong></p><p>I've seen this kind of reversal in other languages, too, but it has very limited contexts, in which it can be said, and is usually meant for emphasis. Is this the case for Italian and is this kind of reversal widely used (for essere and other verbs)?</p>
titulo: When is it appropriate to move "sono" and other verbs to the end?

cuerpo: <p>When talking about “Italian TV shows”, are you perchance referring to <em>Commissario Montalbano</em>?<br>This kind of reversal is very common in the sicilian dialect (and possibly others), but otherwise considered incorrect.</p>

<p>It means <em>I wish</em> when it is used as exclamation.</p><blockquote>  <p><strong>A</strong>: Vuoi che ti accompagni?<br>  <strong>B</strong>: Magari!</p></blockquote><p>It has that meaning in a sentence using the subjunctive mood too.</p><blockquote>  <p>Magari potessi venire anche io al concerto!</p></blockquote><blockquote>  <p>Magari fosse vero che sono fidanzato con Veronica!</p></blockquote><blockquote>  <p>Magari non fosse venuta alla festa! Mi ha fatto litigare con la mia ragazza, che se ne è andata prima che potessi darle il regalo.</p></blockquote><p>When used with the Simple Present and the Simple Past, it normally means <em>maybe</em>, <em>possibly</em>.</p><blockquote>  <p>Magari non sapeva niente.</p></blockquote><blockquote>  <p>Magari non è stato avvisato in tempo.</p></blockquote><blockquote>  <p>Magari è solo in ritardo.</p></blockquote><p>Notice that you could read <em>Magari non c'ero!</em> instead of <em>Magari non ci fossi stato</em>, but in both the cases it  means "I wish I was not there." As in English, the subjunctive mood is often replaced from the indicative mood, at least colloquially.<br>In that case, the difference is made from the intonation.</p>
<p>It is correct to say</p><p><em>Io sono [Title] [Name]</em></p><p>or</p><p><em>Sono [Title] [Name]</em></p><p>The other form is a Sicilian dialect expression.</p>

<p>When do you suggest to use dimenticare and when scordare? Is dimenticare only for reasonings or also valid for people?</p><p>E.g.</p><blockquote>  <p>Avevo dimenticato il tuo viso</p>    <p>Avevo scordato il tuo viso</p></blockquote><p>Secondo voi?</p>
titulo: Difference between "scordare" and "dimenticare"

cuerpo: <p>You can use them both interchangeably, they basically mean the same thing, although <em>scordare</em> may also be referred to an instrument that is out of tune.</p><p>Despite the fact that people believe <em>scodare</em> is less formal than <em>dimenticare</em>, it is not in fact exclusively part of any regional vocabulary and each region applies its own peculiarities to this verb when in use.</p><p>For further reading on this matter, please <a href="http://www.accademiadellacrusca.it/it/lingua-italiana/consulenza-linguistica/domande-risposte/scordare-dimenticare">refer to this page</a> on the <a href="http://www.accademiadellacrusca.it/it">Accademia della Crusca</a> website.</p>

<p>Yes, they have the same meaning and both could be used in your examples.<br>Nonetheless, there is a little difference in the meaning due to their Latin origins.</p><ul><li><em>dimenticare</em> comes from the word <em>mens, mentis</em> (mind) with the prefix <em>de-</em> (distance). To forget something would be <em>to get it out of one's mind</em>.</li><li><em>scordare</em> comes from the word <em>cor</em> (heart) with the prefix <em>s-</em> (meaning again distance or cancellation). To forget something would be <em>to get it out of one's heart</em>.</li></ul><p>That's why you can say <em>ho dimenticato/scordato il tuo viso</em> but you would usually say <em>il primo amore non si scorda mai</em>.</p>

<blockquote>  <p>Si tratta di oggetti <strong>alquanto</strong> strani.</p></blockquote><blockquote>  <p>Si tratta di oggetti <strong>parecchio</strong> strani.</p></blockquote><p>Does <em>alquanto</em> refer to a less, equal or greater quantity in comparison to <em>parecchio</em>?</p><p>Are the objects in the first sentence less, equal or more strange than the objects in the second one?</p>
titulo: Does "alquanto" express a greater quantity than "parecchio"?

cuerpo: <p>The meaning overlaps out of a great deal, but <em>alquanto</em> would refer to a slightly smaller quantity with respect to <em>parecchio</em>.</p><p>So,</p><ul><li><strong>Alquanto + adjective</strong> describes a value in the middle of the adjective, tending to it;</li><li><strong>Parecchio + adjective</strong> is a stronger assessment, which can be translated with "very + adjective".</li></ul>

<p>When used as adjective, <em>alquanto</em> could mean that something is less than <em>parecchio</em>, or it is equivalent to <em>parecchio</em>.</p><blockquote>  <p>Aveva bevuto alquanto vino.</p></blockquote><p>As adverb, it means <em>parecchio, non poco</em>; as undefined pronoun, it means <em>un po'</em>.</p><blockquote>  <p>Oggi sto alquanto meglio.</p></blockquote><blockquote>  <p>Con alquanto di buon vino e di confetto il riconfortò. —G. Boccaccio</p></blockquote>

<p>From the <a href="http://www.accademiadellacrusca.it/it/lingua-italiana/consulenza-linguistica/domande-risposte/avverbi-quantit" rel="nofollow">Accademia della Crusca explanation</a>:</p><blockquote>  <p>le forme <em>abbastanza, alquanto e piuttosto</em> risultano sinonimiche, in  quanto si definiscono reciprocamente.   La tendenza al rafforzamento  semantico si può inoltre notare nella forma <em>alquanto</em>, derivata dal  latino <em>aliquăntu(m)</em> che indicava una quantità discreta, spesso  traducibile in italiano con <em>un po'</em>. Il Dizionario Etimologico della  Lingua Italiana definisce infatti il valore avverbiale di questa forma  con «un poco», osservando nella sezione etimologica: «Alquanto nel  sign. di 'molto' è errore biasimato dal G. Gherardini, Voci italiane  ammissibili benché proscritte dall'elenco del sig. Bernardoni (Milano,  1812).   Considerando che il Grande dizionario italiano dell'uso  impiega il termine <em>parecchio</em> per definire questa forma avverbiale, è  quindi possibile ipotizzarne l'uso in senso intensivo, specie per  rafforzare un aggettivo (ad es.: "ti vedo alquanto stanco" =  'parecchio, molto stanco').</p></blockquote><p>To sum up: The words <em>abbastanza, alquanto, parecchio, piuttosto</em> are synonyms and could be used to define each other. However, the etymology of <em>alquanto</em> (from the Latin word, meaning "un po' - few, a small quantity") makes it closer to <em>abbastanza</em> rather than to <em>tanto</em>.<br>At the same time, <em>parecchio</em> is usually defined as "a bit less than a lot":</p><blockquote>  <p><strong>Parecchio</strong> C’è parecchia, anzi molta confusione intorno a questa voce. E quando si è detto <em>parecchia anzi molta</em> si è già spiegato tutto o quasi tutto. Al pari di <em>assai</em> (e non mettiamo nel mucchio altra roba come <em>abbastanza</em>, sennò facciamo soltanto confusione), <em>parecchio è meno di molto, equivale a piú che sufficiente, in quantità notevole, ma non è ancora molto</em> (Scrivendo e parlando di  Luciano Satta, Firenze, Sansoni, 1988, p. 177)</p></blockquote>

<p>I'd translate the two sentences as</p><blockquote>  <p>Si tratta di oggetti <strong>alquanto</strong> strani<br>  <em>We are talking about <strong>rather</strong> strange objects</em></p></blockquote><p>and </p><blockquote>  <p>Si tratta di oggetti <strong>parecchio</strong> strani<br>  <em>We are talking about <strong>very</strong> strange objects</em></p></blockquote><p>So, <strong>parecchio</strong> is stronger than <strong>alquanto</strong> and it literally indicates a bigger quantity.</p><p>That being said, as a native speaker I would never use <strong>alquanto</strong> in a sentence, as it doesn't sound very colloquial. I'd go with <strong>un po'</strong>, which could be roughly translated to English as <strong>a little</strong>.</p>

<p>I often hear people saying "due euro", even if "due euri" should be used.</p><p>Can anyone explain which one is correct, maybe adding a comment in reference to the differences in regional usage?</p>
titulo: "due euro" vs. "due euri"

cuerpo: <p>In English, the following sentences have a different meaning.</p><blockquote>  <p>If I were rich, I would live on Long Island.</p></blockquote><blockquote>  <p>If I am late, it is because the bus is late.</p></blockquote><p>While the first sentence is using the irrealis mood, and it expresses something that will never happen (I will never be rich, and I will never live on Long Island), the second sentence is expressing a possibility (in the case I am late, that is because the bus is late).</p><p>Is there a way to express that also in Italian? Can I express the difference there is in those English sentences also in Italian, using two different moods or tenses?</p>
titulo: Irrealis conditional versus possibility

cuerpo: <p>Can I use the future tense to express a possibility, or predict the future, rather than saying something I will surely do?</p><p>For example, if I say <em>andrò a casa di mio cugino</em> (literally, "I will go to my cousin's house"), does that mean I am surely going to my cousin's house, or is that also understood as "there is a possibility I will go to my cousin's house"?</p><p>To make another example, in English "I will come to live in Italy" can express something I am willing to do, not something I surely going to do; for some circumstances, the person saying that sentence could not be able to come to live in Italy, for example because she cannot sell her house.<br>What mood or tense should I use in that case, in Italian?</p>
titulo: Using the Simple Future to express a possibility

cuerpo: <p>The plural of <em>euro</em> is <em>euro</em>; I think that was established by the <em>Accademia della Crusca</em>.</p><p>Sometimes, you hear the plural being used, and often it is done in a semi-serious tone; in other cases, it is done from people who are used to use the plural for currency names (which what normally happens; compare <em>un dollaro</em> with <em>dieci dollari</em>), and does the same for <em>euro</em>.</p><h3>References</h3><ul><li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linguistic_issues_concerning_the_euro#Italian" rel="nofollow">Linguistic issues concerning the euro</a></li></ul>

<p>Italian has a future tense only in the Indicative mood, and Indicative is the mood of certainty, when you don't add specific verbs whose effect is to add uncertainty.</p><p>So, no, you can't use that sentence to express a probability. If you want to achieve this effect (convey uncertainty), you say:</p><blockquote>  <p>Credo che andrò a casa di mio cugino.</p></blockquote><p>So, the verb "credere" here adds that particular feature you want: you think you're going to your cousin's house, but that's not certain. </p>

<p>I second @kiamlaluno's answer. The Accademia della Crusca <a href="http://www.accademiadellacrusca.it/en/italian-language/language-consulting/questions-answers/plurale-euro" rel="nofollow">explains</a> that the correct plural form of <em>euro</em> is <em>euro</em> (claiming that it was actually the EU decision from 1998 to make exceptions for the plural form of <em>euro</em> in English, German, and Italian).</p>

<p>Depending on the language euro is (or not) an invariant noun.</p><p>The European Union specifies that, in official documents, <em>euro</em> should be pluralized as <em>euro</em>.</p><p><a href="http://ec.europa.eu/economy_finance/publications/publication6336_en.pdf">Spelling of the words "euro" and "cent" in official community languages as used in community legislative acts</a></p><p>Personally, I only rarely heard Italian people using <em>euri</em> (most often as a joke), and it just sounds wrong to say it.</p>

<p>Just as for English, the same distinction can be done in Italian, using the subjunctive + conditional vs the indicative.</p><blockquote>  <p>Se <strong>fossi</strong> ricco <strong>vivrei</strong> su Long Island. (present subjunctive + present conditional)  </p></blockquote><p>or, in the past</p><blockquote>  <p>Se <strong>fossi stato</strong> ricco <strong>avrei vissuto</strong> su Long Island.</p></blockquote><p>versus</p><blockquote>  <p>Se <strong>sono</strong> in ritardo <strong>è</strong> a causa del [ritardo del] bus (present indicative)</p></blockquote><p>or, in the past</p><blockquote>  <p>Se <strong>fui</strong> in ritardo <strong>fu</strong> a causa del bus</p></blockquote>

<p>English and Italian behave in the same way on this matter.</p><blockquote>  <p>Andrò a casa di mio cugino</p></blockquote><p>and </p><blockquote>  <p>I will go to my cousin's house</p></blockquote><p>have the exact same meaning: I've decided to go to my cousin's house in the future.</p><p>The same applies to the sentence you mentioned in a comment to martina's answer</p><blockquote>  <p>iOS 7 will be the OS used from 97% of the sold cell phones</p></blockquote><p>would translate to</p><blockquote>  <p>iOS 7 sarà il SO usato dal 97% dei cellulari venduti</p></blockquote><p>with the exact same meaning. Both sentences state something that is going to happen in the future, but neither of the sentences would explicitly remark that this is just a prediction, even though this is obvious from the context.</p><p>Both languages have the possibility of adding some emphasis on the uncertainty, by using an auxiliary construct, such as <em>Credo che</em> (<em>I believe</em>) or <em>Prevedo che</em> (<em>I foresee</em>), for instance</p><blockquote>  <p>Prevedo che Android non sarà più usato nel 2020<br>  I foresee Android not being used anymore in 2020</p></blockquote>

<p>I often see sentences like</p><blockquote>  <p>nel ringraziarla, le porgo i miei più cordiali saluti</p></blockquote><p>capitalized as follows</p><blockquote>  <p>nel ringraziarLa, Le porgo i miei più cordiali saluti</p></blockquote><p>Some people claim the latter to be more formal, some others argue that it's wrong and a misuse of capitalization.</p><p>Which one is preferable and/or more correct?</p>
titulo: Should formal pronouns be capitalized?

cuerpo: <p>The second phrase is more formal and slightly antique (antique not in a sense of "archaic" but just as an older and established version). It is the only style in which any bureaucratic correspondence or commercial letters should be written.<br>The <a href="http://www.accademiadellacrusca.it/it/lingua-italiana/consulenza-linguistica/domande-risposte/pronomi-cortesia" rel="nofollow">rules</a> require using capitalization of the pronouns a) to distinguish between a correspondent, addressed in a polite way, and any other (third) person, and b) to show more respect to the correspondent (as it is the case in some other languages, e.g., in German, Danish, Russian, and partially Swedish). But it has become more and more common recently to avoid capitalization, just to simplify correspondence and reading and to shift the writer's attention from the appropriate grammar use to the meaning of what's being said.</p>

<p>I'd like to point out that neither Crusca nor EU can “decide” anything about a language. A language is shaped by its speakers.</p><p>This said, a majority uses “euro” as an invariant noun, while a minority advocates “euri” (and actually there is a precedent: “euro” as the noun of a wind has “euri”, in the generalised sense of “winds”, as its regular plural. For instance, «No; tu dal giovin animo / il timor freddo escludi; / gli Euri sonanti il portino / nelle letee paludi», Ludovico Savioli).</p>

<p>Capitalizing the pronoun when it is referring to the person/people to whom a communication is directed is normally used in commercial/business communications. Capitalizing it would mean to consider the receiver of the communication important.</p><p>Nowadays, it is less and less used; somebody could also find it affected. Eventually, the communication can start with <em>Gentile Cliente</em>, but then the pronoun or the possessive is written normally as any other word (which means it is capitalized only at the beginning of a sentence.)</p><p>In any case, it is not a matter of grammar; It just a way to convey a meaning ("you, the listener, are important for us") that otherwise would require using adjectives (e.g. <em>stimato</em>).</p>
<p>Can anyone explain what <em>avere la botte piena, la moglie ubriaca e l'uva sulla vigna</em> means?</p><p>Also, are there regional variations of that proverb? If so, what are they?</p>
titulo: "avere la botte piena, la moglie ubriaca e l'uva sulla vigna"

cuerpo: <p>It has the same meaning of the expression "<em>have your cake and eat it too</em>", that is, when there's a tradeoff you cannot have both things at the same time.</p><p>In this case you have three parts:</p><blockquote>  <p>botte piena = a full barrel [of wine]<br>  moglie ubriaca = a drunk wife<br>  uva sulla vigna = grapes on the vine, the grapes used to  make the wine</p></blockquote><p>The third part is sometimes omitted, and you also have <em>avere la moglie piena e la botte ubriaca</em>.</p><p>There are some regional variations, for example, in Ferrara there's <em>an s'pol brisa aver galina, ov e cul cald</em> (<em>non si possono avere gallina, uovo e culo caldo</em>; literally, "you can't have chicken, egg and warm ass," where <em>warm ass</em> means not to have to work).</p>

<p>In the banknotes there is written "5 EURO / EYP&Omega; / EBPO" :-) (Actually the word is seen as an abbreviation of "europeo", so it should be invariable like "video". Then again, "euri" is widely used in spoken language, but not in written form)</p>

<p>It means to want something impossible, since it is not possible to have a barrel full of wine if somebody drank the wine, and it is not possible to have grapes on a grapevine, if the grapes have been used to make wine.</p><p>The only variant I know is the shortened version of what you wrote: <em>Avere la botte piena e la moglie ubriaca</em>.</p>

<p>In American English the following sentence would be correctly written.</p><blockquote>  <p>It is true: She wanted me to say she was with me when her husband was killed.</p></blockquote><p>The first word after the colon is written capitalized because it is part of a sentence.</p><p>Also this sentence is correct, since what follow the colon is not a sentence.</p><blockquote>  <p>I did all I had to do: buy the train tickets, pay my taxes online, and order dinner from a take away.</p></blockquote><p>How would the equivalent Italian sentences be written? Would the word after the colon be capitalized in the first sentence, but not in the second one, or would the first word after the colon be written all in lowercase?</p>
titulo: Capitalization of the first word after a colon

cuerpo: <p>The Italian-English dictionaries (Collins, for example) translate both <em>infatti</em> and <em>in effetti</em> as "in fact; as a matter of fact; indeed." The Italians insist, however, that these two words are not interchangeable and actually mean different things. How come?</p><p>So far, I'd write some phrases like this:</p><blockquote>  <p><em>Lo credevo un amico ed infatti è stato proprio cosi.</em><br>  <em>Lo credevo un amico e in effetti si è comportato da vero amico.</em><br>  <em>Lo credevo un amico, in effetti non lo è mai stato.</em></p></blockquote><p>What's the logic behind this? May I use both <em>infatti</em> and <em>in effetti</em> to confirm something? Does the meaning change if I do that? May I use <em>infatti</em> in the last phrase? Finally, do I need to use commas with these expressions (e.g., <em>ed, infatti, è stato...</em>)?</p>
titulo: Difference between "infatti" and "in effetti"

cuerpo: <p>Simple rule is: after any punctuation sign which is not indicating the end of the sentence never use a capital letter.This reduces the use of a capital letter only after . ! and ?.If you are fluent in English you can think about the rules of British English that, in this circumstances, apply fully also to italian.</p>

<p>There's a difference, but maybe these sentences aren't very good examples.</p><p>"In effetti" is more used in adversative or restrictive contexts, take this example:</p><blockquote>  <p>In effetti, dovevamo procedere diversamente. (Actually, we should have proceeded in a different way)</p></blockquote><p>In this case, you can't use "infatti", which usually is used instead to confirm and/or explicate the current context (or the preceding phrase).</p><p>About your examples:</p><ol><li><p>this is a little weird, because "lo credevo un amico" makes me assume that he's not your friend anymore. It's strange to say "infatti è stato proprio così" after this. Better to use presente tense.</p></li><li><p>this is strange for the same reason. I'd rather say:</p><blockquote>  <p>Lo credo un amico, e in effetti si è comportato da vero amico</p></blockquote></li><li><p>this is probably the most correct one. I imagine two friends talking about a third person, which was considered to be a friend, but then the person speaking realizes that this person never behaved as a friend. "In effetti" is used here to contrast with the meaning of the preceeding sentence, so is correct. You wouldn't use "infatti" in this example, it doesn't make sense.</p></li></ol><p>About the commas: you would usually put one before. In your example:</p><blockquote>  <p>Lo credevo un amico, e infatti è stato proprio cosi.</p></blockquote><p>In my example I put a comma after "in effetti", because there's no phrase before. A more complete period could be:</p><blockquote>  <p>A: "Non pensi di aver fatto degli errori?"</p>    <p>B: "In effetti, dovevamo procedere diversamente."</p></blockquote>

<p>For how I use those words, in dialogs <em>in effetti</em> is used when you agree with the person with whom you are speaking; <em>infatti</em> is used when you disagree with the other person, and you are saying for which reason you disagree.</p><blockquote>  <p><strong>A</strong>: Marco sapeva tutto.<br>  <strong>B</strong>: Non sapeva niente. Infatti, si è meravigliato di quello che stavo dicendo e mi ha chiesto cosa Luigi avesse fatto.</p></blockquote><blockquote>  <p><strong>A</strong>: Marco non sapeva niente.<br>  <strong>B</strong>: In effetti, si è meravigliato quando gli ho detto quello che Luigi aveva fatto. Probabilmente hai ragione a dire che non sapeva niente.</p></blockquote><p>Generally speaking, <em>infatti</em> means "in fact; as a matter of fact." It is used when you explain a previous sentence, such as in the following case.</p><blockquote>  <p>Ieri è stata una brutta giornata; infatti, ha piovuto quasi tutto il giorno.</p></blockquote><p>I would not use <em>in effetti</em> in this case; I could use it in the following case.</p><blockquote>  <p><strong>A</strong>: Ieri è stata una brutta giornata.<br>  <strong>B</strong>: In effetti, ha piovuto quasi tutto il giorno.</p></blockquote>

<p>A phrase like "<strong>asking</strong> questions is a sign of a curious mind" is translated in Italian as <em><strong>fare</strong> domande è segno di una mente curiosa</em>; the difference is clearly that English uses the gerund where Italian uses the infinitive.</p><p>Does Italian always use the infinitive where English uses the gerund?</p><p>The only case where this <em>rule</em> doesn't seem to apply is with <em>giocando si impara</em>, which is the translation of "you learn by playing." I would not say <em>giocare si impara</em>.<br>Is there any reason for using <em>giocando</em> in this case?</p>
titulo: Does Italian always use the infinitive where English uses the gerund?

cuerpo: <p>There is no “rule” such as the one you suggest. An English gerund might often correspond to an Italian noun (“running is a healthy sport” > “la corsa è uno sport salutare”), or some phrase not involving an infinitive (“seeing is believing” > “se lo vedi, ci credi”; you <em>might</em> say “vedere è credere”, but it would sound wooden and as a calque from English), and even an Italian gerund, as in the sentence you quote, which is not at all unique.</p><p>In general, in Italian a subordinate phrase with a gerund often expresses a cause, a hypothesis, a way of doing something (as in your example) and the like, so it may correspond to English gerunds introduced by “by”, “while” and so on. Say, “while returning from work, I saw...” > “tornando dal lavoro, ho visto...” but also “mentre tornavo dal lavoro ho visto...”</p><p>(Finally, “giocare si impara” is meaningless; if you were forced at gunpoint to use an infinitive you'd say something like “col giocare si impara”, but it would sound horrid.)</p>

<p>In <em>giocando si impara</em>, <em>giocando</em> is a ‘complemento di mezzo‘ or di ‘modo’; you would say, instead, <em>giocare è divertente</em>; on the other hand you'd say <em>il bello del giocare è il divertimento</em> (<em>the good of playing is the fun</em>).</p><p>The gerund has a meaning of cause, time, medium or mode. So for a specification you need the infinitive.</p><p>This is a cause of several errors when trying to translate Italian in English (or conversely): <em>Questo è spesso causa di errori provando a tradurre l'italiano in inglese</em> can have the gerund, because time is involved (<em>quando si prova</em>). But <em>trying one's best in translating from Italian to English</em> should be <em>fare del proprio meglio traducendo dall'italiano all'inglese</em>.</p>

<p>When translating a sentence like "It has been you." in Italian, should I use the subjective case for <em>you</em>, or the objective case?</p><p>In other words, should I say <em>sei stato tu</em> or <em>sei stato te</em>? </p><p>I would use <em>sei stato te</em>, but it sounds strange to my hears. I interpret is as <em>tu sei stato</em> for which the subject is then moved at the end of the sentence. Is it correct?</p>
titulo: Subjective case or objective case?

cuerpo: <p>“Sei stato te” is an ungrammatical sentence, “te” being the objective-case form, to be used only as the direct or indirect object of a verb (“(non ho visto Gianni,) ho visto te”, “(non l'ho dato a Maria,) l'ho dato a te”), and even so, mostly when you want to put the stress on “you” (otherwise you'd say “ti ho visto”, “te l'ho dato”).</p><p>By the way, in a sentence like “sei stato tu”, “tu” is actually the subject.</p><p>(This said, it is not too uncommon to hear people using “te” in the above ungrammatical way.)</p>

<p>The correct form is</p><blockquote>  <p>Sei stato tu?</p></blockquote><p>as <em>tu</em> is the subject of the phrase and it's grammatically equivalent to</p><blockquote>  <p>Tu sei stato?</p></blockquote><p>even though with a significant different emphasis and meaning.</p><p>However it's not uncommon tu use <em>te</em> in place of <em>tu</em> in such a phrase. Many native speakers would say</p><blockquote>  <p>Sei stato te?</p></blockquote><p>probably without even being aware of its incorrectness. </p><p>So it's still incorrect, but it's surely very used and - personally - it doesn't particularly bother me when I hear it. </p>

<p>1) "<strong><em>un</em></strong> francese e due svizzeri"</p><p>2) "<strong><em>uno</em></strong> svizzero e due francesi"</p><p>Do the bolded <strong><em>un</em></strong> and <strong><em>uno</em></strong> mean the same thing? If so, can 1) be rewritten this way:</p><p>3) "uno francese e due svizzeri"</p><p>If not, can anyone explain the difference between 1) and 3)?</p>
titulo: Article comparison in "un francese e due svizzeri" and "uno svizzero e due francesi"

cuerpo: <p>Feminine nouns pose almost no problem, because the indeterminate article is only <em>una</em>, that's subject to elision in front of vowels. On the other hand, with masculine nouns, the usage of <em>un</em> and <em>uno</em> reflects the usage of <em>il</em> and <em>lo</em>.If a word starts by “s” followed by a consonant (and the digraph “sc” also follows the rule), the articles for it must be “lo” and ”uno” (determinate and indeterminate). So the rest of the answer is about masculine nouns.</p><p>The same happens for words starting with “gn”, ”z”, ”ps”: <em>uno gnocco</em>, <em>lo zio</em>, <em>lo psicologo</em>. For <em>pneumatico</em> the standard should be “lo” and “uno”, but “il” and “un” are frequent. Also words starting with consonantic “i” want “lo” and ”uno” (<em>iato</em> = <em>hyatus</em>), although this is disputed and someone says <em>l'iato</em>.</p><p>The other words want “il” and ”un”. Thus, <em>uno francese</em> is not Italian. The usage of “lo” was more liberal in the past and you find <em>lo duca mio</em> in Dante's “Commedia”. You also find <em>il zappatore</em> in Leopardi's “Il sabato del villaggio”. For this, when I was at the elementary school, the teacher said <em>licenza poetica</em>, but the usage was not really consistent at the time the poem was written.</p><p>When foreign words are concerned, the situation is fluid. Somebody swears for <em>l'whisky</em>, other (I among them) say <em>il whisky</em> (Luciano Satta wrote about this defending “il” and “un” before <em>whisky</em>).</p><p>Dialects are of course different. In Veneto we commonly say <em>il gnocco</em> without any problem.</p><hr><p>A different situation is when “uno” is a pronoun rather than an article. In this case the only form is <em>uno</em>. Thus, *ho tre amici stranieri, uno francese e due svizzeri“; the verbs <em>è</em> and <em>sono</em> are implicit and the complete sentence would be <em>ho tre amici stranieri, uno è francese e due sono svizzeri</em>.</p>

<p><em>Un</em> is an elision of <em>uno</em>, which is used before words starting with vowel or consonant; <em>uno</em> is used with words starting with <em>impure S</em>,  <em>Z</em>, <em>X</em>, <em>gn</em>, <em>pn</em>, <em>ps</em>. (<em>Impure S</em> is an S followed by a consonant.)</p><ul><li><em>Un albero</em></li><li><em>Un cane</em></li><li><em>Uno stagno</em></li><li><em>Un francese</em></li><li><em>Uno xilofono</em></li><li><em>Uno pneumatico</em></li><li><em>Uno zio</em></li></ul><p>About <em>uno svizzero and uno francese</em> in <em>ho due orologi, uno svizzero ed uno francese</em>, that is not using the indefinite article, but it is using a numeral; it is similar to the following sentence.</p><blockquote>  <p>Ho sei orologi: due francesi, uno russo e tre tedeschi.</p></blockquote><p><em>Uno svizzero e un francese</em> would be understood as referring to two people: a person from Switzerland and one from France.</p>

<p>Both <em>un</em> e <em>uno</em> are indeterminate articles (as <em>a</em> in English). For masculine words <em>un</em> is normally used, but you have to use <em>uno</em> if the following word (a noun or an adjective) starts with <em>gn</em>, <em>ps</em>, <em>z</em>, <em>x</em>, <em>y</em>, <em>s</em> + consonant.</p>

<p>Is it acceptable to start a sentence with <em>e</em>, or any other conjunction?</p><blockquote>  <p>E come se non bastasse, nell'unico momento in cui ero libero è arrivata Marisa.</p></blockquote><p>I could write that sentence without <em>e</em> and it would be understood the same. Is there any rule against starting a sentence with a conjunction? If it is not acceptable, is it at least used in not formal contexts?</p>
titulo: Using "e" at the beginning of a sentence

cuerpo: <p>Some sounds don't exist in Italian, such as the Arabic sounds <em>dad</em> (<em>ض</em>), <em>qaf</em> (<em>ق</em>), or <em>ain</em> (<em>ع</em>).</p><p>Are there letters or syllables for these sounds?</p>
titulo: Does Italian language have letters for foreign sounds?

cuerpo: <p>As other languages using the Latin alphabet, Italian doesn't have letters for foreign sounds; the word is written using Latin characters in a conventional way.</p>

<p>In English, a space is added before and after a slash when the slash is used to separate two phrases made of more than one word.</p><blockquote>  <p>I will call you when the president/secretary will ask for you.</p></blockquote><blockquote>  <p>I will call you when the President / Secretary of state will ask for you.</p></blockquote><p>Is there any rule for Italian?</p><p>I would rather not use any space, but I am not sure that is the correct way.</p>
titulo: Space before and after a slash

cuerpo: <p>In English, to avoid a phrase to be misunderstood, the Oxford comma is used.</p><blockquote>  <p>To my parents, the Pope, and Mother Theresa</p></blockquote><p>Without the serial comma, the phrase would become <em>to my parents, the Pope and Mother Theresa</em>, and it could be understood as saying that my parents are the Pope and Mother Theresa.</p><p>(Granted, there are cases where the Oxford comma would make a phrase ambiguous.)</p><p>Since Italian doesn't use the Oxford comma, how can I avoid any ambiguity with that phrase?<br>I am sure that using the comma before <em>e</em> (<em>and</em>) is not standard in Italian, and it was considered an error at the times I went to school.</p><blockquote>  <p>Ai miei genitori, il Papa e Madre Teresa.</p></blockquote>
titulo: How should I disambiguate this sentence?

cuerpo: <p>In English, the items of a list are written like in the following sentence.</p><blockquote>  <p>I have done all my today's jobs:</p>    <ul>  <li>Prepared breakfast for the family</li>  <li>Made sure everybody was awake in time for doing what they had to do</li>  <li>Washed the dishes from the previous night's dinner</li>  <li>Cleaned home</li>  <li>Prepared lunch for me, and dinner for everybody</li>  </ul></blockquote><p>How should I write the same sentence in Italian? Should I capitalize every item in the list? Should I avoid adding a period at the end of each item? In the case the single items are sentences, should I add the period at the end of each sentence?</p>
titulo: Items of a list: Should I capitalize them and use a period at the end?

cuerpo: <p>The common style is to use a semicolon at the end of every list item, and start items with lowercase letters.</p><p>There is an alternative style, ending each sentence with a full stop and starting each item with a capital letter.</p><p>They can be both used. It depends mainly on the publisher (for books, magazines and newspapers).</p>

<p>It is not grammatically wrong, and is used to give emphasis to the sentence. In your phrase it makes the "come se non bastasse" even stronger.</p><p>It should not be abused, it would be like writing all in boldface.</p>

<p>Ogni lingua evolve. </p><p>Misurare la creatività di una lingua non è impresa facile, ma l'apparire di neologismi nel lessico ne è un buon estimatore.</p><p>Non conosco quale sia la regola dietro la scelta di inserimento di neologismi nel vocabolario (intendendo qui il vocabolario come prodotto editoriale, rivisto periodicamente), e sospetto che non sia universale.</p><p>In italiano numerosi neologismi provengono (per ovvi motivi) dall'inglese.Ci sono sostantivi presi così come sono (e.g., <em>computer</em>, <em>bar</em>, <em>pub</em> ...), e questo non è molto interessante. Più interessante è il caso dei verbi, che se di nuova fattura nell'italiano perché provenienti da fuori prendono sempre la coniugazione in -are (e.g., <em>cliccare</em>, <em>googlare</em> ...), in parte perché essendo la più diffusa è la più immediata da associare.</p><p>L'inserimento di foriesterismi non è l'unico stimolo al dinamismo lessicale. Ci sono infatti neologismi che nascono dall'interno dell'italiano stesso, e famoso è infatti il caso del verbo <em>perplimere</em>, nato (anni fa) dalla creatività di un comico. Il suo significato è chiaro e tappa la carenza lessicale di un verbo che significhi "rendere perplesso".Tuttavia, sebbene siano passati anni, tale verbo non fa ancora parte dei vocabolari ufficiali (<a href="http://www.accademiadellacrusca.it/it/lingua-italiana/consulenza-linguistica/domande-risposte/significato-origine-perplimere" rel="nofollow">si può leggere la sua storia qui</a>).</p><p>Questi sono le due categorie principali di dinamismo linguistico che riesco a tracciare nell'italiano. Mi risulta che i dialetti siano molto più creativi, forse perché non avendo un vocabolario scritto non ci si pone il problema sull'inserimento o meno di termini e tutto è lasciato al naturale decorso del parlare. L'italiano ufficiale risulta molto più conservatore nell'accettare il cambiamento.</p><p>Chiedo dotti lumi circa la situazione effettiva della lingua in merito al suo dinamismo, anche magari con paragoni con altre lingue. Esempi di termini che siano attualmente in uso ma che abbiano avuto una storia di travagliata accettazione sono particolarmente ben accetti.</p>
titulo: Creatività e dinamismo nella lingua italiana

cuerpo: <p>The general idea is that you are completing the first part of the sentence before the list, so punctuation goes with it. Example:</p><blockquote>  <p>Lavorare con noi ti permette di</p>    <ul>  <li>andare a casa ogni giorno alle cinque,</li>  <li>avere pranzo gratis e</li>  <li>ricevere una gratificazione natalizia.</li>  </ul></blockquote><p>As you can see it's a <em>typographical convention over a correct, Italian sentence</em>.Another example:</p><blockquote>  <p>Ecco i benefit che offriamo:</p>    <ul>  <li>30 giorni di ferie all'anno;</li>  <li>assicurazione sanitaria privata;</li>  <li>due monitor per sviluppatore.</li>  </ul></blockquote><p>Similarly, it still reads as a sentence (albeit a boring, long, list-like one using <a href="https://it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punto_e_virgola">semicolons to separate concepts</a>). A different case in which lists are composed of sentences:</p><blockquote>  <p>Ecco alcune domande che potremmo chiederti:</p>    <ul>  <li>Quanti d&igrave; conta novembre?</li>  <li>Di che colore era il cavallo bianco di Napoleone?</li>  <li>Come si neutralizza il fantasma Formaggino?</li>  </ul></blockquote><p>In this case, everything still reads as normal Italian, but each sentence is capitalized and ends with a punctuation mark (in this case a question mark, but periods and exclamation marks also work).</p>

<p>Ci sono molti neologismi in italiano, per esempio la <a href="http://www.treccani.it/magazine/lingua_italiana/neologismi/" rel="nofollow">Treccani pubblica una lista in merito</a>.</p><p>In pratica il linguaggio si evolve in base a mode (come pu&ograve; essere la novit&agrave; introdotta da un comico), ma anche e soprattutto in base alla necessit&agrave; di descrivere concetti nuovi.</p><p>Vista in quest'ottica, non sorprender&agrave; nessuno che l'evoluzione della lingua italiana sia stimolata da:</p><ul><li>tecnologia (soprattutto sotto forma di neologismi di origine inglese, ma non solo, ad esempio "amicarsi" su Facebook)</li><li>economia e management (anche qui, inglesismi e volgarizzazioni dell'inglese)</li><li>scienza (ad es. "paleoclimatologo")</li><li>giornalismo e politica (per esempio: neo-latinismi come "mattarellum" o "ad personam")</li></ul><p>Gli esempi sono molti, il link che ho riportato in testa ne contiene circa un migliaio.</p>

<p>The difference is that <em>in effetti</em> is generally used to <em>concede a point</em>, or to talk about how an opinion is altered by facts, or better by the consequences of a theory.</p><p>For example:</p><blockquote>  <p>A: Ho giocato il 42 al lotto perch&eacute; non usciva da molte settimane.</p>    <p>B: Guarda che i ritardi al lotto non contano nulla, nonostante si dica il contrario.</p>    <p>A: In effetti, non ho vinto nulla</p></blockquote><p><em>Infatti</em> is used to indicate complete <em>a priori</em> agreement:</p><blockquote>  <p>A: Mi sono lasciato convincere da mia zia a giocare il 42 al lotto perch&eacute; non usciva da molte settimane.</p>    <p>B: Non mi sembra una grande strategia&hellip;</p>    <p>A: Infatti non ho vinto nulla</p></blockquote><p>Of course, these are the general rules, but languages tend to be a bit more subtle. For example, you can concede with emphasis by using <em>infatti</em>. The following is an example similar to my first, but in which a stronger concession of a point is implied:</p><blockquote>  <p>A: Ho giocato il 42 al lotto perch&eacute; non usciva da molte settimane.</p>    <p>B: Guarda che i ritardi al lotto non contano nulla, nonostante si dica il contrario.</p>    <p>A: Infatti! Non ho vinto nulla!</p></blockquote>

<p>Usually in Italian, you don't use any space before punctuation but only after (with some exceptions).In the case of a slash, if it divides two single words it is used without space as "e/o" or "il/la".If slash is used to divide two sentences, you'd better use the space as in your second example, so it is the same as in English.</p>

<p>Inoltre, un termine già esistente può cambiare il significato a causa dell'affermarsi di tendenze politiche o della nascita di una nuova 'moda' (ad es. <em>scafista</em> o <em>girotondo</em>).  </p><p>C'è un <a href="http://books.google.se/books/about/Parole_nuove_e_datate_Studi_su_neologism.html?id=WRSGkgEACAAJ" rel="nofollow">bel libro</a> di Paolo D'Achille che racconta le storie di alcune parole "nuove", come <em>bagnoschiuma, fondotinta</em> e <em>caffellatte</em>. E poi Giovanni Petrolini <a href="http://books.google.se/books?id=oCwLAQAAMAAJ" rel="nofollow">qui</a> parla di parole dell'uso quotidiano, prese dai dialetti o dalle altre lingue europee (<em>mortadella, patate, scopa</em>, ecc.), e delle loro storie più o meno intense, interessanti, ed a volte tragiche.</p>

<p>Conjunctions should be used to conjunct two different parts (sentences, words, ...) so, technically speaking, starting a sentence with them is broadly considered a misuse.</p><p>But exactly for being a misuse, such construct has the effect of drawing extra attention on the sentence itself.</p><p>Using the form</p><blockquote>  <p>E <em>SENTENCE_B</em> </p></blockquote><p>as opposed to</p><blockquote>  <p><em>SENTENCE_A</em> e <em>SENTENCE_B</em></p></blockquote><p>immediately highlights the absence of a sentence joined before it and makes the reader wonder what the author omitted.</p><p>Such omission can be for instance the situation in which <em>SENTENCE_B</em> takes place, and we find many examples in poetry.</p><p>As an example <sup>[1]</sup>, G. Pascoli starts his poetry <em>Il gelsomino notturno</em> with</p><blockquote>  <p>E s'aprono i fiori notturni, <br>  nell'ora che penso ai miei cari</p></blockquote><p>The sentence after the <em>E</em> describes something happening at night, but there a whole lot of content unexpressed before it, namely the situation of waiting during the night, before the flowers disclose.</p><p>In this other example <sup>[1]</sup></p><blockquote>  <p>E, dopo tanti discorsi, finalmente l'accordo!</p></blockquote><p>The conjunction <em>E</em> implies a phase of discussion before the deal. Using the <em>E</em> allows the writer not to explicitly mention it, but rather to suggest that the current situation is a consequences of previous events.</p><hr><p><sup>[1] Examples taken from <a href="http://www.accademiadellacrusca.it/it/lingua-italiana/consulenza-linguistica/domande-risposte/sulluso-congiunzioni-allinizio-frase" rel="nofollow">http://www.accademiadellacrusca.it/it/lingua-italiana/consulenza-linguistica/domande-risposte/sulluso-congiunzioni-allinizio-frase</a></sup></p>

<p>In the phrase the verb <em>dedicato</em> is probably implicit. Saying</p><blockquote>  <p><em>ai miei genitori, il Papa e Madre Teresa</em></p></blockquote><p>would only mean that the Pope and Mother Theresa are my parents, with no ambiguity whatsoever. In this case it's the grammatical number that makes the difference:</p><blockquote>  <p><em>ai miei genitori, al Papa e a Madre Teresa</em></p></blockquote><p>will convey the correct information. If I want to dedicate my book</p><blockquote>  <p>*ai miei maestri, colleghi e allievi</p></blockquote><p>I'll choose this form rather than the clumsy</p><blockquote>  <p>*ai miei maestri, ai miei colleghi e ai miei allievi</p></blockquote><p>The slight ambiguity is immediately cast out, because no one can be master, colleague and pupil of the same person.</p><p>Also the article can get into the matter:</p><blockquote>  <p><em>a mamma, papà e nonna</em></p></blockquote><p>would be correct. Note that <em>nonna</em> wants the article in some variant of Italian (<em>a nonna</em> is more Central than Northern Italian). But, with articles,</p><blockquote>  <p><em>alla mamma, al papà e alla nonna</em></p></blockquote><p>tends to require repeating the preposition. The article is not compulsory, but if used the preposition becomes somewhat necessary in front of all terms. I'm not saying that</p><blockquote>  <p><em>alla mamma, papà e nonna</em></p></blockquote><p>is ungrammatical, but it doesn't sound right to my ear. If the gender is the same as in </p><blockquote>  <p><em>alla mamma, zia e nonna</em></p></blockquote><p>it <em>could</em> be right, but leaving a small ambiguity as whether my mother is also my aunt and grandmother. So, when the article is involved, repeat the preposition.</p><p>Similarly one will tend to say</p><blockquote>  <p><em>andrò al mare, al lago o ai monti</em></p></blockquote><p>because one term is plural and the others are singular; again, <em>andrò al mare, lago o monti</em> is not good to my ear. On the other hand</p><blockquote>  <p><em>andrò a Rimini, Riccione o Igea Marina</em></p></blockquote><p>can avoid repeating the preposition, but <em>andrò a Rimini, a Riccione o a Igea Marina</em> would be good as well. Here no article can be used, of course.</p>

<blockquote>  <p>Sono qui da trentuno anni.</p></blockquote><blockquote>  <p>Sono qui da trentun anni.</p></blockquote><blockquote>  <p>Sono qui da trentun'anni.</p></blockquote><p>Yes, the first is correct, but which one between the second and the third is correct?</p>
titulo: "Sono qui da trentun anni" versus "Sono qui da trentun'anni"

cuerpo: <p>I often heard people saying "Boh!" especially, but not only, when I stayed in Rome.</p><p>However, I'm unsure what the intended meaning of "Boh!" is, either in Rome or elsewhere. Does it mean <em>I don't know</em>, <em>I don't want to say</em>, <em>I'm not interested</em>, or something else?</p><p>Thus, I would like to know what a non-native speaker should deduce when they hear "Boh!"  Please don't answer with "Boh!"</p>
titulo: What does "Boh!" mean, precisely?

cuerpo: <p>The second is correct. It's apocope (omission of the final sound of a word), which doesn't need an apostrophe. The rule is: anything ending with <em>-uno</em>, including <em>uno</em> as an indeterminate article, as well as <em>alcuno, nessuno, ciascuno,</em> etc., before the masculine words, starting with a vowel or with a consonant other than s impura/z/gn/ps, drops the final letter.<br>Examples: <em>un uomo, alcun pensiero, nessun dubbio, ciascun anno</em>, etc.</p>

<p>'Boh' means 'I do not know', with all its nuances: </p><ul><li>I don't know, </li><li>I know but I am not gonna tell you, </li><li>I don't know and I don't care, </li><li>I am confused</li><li>etc.</li></ul><p>I've been looking around for the etymology of this word but it seems not to be available.</p>

<p>The correct form is the middle one. The first is not incorrect, but not used except in particular cases. The third form is wrong (at least under the current orthography rules).</p><p><em>Trentuno</em> follows the same rule as <em>uno</em> (indeterminate article) discussed in <a href="http://italian.stackexchange.com/questions/122/un-francese-e-due-svizzeri-vs-uno-svizzero-e-due-francesi">&quot;un francese e due svizzeri&quot; vs. &quot;uno svizzero e due francesi&quot;</a>. The truncation is not really compulsory, but very common.</p><p>It's even commoner with the indeterminate adjectives ending in <em>uno</em>, <em>nessuno</em> being the most commonly used. Nobody would say <em>nessuno amico</em>, but <em>trentuno amici</em> can be heard when the emphasis is on the number, say in <em>aveva ben trentuno amici</em>.</p><p>Speaking of <em>apocope</em>, <em>ben</em> is a peculiar word, but this would take too far.</p>

<p>Yes, as it is said in a previous answer <em>Sono qui da trentun anni</em> is correct, while <em>Sono qui da trentuno anni</em> is awkward. Between the following, which one is correct?</p><blockquote>  <p>Sono qui da anni trentun.</p></blockquote><blockquote>  <p>Sono qui da anni trentuno.</p></blockquote><p>If both are wrong, can anyone explain why?</p>
titulo: "Sono qui da anni trentuno" versus "Sono qui da anni trentun"

cuerpo: <p><em>Boh</em> means doubt, indifference, unwillingness to talk about something or to express an opinion. It's widely used in the Roman dialect (but not only). One <a href="http://www.accademiadellacrusca.it/it/lingua-italiana/consulenza-linguistica/domande-risposte/linteriezione" rel="nofollow">possible explanation</a> of its etymology is the sound that one produces when wants to express uncertainty.<br>A non-native speaker should pay attention to the context, where <em>Boh!</em> appears, and then it's quite easy to deduce its meaning, because it usually appears in response to something.</p>

<blockquote>  <p>Io non mancai di ricordargli, che quanto più conosceva, più era tenuto a rimediarvi, e non aspettare che <strong><em>altri</em></strong> facesse […].  &mdash;Niccolò Machiavelli</p></blockquote><p>Can anyone explain how <em>altri</em> is used there?</p>
titulo: What does "altri" mean in "che altri facesse"?

cuerpo: <p><em>Boh</em> is used to mean uncertainty, indifference, disbelief, contempt; it is similar to <em>bah</em> which is used to express uncertainty, hopelessness, disbelief, contempt, and <em>mah</em> that express doubt, uncertainty.</p><p>The first two words are onomatopoeic, while <em>mah</em> comes from Latin <em>măgis</em>.</p>

<p>Both are wrong, but to correct them, it's necessary to know what you want to say.<br>If you want to say "I'm here (= I live here) for thirty years", then it's <em>Sono qui da trentun anni</em>.<br>If you want to say "I'm here since the 1930s (or, maybe, 1830s)," then it should be <em>Sono qui dagli anni Trenta</em>.</p>

<p>It means "other (people)".</p><p>Think about sentences like "gli uni e gli altri" or "non fare ad altri quello che non vorresti fosse fatto a te".</p><p>In Machiavelli's sentence, though, it is an archaic usage as it refers to a single (undetermined) person instead of a multitude: it says</p><blockquote>  <p>non aspettare che altri <strong>facesse</strong> ogni cosa</p></blockquote><p>whereas today it would be correct to say</p><blockquote>  <p>non aspettare che altri <strong>facessero</strong> ogni cosa</p></blockquote>

<p>I have heard the inversion between <em>anni</em> and the number in similar sentences, in formal documents (<em>La qui presente Rossi Giovanna di anni 41 […].</em>); sometimes it was used in other contexts for emphasis.</p><p>It's not the normal order used in Italian, but I would not call it wrong. </p>

<p>Sometimes in television shows like "Big Brother" or "X-Factor" I heard people saying "Ho fatto un provino".</p><p>Suppose I want to say to another person that those persons have made "un provino", can I say </p><blockquote>  <p>Quelle persone, in particolare quelle che hanno partecipato al 'Grande Fratello', sono state tutte <strong><em>provinate</em></strong>.</p></blockquote><p>I.E., does "provinate" work there? </p>
titulo: What do you say to describe persons who made "un provino"?

cuerpo: <p>While you might hear it spoken, it's not correct Italian written language. There is no single word to render the meaning but you can use a phrase</p><blockquote>  <p>Quelle persone, in particolare quelle che hanno partecipato al 'Grande Fratello', sono state tutte sottoposte a provini.</p></blockquote><p>Another way in which you can convey a similar meaning, but not exactly, is to use the term 'selezionate' (selected) o 'scrutinate' (carefully examined).</p><blockquote>  <p>Quelle persone, in particolare quelle che hanno partecipato al 'Grande Fratello', sono state tutte selezionate (scrutinate).</p></blockquote>

<p>Why is the double negation not an issue in the Italian language?</p><p>I ask because I heard that in English you cannot say "non guardo mai la televisione", but you have to say "I never watch at television", which translated word by word  is "Io mai guardo la televisione", thus removing one negation. </p>
titulo: Why is the double negation not an issue in the Italian language?

cuerpo: <p>In Italian the double negation is generally used with a negative meaning, like in the following examples</p><blockquote>  <p><strong>Non</strong> conosco <strong>nessuno</strong><br>  <strong>Non</strong> guardo <strong>mai</strong> la televisione<br>  <strong>Non</strong> posso farci <strong>niente</strong></p></blockquote><p>The way you can think about this is to consider the first negation as not having effect on anything else apart from the verb.</p><p>With this "rule", the <strong>non</strong> only serve the purpose of turning the verb into its negative form, but it doesn't affect the rest of the sentence.</p><p>This is also coherent with some other examples in which two negations on verbs make the sentence a positive one</p><blockquote>  <p><strong>Non</strong> credo di <strong>non</strong> essere capace<br>  <strong>Non</strong> dico che <strong>non</strong> sia appropriato</p></blockquote><p>In both sentences the negation is attached to the verb, and two negated verbs turn the sentence into a positive one. It's worth noting, though, that </p><blockquote>  <p>Non credo di non essere capace</p></blockquote><p>and</p><blockquote>  <p>Credo di essere capace</p></blockquote><p>although both expressing a positive sense, are not interchangeable, the former expressing a higher degree of doubt about the subject's abilities.</p><p>Finally, as an addition, Italian is not the only language making an extensive use of double negations. Spanish is another notable example:</p><blockquote>  <p><strong>No</strong> conozco <strong>nadie</strong><br>  <strong>No</strong> puedo hacer <strong>nada</strong></p></blockquote>

<p>Some English dialects allow to use the double negation (a.k.a. <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double_negative" rel="nofollow">double negative</a>) as intensifier; <em>I can get no sadisfaction</em> and <em>we don't need no education</em> are two phrases used in songs, but this use of double negation is common in some dialects in everyday speaking. See also <a href="http://english.stackexchange.com/questions/8777/is-there-a-rule-about-double-negations-that-arent-meant-as-double-negations-e">Is there a rule about double negations that aren't meant as double negations (e.g. "We don't need no education")?</a></p><p>In Italian, the double negation is by default an intensifier; <em>non so niente</em> doesn't mean <em>io so tutto</em> as Logic would interpret the phrase.</p>

<p>Innanzitutto bisogna fare una distinzione tra <strong>calco</strong> e <strong>prestito</strong>, due fenomeni differenti, i quali poi si suddividono in altri tipi.</p><p>Il <strong>calco semantico</strong>, per esempio, aggiunge un significato ad una parola già esistente: realizzare significa anche "rendersi conto" dall'inglese to realize, <em>salvare</em> file digitali da to save. Il <strong>calco strutturale</strong> prende una parola straniera e ne riproduce la struttura  più o meno fedelmente traducendo le parole che la compongono; un esempio potrebbe essere <em>grattacielo - skyscraper</em>, oppure <em>loanword - lehnwort</em>, oppure <em>fine settimana - weekend</em>.</p><p>Il prestito è invece l'importazione di termini nella propria lingua, ma non solo, vedi il <strong>prestito fonologico</strong> (il suono [ʒ] dal francese, tipo in <em>garage</em>). Il prestito si può distinguere poi in:</p><ul><li><strong>prestito di necessità</strong>: quando si scopre qualcosa di nuovo per cui non esiste un termine</li><li><strong>prestito di lusso</strong>: termine che esiste già ma viene adottato un termine straniero per via dell'accezione o per dare "pregio" al concetto: <em>boom di vendite</em> potrebbe benissimo essere <em>esplosione di vendite</em>.</li><li><strong>prestito non integrato</strong>: viene usato nella forma originaria (anche se poi viene usato come parola neutra), vedi <em>computer</em>, <em>file</em>, <em>web</em>.</li><li><strong>prestito integrato</strong>: viene modificato per adeguarlo al sistema fono-morfologico della lingua ricevente.</li></ul><p>Ma i prestiti che "conosci" o di cui ti accorgi sono solo quelli più recenti. Di moltissimi non è ovvia la natura, per esempio:</p><ul><li><strong>cifra</strong> attraverso il latino dall'arabo <em>ṣifr</em> ‘nulla, zero’</li><li><strong>gazzella</strong> come sopra dall'arabo <em>ghazāl</em></li><li><strong>galassia</strong> dal greco <em>galaksías</em>, derivato dalla declinazione <em>gála gálaktos</em> ‘latte’</li><li><strong>bistecca</strong> dall'inglese <em>beef steak</em></li><li><strong>ingaggiare</strong> dal francese antico <em>engagier</em></li></ul><p>Un atteggiamento critico verso i prestiti porta al concetto di <strong>forestierismo</strong> ("da fuori"). Ma anche se forse sembra così, l'italiano non è così conservatore, non più di altri comunque. Lo spagnolo presenta molti prestiti integrati, un esempio è <em>computadora - computer</em> (chiamato anche <em>ordenador</em>). In Francia, l'Académie Française <a href="http://www.academie-francaise.fr/la-langue-francaise/terminologie-et-neologie">propone espressioni e/o termini alternativi a quelli inglesi</a> per favorire la propria lingua.</p><p>Comunque se vuoi leggere di più, ho parlato in precedenza di prestiti in una <a href="http://linguistics.stackexchange.com/a/3071/111">mia risposta su Linguistics SE</a>. </p>

<p>I was watching an Italian movie once, in Italian, with Italian subtitles. If I remember the name of the movie I'll edit this post later. One of the characters said "Boh!" in conversation, and for some reason the subtitles translated it to "Non lo so!"</p><p>I feel like the two best translations to English (depending on context) are "Meh" and the humming variant of "I dunno," although I have no idea how to spell that. If you're the speaker you can use it for either/or.</p>

<p>Is "essere fuori come un balcone" a well recognized phrase in regional usages? </p><p>One time I tell it to a person in Sicily, who was badly parking their car, and I had the impression that they didn't understand that phrase. </p>
titulo: Is "essere fuori come un balcone" a well recognized expression in regional usages?

cuerpo: <p>I believe it comes from <em>essere fuori di senno</em> (having lost one's mind), which is frequently contracted in <em>essere fuori</em> in popular language. Then, this <em>fuori</em> is qualified with something which is commonly outside something else: a balcony sticks out of a house.</p><p>So it's like <em>è fuori di senno come un balcone è fuori dalla casa</em>, but this of course loses freshness.</p><p>Its usage is regional, but spreading, so it's not surprising somebody doesn't understand it.</p>

<p>As others already pointed out, in Italian we have the expression</p><blockquote>  <p>Essere fuori di testa/senno</p></blockquote><p>which almost directly translates to the English</p><blockquote>  <p>To be out of mind</p></blockquote><p>It is then often abbreviated into</p><blockquote>  <p>Essere fuori</p></blockquote><p>which translates to the English</p><blockquote>  <p>To be outside</p></blockquote><p>Whenever one wants to add more emphasis, some analogies for being outside are used.</p><p><em>Essere fuori come un balcone</em> is indeed one of the most common in my region (I'm from Milano in Lombardia), but I bet many other regions have their own versions of it.</p><p>For instance I occasionally heard</p><blockquote>  <p>Sei fuori come una mina</p></blockquote><p>deriving - I believe - from mines (the bombs) to be generally placed in open fields. Generally speaking I think any native speaker would understand any sentence following the pattern <em>Sei fuori come &lt; X ></em>, regardless of having heard the analogy before or not. It might sound weird, but it wouldn't lose the meaning.</p><p>Another funny example is</p><blockquote>  <p>Sono fuori come gli agricoltori che raccolgono i pomodori</p></blockquote><p>as found in the song "<em>Sono fuori</em>" by Articolo 31 (<a href="http://www.angolotesti.it/B/testi_canzoni_blue_32../testo_canzone_sono_fuori_1901.html">lyrics</a>).</p>

<p>Why do Italian road signs use the infinitive tense in their warning, while, for example, those in English use the imperative?</p><blockquote>  <p>Turn off lights</p>    <p>Spegnere le luci (and not "Spegnete le luci" or "Spegni le luci")</p></blockquote><p>Or, maybe, is there a rule that says that the infinitive tense can be work as an imperative? If so, can anyone suggest some cases in which that rule is used in everyday speech?</p>
titulo: Why do Italian road signs use the infinitive tense and not the imperative?

cuerpo: <p>It's probably a shortening of <em>"<strong>Si prega di</strong> spegnere le luci"</em>, which is more polite than the imperative form.</p>

<p>It is an apocope (in Italian <em>troncamento</em> or <em>apocope</em>), a usual phenomenon in which one or more final letters of a word are omitted, usually for metrical or general euphonic reasons, not specific of a particular grammatical person or number (but with its own empirical rules).</p><p>Some <em>troncamenti</em> are now fixed (think about <em>buon giorno</em> rather than *<em>buono giorno</em>, <em>un uomo</em> rather than *<em>uno uomo</em>, <em>dottor Rossi</em> vs.*<em>dottore Rossi</em>). Others are optional, and left to one's sense of the language and the different emphasis to be given to a sentence (<em>ti vuole bene</em> as well as <em>ti vuol bene</em>).</p><p>In Italian you can read more about it in Treccani <em>Enciclopedia dell'Italiano</em>'s <a href="http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/troncamento_%28Enciclopedia-dell%27Italiano%29/">article about <em>troncamento</em></a>.</p>

<p><a href="http://www.treccani.it/vocabolario/rinquartare/" rel="nofollow"><em>Rinquartare</em></a> ha tra i suoi significati “dividere per quattro”, ma visto che può significare anche “moltiplicare per quattro” non lo consiglierei; <a href="http://www.treccani.it/vocabolario/inquartare/" rel="nofollow"><em>inquartare</em></a> e <a href="http://www.treccani.it/vocabolario/interzare/" rel="nofollow"><em>interzare</em></a> hanno anche i significati di dividere per quattro e per tre (oltre ad altri che interferiscono, come sopra), ma sono usati quasi solo in araldica</p>

<p>Visto che la domanda è taggata <a href="/questions/tagged/idioms" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged &#39;idioms&#39;" rel="tag">idioms</a>, mi urge sottolineare che nè "rinquartare", "inquartare", "interzare", "squartare" o "sterzare" sono idiomi in uso comune. Risulta molto più naturale "ridurre a un terzo" &mdash; o meglio ancora, "ridurre <em>di</em> due terzi," "ridurre <em>del</em> 75%."</p><p>Si potrebbe inventare una spiegazione per questa mia impressione da speaker nativo: nell'espressione "ridurre dell'<em>x</em> percento", <em>x</em> è la quantità di riduzione; sembra dunque più logico, o quantomeno più diretto, di "ridurre al (100&minus;<em>x</em>)%."
