cuerpo: <p>What does this phrase mean?What is an equivalent expression in English, and could you give some examples of usage?</p>
titulo: What does "ci mancherebbe altro" mean?

cuerpo: <p>What is the difference between these two gestures:</p><ol><li><p>tips of fingers and tip of thumb together on one hand, pointing upwards, often with an up-and-down movement (i.e. the classic "Che vuoi?" gesture)</p></li><li><p>tips of fingers of left hand lightly touching those of right hand, with the tips of the thumb of each hand also touching (separately), with an up-and-down movement</p></li></ol><p>It seems to me that the two gestures are very similar, and all I can observe is that the first gesture is more aggressive.  How should they be used?</p>
titulo: What is the difference between two gestures ("gesti")

cuerpo: <p>I understand that one meaning of "figurati" is something like "don't mention it", i.e. in response to "grazie".</p><p>But I've seen it is used in many more contexts than that, as an expression of surprise, something like "you don't say".  It's difficult for me to understand the meaning of this phrase, and how the different contexts tie together.  How can I understand the meaning of it?</p>
titulo: What does "figurati" mean?

cuerpo: <p>As this would no doubt be a "cool" word, I have no doubt in my mind that most Italians would say "shopaholic"—assuming they understood what it meant.</p><p>You hear people say "lo shopping" instead of their own (Italian) word, come on.</p>

<p>The second one is something like "oh, please! Come on! Don't you get what you're saying is just nonsense?"<br>Unite hands, like in a prayer, and make the same up-and-down movement is much like a weaker version.<br>The first one you're talking about can have the same meaning as the second one. In this case you usually tilt your head to the right (if you've used the right hand), and you give the other person a look that speaks volumes (oh, please, are you listening to yourself?!)</p>

<p>It can be used as an answer to <em>"Grazie"</em>, like <em>"prego"</em>, <em>"non c'è di che"</em>, <em>"figurati"</em>, but I dare say is the stronger one. To say something stronger you should come up with a long sentence, like </p><blockquote>  <p>"Ma assolutamente, (non pensarci nemmeno) ci mancherebbe altro!".</p></blockquote><p>Basically, you're refusing the idea the other person owes you something.</p><hr><p>Its other meaning... well, the meaning is actually the same one, but the situation you're using it changes, so it doesn't appear so... Like I was saying, the "other meaning" is something like <em>"that's out of discussion"</em>, <em>"it's not gonna happen"</em>, <em>"that's preposterous!"</em>.  For example, you could say, "ci mancherebbe [altro] che dopo quello che è successo ti perdoni": "ci mancherebbe che ti perdoni" could be accurately translated as "there's no way I can forgive you". </p><p>The literal meaning is "(if what you're talking about would actually happen/go through/...) then something would be missing".    </p><p>Imagine you've received an absurd request, and the other person tells you <em>"Well, are you gonna do me this favor?"</em>. you could say <em>"And then what? I could clean your apartment and call you master for the rest of my life!?!"</em></p><p>So, that's what's missing, an even more absurd request, which is unbelievable and still what you've been asked is not that different in its absurdity.</p><hr><p>Finally, there's another use, the one Matteo was talking about in a comment.  This too comes after a request, but you can use it to express your agreement (!).<br>Yeah, the very opposite of the previous one. </p><p>It depends on context, tone of voice etc. but you can also be more explicit.<br>The basic idea is the same one: "(If......) then something would be missing".Let's say someone asks you to stay at your place. You have two choice. You could answer</p><blockquote>  <p>Ma ci mancherebbe altro (che ti ospitassi), non pensarci nemmeno!</p></blockquote><p>The absurd idea is that you let him stay ("che ti ospitassi" means "that I let you stay". Here you're refusing the request, as we already said.  </p><p>However you could answer with something apparently similar, that means the opposite</p><blockquote>  <p>Ma ci mancherebbe altro (che NON ti ospitassi), non devi nemmeno chiederlo!</p></blockquote><p>This time, the absurd idea you can express or not, as you like, the one between parentheses, is the opposite, "che NON ti ospitassi" (that I won't let you stay). So with your expression "ci mancherebbe altro" you're saying that the opposite of the request you received is an absurd idea!</p><p>Do remember you can always add something to be perfectly clear.<br>In this last example you can add "you don't even have to ask!" (non devi nemmeno chiederlo) to refuse the idea you may not listen to the other person's request.<br>Likewise you may add "don't even think about it" in the previous one, when your intention was to refuse the request.</p>

<p>"Figurati" is equivalent to the English expressions 'don't mention it' or 'not at all'. </p><p>It can be used also in different context to express  negative reactions or expectations. Usage is important  to familiarise with this expression. </p><blockquote>  <ul>  <li><p>Figurati se vado in vacanza con i miei genitori!<br>  No way/don't expect that I go on holiday with my parents! </p></li>  <li><p>Figurati se il mio partito vince  le elezioni!<br>  No chance that my political party is going to win  the elections. </p></li>  </ul></blockquote><p>Notice that the implicit subject for "figurati" is "tu"; in a formal conversation, you would rather say "si figuri", which employs "Lei". </p>

<p>Credo che il concetto di memoria <em>condivisa</em> possa essere considerato equivalente a quello di memoria <em>collettiva</em>. Quindi la memoria condivisa è quell'insieme di eventi storici, ricordi e ricorrenze che è posseduto da un gruppo generico di individui, sia esso una setta, un partito, una popolazione. La <a href="http://it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memoria_collettiva" rel="nofollow">pagina</a> di Wikipedia relativa alla memoria collettiva sembra esporre un concetto molto simile a quello contenuto nella <a href="http://www.presentepassato.it/150_anni/2_Memoria/prob_mem11-margalit_memoria_mito.htm" rel="nofollow">pagina</a> riportata da @randomatlabuser. </p>
<p>"Figurati" or  "si figuri" are used in response to "scusami" or "mi scusi" respectively, too.</p>
<p>Con la locuzione 'memoria condivisa' si intende l'insieme degli eventi che due o più persone ricordano con la medesima empatia.</p>

<p>Mettendo insieme gli spunti forniti da <em>uomoinverde</em> e <em>Elberich Schneider</em>, azzardo un'interpretazione.</p><p>Per <em>'memoria condivisa'</em> si intende un insieme di racconti storici o mitici che mantengono vivi in una data comunità senso d'identità, valori, ideali, aspirazioni, usanze, contribuendo insieme ad altri fattori a far da collante tra gli aderenti a quella comunità stessa. Tali racconti debbono essere tali da suscitare emozioni e valutazioni simili e concordi tra i più, o almeno tra chi conta di più, ma senza suscitare eccessivi contrasti, senza scatenare eccessive conflittualità nellacomunità più ampia. Forse questa è la differenza rispetto alla <em>'memoria collettiva'</em> citata da <em>uomoinverde</em> che invece mi sembra possa contenere racconti molto discordi tra di loro, e quindi non abbia la funzione di collante: in questo caso la <em>'memoria condivisa'</em> potrebbe considerarsi un sottoinsieme della <em>'memoria collettiva'</em>? Da notare però che <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collective_memory" rel="nofollow">qui</a> si dice che la memoria collettiva è anche condivisa, nel senso di "shared", e si mette in collegamento con altri concetti quali <em>'intelligenza collettiva'</em>, <em>'coscienza collettiva'</em>, <em>'conoscenza distribuita'</em>: secondo me è "shared" solo nel senso che è generata collettivamente e quindi a disposizione di tutti, ma non tale da generare le stesse risposte emotive come suggerito invece dall'aggettivo italiano "condiviso" che mi sembra più forte dell'inglese "shared".</p><p>Quindi, per fare un esempio, i fatti relativi ad alcune stragi italiane, tra i quali la Strage di Portella della Ginestra (1947), la Strage di Piazza Fontana (1969), la Strage di Piazza della Loggia (1974), la Strage della stazione di Bologna (1980), le Stragi di Capaci e Via D'Amelio (1993), appartenengono tutti alla memoria collettiva italiana, tutti li ricordano; ma i racconti sono discordi, non è una memoria condivisa, le ricorrenze vengono vissute con emozioni contrapposte e tali non da rafforzare il senso d'identità nazionale quanto piuttosto tali da scatenare conflittualità aperte e apparentemente insanabili.</p><p>Per come lo capisco io, il concetto di <em>'memoria condivisa'</em> è associato a quello di <em>'mito fondante'</em> (o <em>fondativo</em>).</p><p><a href="http://www.deportati.it/static/upl/pr/present_cereda.pdf" rel="nofollow">Qui</a> ho trovato alcune opinioni interessanti, ne cito un paio:</p><blockquote>  <p>La memoria è soggettiva, non può essere condivisa; può essere confrontata, ma non condivisa. Ciò che si può cercare di condividere non è una memoria, ma una storia (Walter Barberis)</p>    <p>Memoria collettiva […] non equivale necessariamente a memoria condivisa […]: perché l‟una rimanda ad un unico passato, cui nessuno di noi può sottrarsi e che coincide appunto con la nostra storia; mentre l‟altra sembra presumere un‟operazione più o meno forzosa di azzeramento delle identità e di occultamento delle differenze. Il rischio di una memoria condivisa è una "smemoratezza parteggiata", la comunione della dimenticanza. (Sergio Luzzatto)</p></blockquote><p>E <a href="http://www.presentepassato.it/150_anni/2_Memoria/00_memoria_intervento_fabio.htm" rel="nofollow">qui</a> c'è invece un discorso più ampio in cui si discute di memoria collettiva, condivisa, comune, pubblica, uso pubblico della storia, e altro. Ma ci stiamo allontanando dalla lingua italiana per addentrarci nei meandri insidiosi della filosofia, della storia, della sociologia e della politica.</p>

<p>Your observation is correct: the first gesture carries an aggressive feel, whereas the second one is more apt to a lecture, specifically a telling-off. However, I think there is also a subtle difference in meaning.</p><p>If we were to "translate" the first gesture into words, the result would be akin to either "che vuoi?" o "ma cosa dici?", in an aggressive tone: respectively, you're displaying your annoyment with the other person and "mocking" them for making a statement you deem to be fake.</p><p>The second one, instead, would sound more like:</p><ul><li>"ma per favore", that is, "come on! [That's obviously false!]";</li><li>"I'm disappointed with what I'm talking about, I can't stand it" - this is how you would translate it, when a person is complaining about something, or lecturing you.</li></ul><p>Finally, I believe the first gesture is more typical of southern regions, but don't quote me on that.</p>

<p>The verb <a href="http://www.treccani.it/vocabolario/figurare/" rel="nofollow"><em>figurare</em></a> is directly from Latin, <em>figurare</em>, derived from <em>figura</em>, <em>image</em>, and this from <em>fingĕre</em>, <em>to shape</em>, <em>to model</em>. It has always been used in Italian since the very beginning (Dante, Boccaccio, etc.).</p><p><em>Figurarsi</em> is <em>figurare a sé</em>, to mentally depict a real or hypothetic person, thing or situation, without possessing any previous experience, with the aim to figure out how it would be for real.</p><p><em>Figùrati</em> is imperative mood, <em>figure it out by yourself</em>, and is used to resolutely confirm or deny. It usually means <em>of course not</em> or <em>yes, of course</em>.</p><p>How can you distinguish between the two opposite meanings? By the context, body language, face expressions, etc., there is no other way.</p><blockquote>  <p>«Disturbo?»</p>    <p>«Ma figùrati», smiling in a friendly way --> «Of course not!»</p>    <p>«Disturbo?»</p>    <p>«Ma figùrati», smiling with gritted teeth --> «Of course you are, can't you figure it out by yourself? And, of course, if you can't, I can't do it for you and let you know - I just hope you can make it quick and leave soon».</p></blockquote>

<p>I have decided to be very brave and put my Italian out there in a blog. I will admit that the first entry I am writing is mostly done from a translator site but I want to try it on my own eventually.</p><p>In my first entry, I am writing about how I came to be so interested in Italy and the language. I want to say about the person who first made me focus on Italian</p><p><em>He made the language sing</em>.</p><p>The translator gave me </p><p><em>Lui fa cantare dalla lingua.</em></p><p>which translates back as</p><p><em>He does sing in a language.</em></p><p>which does not say what I want to say. Can someone help me, please?</p><hr><p><em>Based on the advice given, I have edited my composition and published on my new blog -<a href="http://iosonoinitalia.wordpress.com/" rel="nofollow">http://iosonoinitalia.wordpress.com/</a> Polite critic of my Italian is always wlecome there :)</em></p>
titulo: How would I translate "He makes the language sing." into Italian

cuerpo: <p>There is no literal equivalent to "making a language sing", we don't have any such idiom. A literal translation would be <em>far cantare una lingua</em>: an educated native speaker would understand what you mean, although it isn't a common idiom -  in fact, I never heard it.<br>A more natural translation would be something along the lines of "esaltare la <em>musicalità</em> della lingua": in my opinion, that's how a native speaker would translate it. In your case, you could write </p><blockquote>  <p>Mi ha fatto apprezzare la musicalità dell'italiano.<br>  They made me appreciate the music-like aspect of spoken Italian.</p></blockquote><p>As a final note, your translator failed quite a bit. The literal translation of "he made the language sing" is "[lui] ha fatto cantare la lingua"; the translation it gave said "lui fa cantare dalla lingua", which doesn't make any sense but could be interpreted as "he makes people sing from the language". </p>

<p>Well, here is my 2 cents:</p><p><em>Cosare</em> is very informal and slightly humorous in tone.</p><p>I find if <em>very</em> hard to capture its <em>tone</em> in English, and as a native speaker of Italian I think that "doing stuff with the thing" doesn't quite cut it, although it's pretty close.</p><p>The thing is, "cosa" is a <strong>noun</strong> which is used as a verb, which is somewhat less common in Italian than in English - e.g. we say "cercare su Google" instead of "Google it", "Googlare" still sounds wrong to the native ear - it is pretty much a <em>deliberate act</em> of grammatical sabotage, which is why it's both <em>humorous</em> in tone and <em>low-registry</em>.</p><p>It′s hard to give a translation of "cosare" because it basically <em>doesn′t mean anything</em>, it′s essentially a placeholder.</p><p>To convey the meaning as well as the tone I think one should <strong>rewrite the entire sentence</strong> in, well, pretty much this style, using a bit of creativity: <a href="http://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BuffySpeak" rel="nofollow">http://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BuffySpeak</a>:</p><blockquote>  <p><em>Any of a variety of speech patterns used to indicate that a character, while   intelligent, is perhaps too young, too inexperienced and/or  insufficiently educated (or simply talks too fast) to properly express  the complex ideas and thoughts that they clearly possess.</em></p>    <p><em>One of the most obvious elements is a <strong>lack of relevant vocabulary</strong>, leading to both   <strong>unconventional adjectival-noun structures like "shooty-gun thing"</strong>, and incomplete, floundering similes that turn back on themselves in  frustration: "That idea went over like... like... like a thing that  doesn't go over very well." Metaphorgotten is frequently a side  effect. Often includes Oh God, with the Verbing! or similar. And  sometimes Name McAdjective is employed.</em></p></blockquote><p>Notice "lack of relevant vocabulary" (check) and "unconventional structures" (check).</p><p>Taking  a (perhaps extreme) example from that wiki:"People Who Fight And Stuff For Money And It's Fake" (meaning professional wrestlers) would probably be aptly rendered in Italian as "i tizi muscolosi in costume che si <strong>cosano</strong> per finta" (the ripped, costumed guys who fake-<em>cosano</em> each other).</p><p>Hope it helps.</p>
